We measure the ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]/H\\,\\beta }=0.33$|</span> in the spectrum, while in planetary nebulae the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission is 10\u2013100\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We fit Gaussians to the emission lines H\u03b2, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>, H\u03b1, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and the line at 5200\u00a0\u00c5. We find that the FWHM of the 5200\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0emission line is consistent with the FWHM of the forbidden lines for both of the galaxies. We identify the emission line at 5200\u2009\u00c5\u00a0as emission from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|\u2060</span>, using the emission-line catalogue conducted by Kaler, Shaw &amp; Browning (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>, see references therein). <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission is usually observed in planetary nebulae and its strength is typically 10\u2013100\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2 emission, it is also detected in composite quasar spectra with a typical strength that is 10\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2 (Zakamska &amp; Greene\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). In our galaxies, the EW ratio of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> ranges from 0.33 to 1. However, we note one case in the literature where the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission strength is comparable to the H\u03b2 emission, PKS 2322-12 (Costero &amp; Osterbrock\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1977</a>), which is a narrow-line radio galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While galaxies often show strong emission from singly ionized nitrogen (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>), atomic nitrogen is not observed in emission since it is too easy to ionize. Atomic nitrogen can exist in cool areas where it is shielded from ionizing radiation and can be seen in weak emission, most likely due to photoexcitation. An alternative scenario, which can potentially produce stronger <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission, can take place in cool cluster filaments, where the shielded atomic nitrogen is excited by shocks or hard penetrating X-ray photons (Ferland et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). These scenarios however do not explain how we see such strong emission in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> in these galaxies. This may require photoionization calculations that are beyond the scope of this paper.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438681 id=\"58438681\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Unusual emission lines ratios</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Most of the galaxies in this subsample are of known classes, but their emission lines lie at the extreme of their population's respective distribution. These objects show outlying line ratios \u2013 156 of them are outliers on the BPT line diagnostic diagram, and there are 30 galaxies for which only the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{H\\,\\alpha {\\rm -}[N\\,\\small {II}]{\\rm -}[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> complex is detected. Furthermore, they show relatively weak H\u03b1 emission compared to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438683 id=\"58438683\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4-1>4.4.1 Outliers on the BPT diagram</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Prominent emission lines in galaxies have been used to study the physical properties of galaxies and their dominant source of radiation. Baldwin, Phillips &amp; Terlevich (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1981</a>) proposed a diagnostic diagram (known today as the BPT diagram) based on the ratios <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> to separate among gas that is exposed to hard radiation fields, planetary nebulae and H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions. Veilleux &amp; Osterbrock (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>) refined this scheme and added two additional diagnostic diagrams with the ratios <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {I}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|\u2060</span>, based on photoionization models. The SDSS, providing millions of galaxy spectra, has had a great impact on the classification of galaxies and allowed a clean and significant characterization of the different types of galaxies and the transitions between them (Kauffmann et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003b</a>; Kewley et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> a BPT diagram for the emission line ratios: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\beta }$|\u2060</span>. We show typical galaxies from the MPA-JHU catalogue in grey, on a logarithmic colour scale. For our outlying galaxies, we measure the emission lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>, H\u03b1, H\u03b2 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> by integration over Gaussians profiles that we fit: the H\u03b1, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> are modelled jointly with 5 Gaussians at fixed rest-frame wavelengths and the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> and H\u03b2 profiles are similarly measured with 3 Gaussians. We examine the goodness of the fit by eye, and when needed we add additional Gaussian component (e.g. if a profile is not symmetric) or allow the rest-frame wavelength to shift. We mark the emission line ratios of our outliers in green.</p>                        <a id=\"58438686\" scrollto-destination=\"58438686\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=LQ6o9geEGQhP6lhCSGQdJXIcKCU8b8AZRUaHc2hyAXSpT~m2pEG3wBJedwExvUvUN-z0iKkRv4bOci1n0T1FCLN6jahBDSWCQFByVeuL~HmaFlEzblJCOeyDXtOKk7Syeu6VdR-mqGCwnW2fEgWcey90umFUodRiWadPhADNHzxDIrD88r-rwVv8oUVKcOpMZMqSQQjQbuYs9uKJWNGnTeNZgTaibINu2y2hKmTHa5YU0lQnEMZ4xxRapLyUQz9QUg3hR4K3MziptVlMIMAdIp~kC4CNKP4eN1rpqxmMKtPfuFWgp3h8JZz5hNjacAzwSwDbEYWGSXxj4xTk38KqbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"BPT diagrams based on the $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$ emission line ratios (left-hand panel) and $\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$ ratios (right-hand panel). The grey background represents the density of SDSS galaxies (927\u00a0552 galaxies from DR7) on a logarithmic colour scale. Outlying galaxies are marked with green circles. Outlier galaxies that are classified as H\u2009ii regions in one diagnostic and as AGN in another are each plotted with the same marker and colour in both panels. The classification limits are taken from the extreme starburst limit by Kewley et\u00a0al. (2001, Ke01; blue line) and composite galaxies by Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (2003a, Ka03; black line).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438686/stw3021fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438686\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=bs3B5zMwthrzccP651JfJve8hnQQ0hMgm5fdwPlshheOUNft61NlNf3o0LjZR-jnosc3QFA6C5JW23AUhXWDX1l4hpqdo~tnuCOqHIaHCgiA9jpwdi5nHvgioO6iSTV~A8SPszIWW08ly-eKc5AGt8-bOm8UuXoixoe6RCkj1nOmfVsWyWXV~2WCXrfRMgfZpnt8DSrMsl3LbsKKE-50D2C7C8qV8JKli-LReX4LSHCbeLDX4LUb2VZdFHEp6tvima1TUJki39JKVJCJSNZ89qrB~5myn9zPg615dgQbXGrp8kJRBdcmZ0aen7izpgCGGECxwRZUOxM079jzi5RuSw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438686&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">BPT diagrams based on the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> emission line ratios (left-hand panel) and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> ratios (right-hand panel). The grey background represents the density of SDSS galaxies (927\u00a0552 galaxies from DR7) on a logarithmic colour scale. Outlying galaxies are marked with green circles. Outlier galaxies that are classified as H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions in one diagnostic and as AGN in another are each plotted with the same marker and colour in both panels. The classification limits are taken from the extreme starburst limit by Kewley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>, Ke01; blue line) and composite galaxies by Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003a</a>, Ka03; black line).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=LQ6o9geEGQhP6lhCSGQdJXIcKCU8b8AZRUaHc2hyAXSpT~m2pEG3wBJedwExvUvUN-z0iKkRv4bOci1n0T1FCLN6jahBDSWCQFByVeuL~HmaFlEzblJCOeyDXtOKk7Syeu6VdR-mqGCwnW2fEgWcey90umFUodRiWadPhADNHzxDIrD88r-rwVv8oUVKcOpMZMqSQQjQbuYs9uKJWNGnTeNZgTaibINu2y2hKmTHa5YU0lQnEMZ4xxRapLyUQz9QUg3hR4K3MziptVlMIMAdIp~kC4CNKP4eN1rpqxmMKtPfuFWgp3h8JZz5hNjacAzwSwDbEYWGSXxj4xTk38KqbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"BPT diagrams based on the $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$ emission line ratios (left-hand panel) and $\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$ ratios (right-hand panel). The grey background represents the density of SDSS galaxies (927\u00a0552 galaxies from DR7) on a logarithmic colour scale. Outlying galaxies are marked with green circles. Outlier galaxies that are classified as H\u2009ii regions in one diagnostic and as AGN in another are each plotted with the same marker and colour in both panels. The classification limits are taken from the extreme starburst limit by Kewley et\u00a0al. (2001, Ke01; blue line) and composite galaxies by Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (2003a, Ka03; black line).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438686/stw3021fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438686\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=bs3B5zMwthrzccP651JfJve8hnQQ0hMgm5fdwPlshheOUNft61NlNf3o0LjZR-jnosc3QFA6C5JW23AUhXWDX1l4hpqdo~tnuCOqHIaHCgiA9jpwdi5nHvgioO6iSTV~A8SPszIWW08ly-eKc5AGt8-bOm8UuXoixoe6RCkj1nOmfVsWyWXV~2WCXrfRMgfZpnt8DSrMsl3LbsKKE-50D2C7C8qV8JKli-LReX4LSHCbeLDX4LUb2VZdFHEp6tvima1TUJki39JKVJCJSNZ89qrB~5myn9zPg615dgQbXGrp8kJRBdcmZ0aen7izpgCGGECxwRZUOxM079jzi5RuSw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438686&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">BPT diagrams based on the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> emission line ratios (left-hand panel) and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> ratios (right-hand panel). The grey background represents the density of SDSS galaxies (927\u00a0552 galaxies from DR7) on a logarithmic colour scale. Outlying galaxies are marked with green circles. Outlier galaxies that are classified as H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions in one diagnostic and as AGN in another are each plotted with the same marker and colour in both panels. The classification limits are taken from the extreme starburst limit by Kewley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>, Ke01; blue line) and composite galaxies by Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003a</a>, Ka03; black line).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Kewley, Jansen &amp; Geller (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) analysed the effect of a fixed aperture size on metallicity, star formation rate and reddening, and concluded that a minimum aperture covering a fraction of \u224820 per\u00a0cent is required for the spectral properties to approximate the global values, which translates to a lower limit on redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.04 (for the SDSS spectrograph). Out of the 156 emission line galaxies with unusual ratios, only 86 satisfy this criterion. One can see that the outlier galaxies show emission line ratios that reside on the tails of the distribution of the entire population, which explains their weirdness score.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">15 outliers are classified as H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions with one diagnostic and AGN with another diagnostic. We show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> examples for such cases. We use two separating criteria: Kewley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) who used a combination of population synthesis models and photoionization models to produce a theoretical upper limit that separates between starbursts and AGN-dominated galaxies (Ke01; blue line), Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003a</a>) modified this limit by including composite galaxies that contain significant contribution from both star formation and AGN (Ka03; black line). Individual objects that show this duality are marked with the same colour and symbol in the two panels, for convenience. We list the 156 BPT outliers in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A7</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438689 id=\"58438689\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4-2>4.4.2 Weak H\u03b1 emission</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify 30 galaxies with emission in H\u03b1, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> but none in H\u03b2 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|\u2060</span>. Therefore, in order to study their gas emission properties, we fit and subtract a stellar population synthesis model (as in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1.1</a>). These galaxies have unusually large <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and S[II] over H\u03b1 ratios (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha } \\approx 0.1$|\u2060</span>). Some of the objects are low-redshift galaxies, with an angular size a few times the diameter of the SDSS fibre, so the spectrum only samples a small fraction of the gas near the galactic centre.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, we find seven objects with <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.065, and by comparison of their Petrosian radius (from SDSS photometry) to the fibre diameter, we verify that the SDSS fibre indeed captures 20 per cent or more of the galactic light. We measure the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> line ratio for our objects and present it in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a> compared to the line ratio histogram of the MPA-JHU catalogue of galaxies from the SDSS (left-hand panel), where one can see that our objects reside on the tail of this distribution. We give an example of such a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.138 for which <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$|</span> (right-hand panel). We list these galaxies in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A8</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58438692\" scrollto-destination=\"58438692\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=q13B8JWCngyh4zsNwezAG9Rl7TkV6J3UuTBZ0BxbmVkgZyo6d7HoGZQf1KkGqz0YT8V4I~0~1uoHhRSSBS7ZHfw8gPqcJTgo2Z~ekf6twqRTQHybzi1DbrTJC-sekGRgLZhFRFSKx1z--Sl0P~88YEjkx-gpPoVy-eXEFYRqwwrUCpW5cnqjlfUQXQWrB2t6dSOh-TGrrMQHUiKOeD5ekhR1062Y9sB7FDd6UAXgTaZC3KgznWdDYM6kNuNbs9XTXxPUw2cBCsC~IL4PcfnSczA6zbGVLu2F82bwqqCtYg~D1IXHq-zg~M74PwoTU0Bw6X35i5hy32uwbBy7TikLLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between the $\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ line ratio of the 24 outlying galaxies (pink) and the general galaxy population (grey histogram) using the MPA-JHU catalogue of SDSS galaxies (left-hand panel). One can see that the galaxies we find are located on the tail of the general distribution and have unusual line ratios, greater than most of the galaxies in SDSS. We give an example of such a galaxy (SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1; 7054-56575-500) at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.138 that has a ratio $\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438692/stw3021fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438692\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=IhDbD9ztvMRHvstnBNmkf3XyqK2-L~xIsbRW5sU0EinZcn0kFEUMRYiFljd-bOY~0F-3rdGgB4rppdz8Mnh0pql0SqeyeNC4BAp7qLNY7nYXCiJKrei4r1mCkR~QBnIoNOX~vMGzFAC3EvvXC6qy9IERYLHRHtk0ncmp8OgPVUpOL4fWKkhsEmLRA-YNmmg1foUWg5w6KhgH-6cx-mBWVPRQ6~UW13tvbk~4hRketCjW7r6yHz6GhwY9OZq2MM-FpevVxZc0oxTMBTNqTQiWCi7r5xuUq9JoQGibBKUkG2tV5ToNR0ZjL08d1EA7a0tsarmmF-Gj6NVqDdNTWKuyAQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438692&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> line ratio of the 24 outlying galaxies (pink) and the general galaxy population (grey histogram) using the MPA-JHU catalogue of SDSS galaxies (left-hand panel). One can see that the galaxies we find are located on the tail of the general distribution and have unusual line ratios, greater than most of the galaxies in SDSS. We give an example of such a galaxy (SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1; 7054-56575-500) at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.138 that has a ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=q13B8JWCngyh4zsNwezAG9Rl7TkV6J3UuTBZ0BxbmVkgZyo6d7HoGZQf1KkGqz0YT8V4I~0~1uoHhRSSBS7ZHfw8gPqcJTgo2Z~ekf6twqRTQHybzi1DbrTJC-sekGRgLZhFRFSKx1z--Sl0P~88YEjkx-gpPoVy-eXEFYRqwwrUCpW5cnqjlfUQXQWrB2t6dSOh-TGrrMQHUiKOeD5ekhR1062Y9sB7FDd6UAXgTaZC3KgznWdDYM6kNuNbs9XTXxPUw2cBCsC~IL4PcfnSczA6zbGVLu2F82bwqqCtYg~D1IXHq-zg~M74PwoTU0Bw6X35i5hy32uwbBy7TikLLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between the $\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ line ratio of the 24 outlying galaxies (pink) and the general galaxy population (grey histogram) using the MPA-JHU catalogue of SDSS galaxies (left-hand panel). One can see that the galaxies we find are located on the tail of the general distribution and have unusual line ratios, greater than most of the galaxies in SDSS. We give an example of such a galaxy (SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1; 7054-56575-500) at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.138 that has a ratio $\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438692/stw3021fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438692\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=IhDbD9ztvMRHvstnBNmkf3XyqK2-L~xIsbRW5sU0EinZcn0kFEUMRYiFljd-bOY~0F-3rdGgB4rppdz8Mnh0pql0SqeyeNC4BAp7qLNY7nYXCiJKrei4r1mCkR~QBnIoNOX~vMGzFAC3EvvXC6qy9IERYLHRHtk0ncmp8OgPVUpOL4fWKkhsEmLRA-YNmmg1foUWg5w6KhgH-6cx-mBWVPRQ6~UW13tvbk~4hRketCjW7r6yHz6GhwY9OZq2MM-FpevVxZc0oxTMBTNqTQiWCi7r5xuUq9JoQGibBKUkG2tV5ToNR0ZjL08d1EA7a0tsarmmF-Gj6NVqDdNTWKuyAQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438692&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> line ratio of the 24 outlying galaxies (pink) and the general galaxy population (grey histogram) using the MPA-JHU catalogue of SDSS galaxies (left-hand panel). One can see that the galaxies we find are located on the tail of the general distribution and have unusual line ratios, greater than most of the galaxies in SDSS. We give an example of such a galaxy (SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1; 7054-56575-500) at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.138 that has a ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">High <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[N\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> emission line ratios are generally attributed to LINER galaxies (see for example Kewley et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a> and references within), though the ratios we measure for our outlier galaxies deviate from the typical ratio produced by a LINER galaxy. These galaxies can therefore be extreme cases of LINER galaxies in which we do not detect the H\u03b2 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission due to limited SNR, or high dust extinction along the line of sight to the AGN. Alternatively, the high emission line ratio can be due to shock ionization from galactic-scale winds (Heckman\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>; Dopita &amp; Sutherland\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; L\u00edpari et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Veilleux, Cecil &amp; Bland-Hawthorn\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Allen et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). One can find in the literature additional examples of high <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> emission line ratios measured with integral field spectroscopy within individual lines of sight in galaxies (e.g. Singh et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a> and Cheung et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438694 id=\"58438694\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5>4.5 Extremely red and sodium excess galaxies</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 47 galaxies that have extremely red continua and/or unusually strong sodium absorption.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438696 id=\"58438696\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5-1>4.5.1 Sodium excess galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">38 galaxies have very strong sodium (NaID 5889, 5895\u2009\u00c5) absorption, some with extremely red continua as well. There is some debate in the literature regarding the origin of the NaID excess objects \u2013 one explanation is that the NaID excess is related to the interstellar medium (ISM), either due to galactic-scale gaseous outflows in star-forming galaxies or cool gas that resides in the disc, another explanation is that the absorption is stellar, and due to variations in metal abundance. van Dokkum &amp; Conroy (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, and references therein) suggested that an initial mass function (IMF) in early-type galaxies with a larger number of low-mass stars (less than 0.3\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>) may lead to stronger NaID absorption.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to address these questions, Jeong et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a>) compiled a catalogue of roughly 1000 NaID excess objects up to SDSS DR7. They limited themselves to the redshift range <em>z</em> \u2264 0.08 and applied further colour cuts to ensure the completeness of their sample, from which they identified the NaID excess objects. The authors used the absorption line measurements of all the galaxies in the SDSS performed by Oh et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and defined the index fNaD as follows: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{{\\rm fNaD} = \\frac{{\\rm NaD}_{{\\rm observed}} - {\\rm NaD}_{{\\rm model}}}{{\\rm NaD}_{{\\rm model}}}},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where NaD<sub>observed</sub> is the observed NaD line strength and NaD<sub>model</sub> is the expected model NaD line strength. The expected NaD<sub>model</sub> is also taken from Oh et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), where the authors fitted population synthesis models from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and stellar templates by S\u00e1nchez-Bl\u00e1zquez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and calculated internal reddening due to dust. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> chose 1603 galaxies for which <em>f</em>NaD\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.5 (i.e. observed strength is 50\u00a0per\u00a0cent stronger than expected by model; see fig. 1 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a>) and defined them as their sodium excess objects.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 24 galaxies that were not part of the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> sample, some for obvious reasons such as the redshift cut, the SDSS data release, and the colour cuts they performed. We find four galaxies that satisfy the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> cuts in DR7 but were not part of their sample, possibly due to erroneous measurement of the observed NaD. We present in the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a> the histogram of the NaID excess objects from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> compared to the outlying galaxies we find. In the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a>, we show an example of such outlying galaxy, at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.024, compared to the best SDSS model of this galaxy. One can see that the observed NaID is more than double the strength expected from the model. We list the NaID excess objects in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A9</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58438700\" scrollto-destination=\"58438700\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig16\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=zOpNBgPHvhJlE8YirNWRWgK~PLQETRM5hnKib648QIIYKPR1YS0xESj1esheJHkrvbTNpScCyru8fGFVf~VMjMNyuugqxF6YZLgzenS-~-i6OsiuRNITO6L9O1usDi~mJAwAe9Ud8JM-iVOT4UHboINAd~xCRZVLoaE6cU9C8KGk~wfB87FqBe5-PQoDGJH64NsH4vRHNzy5cvVukwfMYxLTT-6IXiJiHmtCR1WmFEwOd2MWV7j1BgVym412EzRa66wwZHIatoZYvbpS2MAekUMES1G9jkBlDwNHyEUf24rXhnGXLsobrQKjWCuvKEvhegUikXiIYo32DhibHdoDQA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of NaID excess index (see Section\u00a04.5.1 for definition) of the NaID excess objects studied by JE13 (grey bars); these are the 1603 galaxies that have the most extreme discrepancy between the observed NaID and the NaID predicted from a standard model of a galaxy. We mark the indices of the 13 outlying objects our algorithms finds, which are also present in the JE13 sample. The right-hand panel presents the galaxy SDSS J123308.44+262057.6 (2235-53847-0086), which is not included in the JE13 catalogue, at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.024 (black), compared to the SDSS best-fitting model (green). One can see that the observed NaID absorption is more than double what is expected from to the best-fitting model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438700/stw3021fig16.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438700\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=xu1zjSqpGMoqs4ZqtGQZwO4Casmf6bmINxrLR1iWTzWFHFB4f3kukvXXI~-8yPzErsr4K5xnzajyr85V3li8KXs0KhW7OCck44XBjWZbh3rXAqC8JxB7UJBB2QnJQsgwGqP8CLcxO9Lt1s8ROnf4ZxQIjIGCs8xOWHlwx6mtpyk5lc2Q7AqPKGx8zwb3VNW9fROaudaB2FngXbre28p3G3b0wzG~D7PuUSGpL4dwqw7qgsAeGeBbR7QHS2CQyfI2zLopJ27fLGUy91ygkyal2q3hhkkG4f4j7A0nCYfjlBtvF~L-9TOOYIwS92kUqmjsyvCfEz4ZSMbwfYP8tPTcvg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438700&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of NaID excess index (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.5.1</a> for definition) of the NaID excess objects studied by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> (grey bars); these are the 1603 galaxies that have the most extreme discrepancy between the observed NaID and the NaID predicted from a standard model of a galaxy. We mark the indices of the 13 outlying objects our algorithms finds, which are also present in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> sample. The right-hand panel presents the galaxy SDSS J123308.44+262057.6 (2235-53847-0086), which is not included in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> catalogue, at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.024 (black), compared to the SDSS best-fitting model (green). One can see that the observed NaID absorption is more than double what is expected from to the best-fitting model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig16\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=zOpNBgPHvhJlE8YirNWRWgK~PLQETRM5hnKib648QIIYKPR1YS0xESj1esheJHkrvbTNpScCyru8fGFVf~VMjMNyuugqxF6YZLgzenS-~-i6OsiuRNITO6L9O1usDi~mJAwAe9Ud8JM-iVOT4UHboINAd~xCRZVLoaE6cU9C8KGk~wfB87FqBe5-PQoDGJH64NsH4vRHNzy5cvVukwfMYxLTT-6IXiJiHmtCR1WmFEwOd2MWV7j1BgVym412EzRa66wwZHIatoZYvbpS2MAekUMES1G9jkBlDwNHyEUf24rXhnGXLsobrQKjWCuvKEvhegUikXiIYo32DhibHdoDQA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of NaID excess index (see Section\u00a04.5.1 for definition) of the NaID excess objects studied by JE13 (grey bars); these are the 1603 galaxies that have the most extreme discrepancy between the observed NaID and the NaID predicted from a standard model of a galaxy. We mark the indices of the 13 outlying objects our algorithms finds, which are also present in the JE13 sample. The right-hand panel presents the galaxy SDSS J123308.44+262057.6 (2235-53847-0086), which is not included in the JE13 catalogue, at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.024 (black), compared to the SDSS best-fitting model (green). One can see that the observed NaID absorption is more than double what is expected from to the best-fitting model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438700/stw3021fig16.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438700\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=xu1zjSqpGMoqs4ZqtGQZwO4Casmf6bmINxrLR1iWTzWFHFB4f3kukvXXI~-8yPzErsr4K5xnzajyr85V3li8KXs0KhW7OCck44XBjWZbh3rXAqC8JxB7UJBB2QnJQsgwGqP8CLcxO9Lt1s8ROnf4ZxQIjIGCs8xOWHlwx6mtpyk5lc2Q7AqPKGx8zwb3VNW9fROaudaB2FngXbre28p3G3b0wzG~D7PuUSGpL4dwqw7qgsAeGeBbR7QHS2CQyfI2zLopJ27fLGUy91ygkyal2q3hhkkG4f4j7A0nCYfjlBtvF~L-9TOOYIwS92kUqmjsyvCfEz4ZSMbwfYP8tPTcvg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438700&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of NaID excess index (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.5.1</a> for definition) of the NaID excess objects studied by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> (grey bars); these are the 1603 galaxies that have the most extreme discrepancy between the observed NaID and the NaID predicted from a standard model of a galaxy. We mark the indices of the 13 outlying objects our algorithms finds, which are also present in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> sample. The right-hand panel presents the galaxy SDSS J123308.44+262057.6 (2235-53847-0086), which is not included in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> catalogue, at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.024 (black), compared to the SDSS best-fitting model (green). One can see that the observed NaID absorption is more than double what is expected from to the best-fitting model.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438701 id=\"58438701\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5-2>4.5.2 Extremely red galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 19 galaxies that are extremely red, most of them show a diagonally shaped continuum. We use the galaxy composite catalogue by Dobos et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a>). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> classified all the galaxies in SDSS DR7 by colour, nuclear activity and star formation activity, and constructed a set of spectra with high SNR and high resolution. They fitted the continuum of the composite spectra using the population synthesis models by Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and found that the composite spectra represent the different galaxy populations well. Using the best stellar population synthesis model, they extracted the best metallically and the optical depth of interstellar dust. The <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> composites are divided into colours \u2013 red, green and blue \u2013 and into classes \u2013 passive, star forming, H\u03b1 detected, AGN and H\u03b1 detected (for objects which show both nuclear activity and substantial star formation), LINERs and Seyfert galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Composite spectra that belong to the same class of galaxies (passive for example) but in a different colour bin differ not only in dust optical depth but also in metallicity and stellar population. We therefore use all the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> composite spectra and apply additional dust reddening to them in order to reach the continuum shape we observe in our galaxies. We use the prescription by Fitzpatrick (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) for the additional dust extinction and find the best composite spectrum and the additional dust reddening to be applied to this composite in order to reproduce the continuum shape of our galaxies. We find that for all of our objects, the reddest composite spectrum is a better fit than the green and the blue. For these <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> derive metallicity value of <em>Z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.02.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The dust reddening we find ranges from <em>E</em>(<em>B\u2212V</em>) = 0.3 to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{{\\rm {\\it E}}}{(B-V}) = 0.9$|</span> for our outlying galaxies; this is in addition to the dust that is derived by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> in their stellar population synthesis models, giving in total colour excesses between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{{\\rm {\\it E}}}{ (B-V)}$|</span>= 0.5 and 2.2. We show two examples of extremely red galaxies and their best <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> composite plus additional reddening in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">17</a>. We find that the best-fitting composite for SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel) belongs to the H\u03b1 detected class, with colour excess derived from population synthesis of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{{\\rm {\\it E}}}{(B-V)} = 0.15$|</span> but with an additional E(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00.95. The second object (right-hand panel), SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-0115), is best described by a LINER galaxy composite with a total of E(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00.98. We list these galaxies in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl10\" data-open=\"tbl10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A10</a>, where we note specifically the galaxy SDSS J044023.25+245402.0 (1257-52944-314) with E(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a01.6, caused by MW dust. These galaxies are rare in SDSS due to colour selection.</p>                        <a id=\"58438705\" scrollto-destination=\"58438705\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig17\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 17.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig17.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=DB0UZ2Z7g-9dGTCIDKA9mGiuPC81cZ5QnkgBnbIupa~smdggyZoTzv5oueVMrOmQCUY4OkL1tJFGOVqLQCM0qUlioDhb~nLYuxaGRwGWpmVEmk9Gyg0N0iljtNwbH10Sdd3TrsuQ6OgUQQV9qKvl86Lc8L78~DAgfFTK2fl34ROMh-Ilwv6qZOpgO3VMB31rZCA-qxKZJdvhwoEHxoSAYEH4iCzHkW55eAA9w9~mSI4peJyxfkIwch5iucJcY9S677moEjZGSa1wX8y~9JpZtZP1TVsJryAAkppsddSSXFbvbMc18lt1FbclC6BAX6nxLPUtnP5KuXqZ~k1BO46pxw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of two galaxies that show diagonally shaped continua. We fit the galaxies with the galaxy composites constructed by DO12 with additional reddening in order to match their red colours. SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with an \u2018H\u03b1 detected\u2019 composite with total dust reddening of EB\u00a0\u2212\u00a0V\u00a0=\u00a01.1 (pink) and SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-115; right-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with a LINER composite with total EB\u00a0\u2212\u00a0V\u00a0=\u00a00.98.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438705/stw3021fig17.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438705\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig17.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=nTuAxkbJJxsuJm10HJbUwPg5ccOGlv7w6pViZz3mk14ZoWvu~CKw0or2dYE7zG2GCBLae-d0xnIj9dP-X26ybpHfA70T9Y0~-0tDCTxGrM4ghXh1ySFZFz-4yrb8ynEi-TlrqAsn0UiRbWtgg34F10RJVIJRoyjpUtxP3PIhiL0rZHax6l1whPasiGmZTKu4ggZGVPJCh3-ZpZT3YkhLf8JfOlZM66d7DBMSTczix4f0YlFc2l3lljhgxP647mskmJx2XwG4l6Sgrjh~taol9mPoEKZsWvv-o8k-~1kmHUn0qRRzmJSHX7MLiYsSzMoh3DCnBHM-yiNS0qQgb5PGSA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438705&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of two galaxies that show diagonally shaped continua. We fit the galaxies with the galaxy composites constructed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> with additional reddening in order to match their red colours. We fit the galaxies with the galaxy composites constructed by DO12 with additional reddening in order to match their red colours. SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with an \u2018H\u03b1 detected\u2019 composite with total dust reddening of EB\u00a0\u2212\u00a0V\u00a0=\u00a01.1 (pink) and SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-115; right-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with a LINER composite with total EB\u00a0\u2212\u00a0V\u00a0=\u00a00.98.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438705/stw3021fig17.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438705\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig17.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=nTuAxkbJJxsuJm10HJbUwPg5ccOGlv7w6pViZz3mk14ZoWvu~CKw0or2dYE7zG2GCBLae-d0xnIj9dP-X26ybpHfA70T9Y0~-0tDCTxGrM4ghXh1ySFZFz-4yrb8ynEi-TlrqAsn0UiRbWtgg34F10RJVIJRoyjpUtxP3PIhiL0rZHax6l1whPasiGmZTKu4ggZGVPJCh3-ZpZT3YkhLf8JfOlZM66d7DBMSTczix4f0YlFc2l3lljhgxP647mskmJx2XwG4l6Sgrjh~taol9mPoEKZsWvv-o8k-~1kmHUn0qRRzmJSHX7MLiYsSzMoh3DCnBHM-yiNS0qQgb5PGSA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438705&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of two galaxies that show diagonally shaped continua. We fit the galaxies with the galaxy composites constructed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> with additional reddening in order to match their red colours. SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with an \u2018H\u03b1 detected\u2019 composite with total dust reddening of E<sub><em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.1 (pink) and SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-115; right-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with a LINER composite with total E<sub><em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.98.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438706 id=\"58438706\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-6>4.6 Galaxies hosting supernovae</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 18 galaxies in which a supernova happens to have exploded when the spectrum was taken. Supernova rates are of order one per galaxy per century (e.g. Li et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), or one per 5000 weeks. Assuming a supernova maintains a luminosity comparable to its host's for about a week, there should be hundreds of such objects in the SDSS galaxy sample, which is rare but not ridiculously so. There are several studies whose main goal is the detection of supernovae in the galaxy spectra of the SDSS, and they found 15 of our objects. In all of these studies, the galaxy spectra are fitted with galaxy eigenspectra that are obtained from PCA analysis of SDSS galaxies. Supernova detection is then carried out on the residual between the galaxy spectrum and its best eigenspectra fit, using various methods of template fitting: Madgwick et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) used wavelet transform in order to obtain a residual which is noiseless, and then cross-correlated it with a set of type Ia spectral templates. Tu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), Krughoff et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), Graur &amp; Maoz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and Graur, Bianco &amp; Modjaz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) used PCA or singular value decomposition (SVD) of supernovae spectroscopic templates to fit the residual. In all of these cases, it was necessary to use both galaxy and supernova templates in order to detect the supernovae. We list the outlying galaxies with supernovae in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl11\" data-open=\"tbl11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A11</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) is reported here for the first time since the galaxy is part of DR10, while Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) worked with the DR9 galaxy sample. We present in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig18\" data-open=\"fig18\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">18</a> the galaxy spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel) where one can notice additional, broad, features that the best SDSS model does not account for. We subtract the best-fitting SDSS model from the spectrum and normalize the residual with a continuum fit and compare the residual to a type Ia supernova template from Nugent, Kim &amp; Perlmutter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) 2\u00a0d after the <em>B</em>-band maximum. This is shown in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig18\" data-open=\"fig18\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">18</a>. One can see that the supernova template matches well the broad residual features in our galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"58438709\" scrollto-destination=\"58438709\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig18\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 18.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig18.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=KpLln~2-yKPi5GU~maXO6yyhbsRJCfI4kEeKpo4LaavYUBB9ZTezQ1UCJ6~H2cBfH9isC8gaF7emkaeHG4ykCLqplskH8QH~V4IVLnpIDT4g9Maf-F83xyFToxBvf~~EmwZmDTfmMeCr8HLFkxHEguUa1hhD7AIa2uHU9TOLJNWuAoRDdr3-sWc7dDlTnF4I5KpPCPQX65~lhE8xA7YM67iHnRDl9HXa~dVfizX5sZJf0ZAVfbsDu8NXjj7HsU5KcqZCkbYSb5nyapsc9gsRcaBvy4GFrzTiF~-hrDRZhkhMuuKQF4LV03qqlF2ohH6M8wtDSFkLOAudnknkVwdcgQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel), where one can see that the SDSS model fails to account for some broad features in the spectrum. We subtract the model from the spectrum and normalize it with a continuum fit (right-hand panel; black) and compare it to a supernova template (2\u00a0d after the peak) which we also normalize (green). One can see that the supernova template is able to account for the residual broad features in the galaxy spectrum.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438709/stw3021fig18.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438709\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig18.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=M7twKoKw7TbcL3ZBsd7iBpTuwO7R3jcXLKgixI~w3BNpruNC0LPaDIPk7f-YPedxLXAa6czvX4EcwyPMtGL29UaZ-pf1aK0MNKvdpT5zO36iqSIcMicmIs8U~MT0dPLJTGWei76wLteL6xh1xuxmEOY6ppAVkdBa0NoCNl61Pxo4ZBc6P35~rqJ8HeNZaeHN2Y9Wc0LrEhaOTygk-2361wvptbfV66C3BJcrZ9qynm-8fFfZr5Fyccq4bi80pxlhjjRs6xwferbDmg3drI027Xi~SWMiAHLC92Dr-ntMFWOF0VxRo-eH-gCXZfsnG9RHJdc3JC51z~1ADOcqLIqj5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438709&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel), where one can see that the SDSS model fails to account for some broad features in the spectrum. We subtract the model from the spectrum and normalize it with a continuum fit (right-hand panel; black) and compare it to a supernova template (2\u00a0d after the peak) which we also normalize (green). One can see that the supernova template is able to account for the residual broad features in the galaxy spectrum.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig18\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 18.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig18.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=KpLln~2-yKPi5GU~maXO6yyhbsRJCfI4kEeKpo4LaavYUBB9ZTezQ1UCJ6~H2cBfH9isC8gaF7emkaeHG4ykCLqplskH8QH~V4IVLnpIDT4g9Maf-F83xyFToxBvf~~EmwZmDTfmMeCr8HLFkxHEguUa1hhD7AIa2uHU9TOLJNWuAoRDdr3-sWc7dDlTnF4I5KpPCPQX65~lhE8xA7YM67iHnRDl9HXa~dVfizX5sZJf0ZAVfbsDu8NXjj7HsU5KcqZCkbYSb5nyapsc9gsRcaBvy4GFrzTiF~-hrDRZhkhMuuKQF4LV03qqlF2ohH6M8wtDSFkLOAudnknkVwdcgQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel), where one can see that the SDSS model fails to account for some broad features in the spectrum. We subtract the model from the spectrum and normalize it with a continuum fit (right-hand panel; black) and compare it to a supernova template (2\u00a0d after the peak) which we also normalize (green). One can see that the supernova template is able to account for the residual broad features in the galaxy spectrum.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438709/stw3021fig18.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438709\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig18.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=M7twKoKw7TbcL3ZBsd7iBpTuwO7R3jcXLKgixI~w3BNpruNC0LPaDIPk7f-YPedxLXAa6czvX4EcwyPMtGL29UaZ-pf1aK0MNKvdpT5zO36iqSIcMicmIs8U~MT0dPLJTGWei76wLteL6xh1xuxmEOY6ppAVkdBa0NoCNl61Pxo4ZBc6P35~rqJ8HeNZaeHN2Y9Wc0LrEhaOTygk-2361wvptbfV66C3BJcrZ9qynm-8fFfZr5Fyccq4bi80pxlhjjRs6xwferbDmg3drI027Xi~SWMiAHLC92Dr-ntMFWOF0VxRo-eH-gCXZfsnG9RHJdc3JC51z~1ADOcqLIqj5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438709&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel), where one can see that the SDSS model fails to account for some broad features in the spectrum. We subtract the model from the spectrum and normalize it with a continuum fit (right-hand panel; black) and compare it to a supernova template (2\u00a0d after the peak) which we also normalize (green). One can see that the supernova template is able to account for the residual broad features in the galaxy spectrum.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J085425.56+180507.0 (2281-53711-0149) and SDSS J085436.69+180552.9 (2281-53711-0156) are also reported here for the first time. These spectra were in DR7, but the SDSS pipeline failed to fit the correct redshift to them, mistaking the H\u03b1 emission for Ly\u2009\u03b1 at high redshift. We derive the correct redshift by fitting the narrow <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> and H\u03b1 emission lines, finding redshifts of 0.094 and 0.211, respectively. For this reason, they were missed by Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Using the same fitting procedure as described in Graur &amp; Maoz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), we find that SDSS J085425.56+180507.0 is either a type Ia or a type Ic near maximum light. SDSS J085436.69+180552.9 is most likely a type Ia near peak (O. Graur, private communication).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438711 id=\"58438711\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-7>4.7 Blends</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 27 outliers that are blends of two objects. These include 6 galaxy\u2013galaxy gravitational lenses, 9 spectra with two sets of emission lines, and 12 spectra that appear unusual due to chance alignment of a galaxy and a nearby star. We list the galaxies that are contaminated by nearby stars in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl12\" data-open=\"tbl12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A12</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple studies were carried out with the goal of finding gravitationally lensed galaxies in the SDSS spectroscopic data (Bolton et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Brownstein et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Tsalmantza &amp; Hogg\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Shu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). These studies focused on galaxies with two sets of nebular emission lines at redshifts that differ significantly. For example, Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) used the best-fitting model obtained by the SDSS pipeline and subtracted it from the spectrum, resulting in a residual spectrum. The residual spectrum underwent a match-filtering algorithm that was designed to find an additional set of emission lines. Tsalmantza &amp; Hogg (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) used a data-driven model that recovered most of the known galaxy lenses in the SDSS by constructing basis functions for dimensionality reduction. Overall, up to DR12, these studies have found 392 galaxy lens candidates in the SDSS. We list the six galaxy lenses our algorithm recovers in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl13\" data-open=\"tbl13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A13</a>, all of which were reported by previous studies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The second subset consists of objects with two sets of emission lines that were not previously reported as galaxy lenses. The second set of nebular emission lines is due to a close companion (i.e. at a small angular separation) to the primary galaxy, and in most of the objects the primary and the companion galaxy are somewhat to well distinguished in the SDSS imaging. For each of the objects, we fit two sets of emission lines with Gaussians in order to ascertain that all the nebular lines of the secondary set differ by the same velocity compared to the primary set of lines and measure the redshift of the secondary object. In all of the cases, the redshift produced by the SDSS pipeline belongs to the more luminous set of emission lines. We find that for seven out of eight of the objects the secondary set of emission lines is emitted by gas at a lower redshift than the primary. For three of the pairs, we find an SDSS spectrum of the secondary galaxy as well as the primary, and find that the redshift estimation of the secondary galaxy is equal to the redshift we derive from the second set of emission lines in the primary's object spectrum. We present an example of such galaxy in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig19\" data-open=\"fig19\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">19</a>, where we show the SDSS image of the primary and secondary galaxy (left-hand panel; the cross indicates the primary object) and the spectrum of the primary, shifted to its rest frame, where one can see two sets of emission lines. The first set of emission lines is at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the second set at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063, which is the redshift of the secondary galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"58438715\" scrollto-destination=\"58438715\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig19\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 19.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig19.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=QipTlMwfxehqcB8AE9yUGyuyJIAqoqVLLhywlAuYykrhjd4hIYUtcdY-GNa4wtSdbLHpMMxU5dKOHEteHXB48jJiS8FD2VueuF6XusmDE6n5sCdwMAOjAfpmvo3iZ9mmyT7NI87HYrdxHbKpt6rOd3B1rpcmSoK9a6cGP1WvFMDDOBNdZXEyQVdAYGOxU-MOME6cOs4ePddW1jzh8f1r-1qk3jVDhBkQ9S-CsAu10sk-ovnlmH4D8Y62BXHgNAue0GPrPfVW0747URXmgL42Ht0ziQ6jD2EDfwwxfUXaq4LbmvAirJUqNeg4BpAszF-E4HRhhrYfIyBCpjiL~z2CaA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example of a galaxy with two sets of emission lines. The primary galaxy (SDSS J161754.02+320627.4; 1420-53146-528), marked with a cross in the image from the SDSS (left-hand panel), is at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.117. The secondary galaxy (SDSS J161753.62+320633.8) is at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.063 and the gas in its outskirts is along the line of sight towards the primary galaxy. The spectrum of the primary galaxy (right-hand panel) consists of two sets of emission lines, one at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the other at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.063.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438715/stw3021fig19.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438715\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig19.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=GwrJe88rlpoDoUNRdt1r7S~gbFBMYygPYfdyyyJmuAHSLFCGx2f~4RkvtcKQHAhj0LV~jzRkFPTGYOrSbbKpOmXk-BNWAmsUdQ2nUD~YBoxBpiRKjMEcP7304fqHSbKYiY4RA3GS9IOs1pzRLmqiwrDHpbOLqby8bXCP9HiPgJh0cqezf-LGkW2yXrmWkwown2NUfgvpgzlhJ~jz0BY~G9dkrs9LGd5tDd0DKYWHJ2ZW3mDdKbg7EqQM7-n20iP456EqAwyZ48Oo~~NIrNZlnvIhZszLZvH66msgIuWxsanLncN-2swv54dRcAv1Rqd5zxasE7BDuRo8x42bxLljBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438715&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of a galaxy with two sets of emission lines. The primary galaxy (SDSS J161754.02+320627.4; 1420-53146-528), marked with a cross in the image from the SDSS (left-hand panel), is at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117. The secondary galaxy (SDSS J161753.62+320633.8) is at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063 and the gas in its outskirts is along the line of sight towards the primary galaxy.
