The primary galaxy (SDSS J161754.02+320627.4; 1420-53146-528), marked with a cross in the image from the SDSS (left-hand panel), is at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.117. The secondary galaxy (SDSS J161753.62+320633.8) is at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.063 and the gas in its outskirts is along the line of sight towards the primary galaxy. The spectrum of the primary galaxy (right-hand panel) consists of two sets of emission lines, one at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the other at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.063.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438715/stw3021fig19.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438715\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig19.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=GwrJe88rlpoDoUNRdt1r7S~gbFBMYygPYfdyyyJmuAHSLFCGx2f~4RkvtcKQHAhj0LV~jzRkFPTGYOrSbbKpOmXk-BNWAmsUdQ2nUD~YBoxBpiRKjMEcP7304fqHSbKYiY4RA3GS9IOs1pzRLmqiwrDHpbOLqby8bXCP9HiPgJh0cqezf-LGkW2yXrmWkwown2NUfgvpgzlhJ~jz0BY~G9dkrs9LGd5tDd0DKYWHJ2ZW3mDdKbg7EqQM7-n20iP456EqAwyZ48Oo~~NIrNZlnvIhZszLZvH66msgIuWxsanLncN-2swv54dRcAv1Rqd5zxasE7BDuRo8x42bxLljBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438715&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of a galaxy with two sets of emission lines. The primary galaxy (SDSS J161754.02+320627.4; 1420-53146-528), marked with a cross in the image from the SDSS (left-hand panel), is at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117. The secondary galaxy (SDSS J161753.62+320633.8) is at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063 and the gas in its outskirts is along the line of sight towards the primary galaxy. The spectrum of the primary galaxy (right-hand panel) consists of two sets of emission lines, one at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the other at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We list all the objects in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl14\" data-open=\"tbl14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a>, and note the redshift of the primary and secondary sets of lines. One of the objects, SDSS J160818.74\u2212002745.4 (345-51690-229), is an exception, since no clear companion can be seen in the imaging. Furthermore, the secondary set of emission lines is at a higher redshift than the primary galaxy, and these two sets are separated only by 2860\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The spectrum provided by the SDSS is a median spectrum that consists of a few subexposures of the same galaxy, each of them undergoes a separate wavelength solution, sky subtraction and flux calibration. The calibrated spectra are then combined using a median filter. A wrong wavelength solution could cause the median spectrum (with which we work) to appear as a spectrum with two (or more) sets of emission lines. We compare the subexposures of J160818.74-002745.4 and find two sets of emission lines in all of them, indicating that this is not an instrumental error.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note an additional object, SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773), for which the secondary redshift estimation is based only on two emission lines, one of which is marginally detected. The primary redshift of the galaxy is <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133 and no clear companion is detected in the imaging. However, we find an unidentified emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observer's frame, and its FWHM is inconsistent with the FWHM of the emission lines of the galaxy. Assuming the unidentified emission line is due to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> 3727\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the rest frame of a background galaxy, we estimate the redshift of the background galaxy to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733. We show the spectrum of the galaxy in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig20\" data-open=\"fig20\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">20</a>, where the supposedly <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission is marked with a green dashed line (left-hand panel). In the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig20\" data-open=\"fig20\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">20</a>, we mark the wavelength of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> 5007\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame for the redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733, which match a weak feature in the spectrum. The FWHM values of both of them are consistent with each other. The flux of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission is in the range expected from star forming galaxies at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733, thus no magnification is needed in order to explain the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission strength. We therefore conclude that their background galaxy is not strongly lensed.</p>                        <a id=\"58438718\" scrollto-destination=\"58438718\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig20\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 20.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig20.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=N09VPJuF00xmZJBIl7QCqXbqwyyEE6JY7LURHj5IoLNbhzw7YHUPQssdW2CSxk7xYku2EN9PqkI~wB~uqJTKt9MJ5wB6GzMhWm6nnWwREh15k1qSvG~VF2a0ew85elVVci918YyF6ElsfGDxZcj-aJP3qGm3iZ1kpovRkbYFqHSxN0a2cXyVMFX4A-iFiNth24IzTUUgPf-7K3VF1PLcJWAHSwsFambuGW2~9TzfHA1uOkoPeemoWYLdw6TgHlumlLMDwYZ6MV~xyKquhtd2mI07rvwGmJS9jofUwlM1ygrPvmIoMg5lue3yz7cOy9fEyol4gJ6KfkQ~yn9giZ0ImQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773) is a galaxy at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.133 for which we detect an emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame. This emission line is broader than the emission lines that belong to this galaxy (left-hand panel) and does not match in wavelength to any known emission lines at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.133. Assuming the emission line is due to $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$ 3727\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the rest frame of a background galaxy, we estimate the redshift of the background galaxy to be z\u00a0=\u00a00.733. We mark in the right-hand panel the wavelength of $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$ 5007\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame for the redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.733, which matches a weak feature in the spectrum. Since the flux of the supposed $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$ emission is within the range expected for galaxies at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.7, we conclude that this galaxy is another case of galaxy\u2013galaxy chance alignment.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438718/stw3021fig20.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438718\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig20.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Nf6QsfwTndMsLiNx5kdZOdnU3FPRyPdQmSve1Rvrp~bGIIFBOg4vL0AQhtA1GJc5AM8eUFpxW6wBS2RZgsnK43KynvK3P6HrN8qSMYbua8HOpMSmHS6MshDOst~ejxYbngs6IOCWiKbekMq2kOL~et6gAtO0TyUqxmOMQaUj9Pce9lS55KnptVVPeSV8HjT6mfsAYcsoWnTHgL3QqtpehlvLsjhoEZWxfePC3vg~rk19xYqe5Ca2Wsxd70fb1aYsfDDauS4nbIECgI4ZwMsBLn8HZYVxxJyGOh-hAvHjQywBaRXIu-nMNtyySSZzewec9tad~3ODyg7nns2GL~0s5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438718&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133 for which we detect an emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame. This emission line is broader than the emission lines that belong to this galaxy (left-hand panel) and does not match in wavelength to any known emission lines at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133. Assuming the emission line is due to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> 3727\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the rest frame of a background galaxy, we estimate the redshift of the background galaxy to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733. We mark in the right-hand panel the wavelength of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> 5007\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame for the redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733, which matches a weak feature in the spectrum. Since the flux of the supposed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission is within the range expected for galaxies at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.7, we conclude that this galaxy is another case of galaxy\u2013galaxy chance alignment.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig20\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 20.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig20.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=N09VPJuF00xmZJBIl7QCqXbqwyyEE6JY7LURHj5IoLNbhzw7YHUPQssdW2CSxk7xYku2EN9PqkI~wB~uqJTKt9MJ5wB6GzMhWm6nnWwREh15k1qSvG~VF2a0ew85elVVci918YyF6ElsfGDxZcj-aJP3qGm3iZ1kpovRkbYFqHSxN0a2cXyVMFX4A-iFiNth24IzTUUgPf-7K3VF1PLcJWAHSwsFambuGW2~9TzfHA1uOkoPeemoWYLdw6TgHlumlLMDwYZ6MV~xyKquhtd2mI07rvwGmJS9jofUwlM1ygrPvmIoMg5lue3yz7cOy9fEyol4gJ6KfkQ~yn9giZ0ImQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773) is a galaxy at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.133 for which we detect an emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame. This emission line is broader than the emission lines that belong to this galaxy (left-hand panel) and does not match in wavelength to any known emission lines at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.133. Since the flux of the supposed $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$ emission is within the range expected for galaxies at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.7, we conclude that this galaxy is another case of galaxy\u2013galaxy chance alignment.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438718/stw3021fig20.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438718\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig20.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Nf6QsfwTndMsLiNx5kdZOdnU3FPRyPdQmSve1Rvrp~bGIIFBOg4vL0AQhtA1GJc5AM8eUFpxW6wBS2RZgsnK43KynvK3P6HrN8qSMYbua8HOpMSmHS6MshDOst~ejxYbngs6IOCWiKbekMq2kOL~et6gAtO0TyUqxmOMQaUj9Pce9lS55KnptVVPeSV8HjT6mfsAYcsoWnTHgL3QqtpehlvLsjhoEZWxfePC3vg~rk19xYqe5Ca2Wsxd70fb1aYsfDDauS4nbIECgI4ZwMsBLn8HZYVxxJyGOh-hAvHjQywBaRXIu-nMNtyySSZzewec9tad~3ODyg7nns2GL~0s5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438718&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133 for which we detect an emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame. This emission line is broader than the emission lines that belong to this galaxy (left-hand panel) and does not match in wavelength to any known emission lines at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133. Assuming the emission line is due to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> 3727\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the rest frame of a background galaxy, we estimate the redshift of the background galaxy to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733. We mark in the right-hand panel the wavelength of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> 5007\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame for the redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733, which matches a weak feature in the spectrum. Since the flux of the supposed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission is within the range expected for galaxies at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.7, we conclude that this galaxy is another case of galaxy\u2013galaxy chance alignment.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438719 id=\"58438719\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-8>4.8 Calibration errors, source confusion and sky contamination</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This group of outliers is a mixed bag of objects that are broadly defined as not being astronomically \u2018interesting\u2019. This includes calibration errors and SDSS pipeline misclassifications. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we remove pixels that are marked as bad by the SDSS pipeline, and we also apply a median filter for the removal of residual cosmic rays and unresolved sky emission. The SDSS also provides quality flags for all the plates and all their spectra. Since we do not limit ourselves to plates of good quality only, it is inevitable that some bad spectra exist in our data set. Additionally, our algorithm finds the relatively few objects that were misclassified by the SDSS pipeline, and we include them here.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">First, we identify 41 galaxy spectra that are in fact single stars. Additionally, we find five spectra of white dwarfs that were mistakenly identified as galaxies, four of these were previously reported as white dwarfs by Girven et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and Kleinman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and one of them, SDSS J103259.82+442202.2 (2567-54179-177), is reported here for the first time. SDSS J141118.31+481257.6 (1671-53446-0010) is identified as a galaxy at redshift 0.135 by the SDSS pipeline. However, it is actually an AM Canum Venaticorum star, which is a rare type of cataclysmic variable star, where a white dwarf accretes hydrogen-poor matter from a compact companion star (Anderson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). We list these in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl15\" data-open=\"tbl15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>. Finally, 10 objects suffer from various problems such as bad sky subtraction and wrong flux calibration (i.e. flux level from the blue and red arms of the spectrograph do not match; Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl16\" data-open=\"tbl16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438722 id=\"58438722\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CONCLUSIONS AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have introduced an outlier detection algorithm that is based on an unsupervised implementation of RF. By construction, the algorithm learns the most important features of the data and their interconnections; it is completely general and can be applied to imaging data, time series and other spectroscopic objects as well. Out of 2355\u00a0926 galaxies that compose the input sample, we chose 400 galaxies with the highest weirdness score. We find objects with unusual emission line ratios, and complex velocity structures, extremely red objects, objects with extremely strong absorption lines (i.e. sodium and H\u03b4), galaxies which host supernovae, or have rare emission lines.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The algorithm finds a large variety of outliers arising from a large variety of physical environments. It is sensitive to the ratio between emission lines, thus to the radiation field that gas in a galaxy is exposed to, and to the metallically of the gas. It is sensitive to the widths of emission lines i.e. objects with extreme velocity dispersion, or with a number of different velocity components. It is sensitive to the shape of the continuum and to its connection to the strength of the emission lines and absorption lines. It recovers a number of rare phenomena that are subject to great attention in the astronomical community: H\u03b4-strong galaxies, outflows and shocks, supernovae, galaxy-lenses, double-peaked emission lines that may be due to galaxy mergers or binary BHs. Only about a fifth of the objects we find were discovered in previous studies, using specific algorithms that isolate a single type of objects they were looking for (or searching by eye). Our algorithm detects all of them in one fell swoop. Despite how thoroughly SDSS has been explored before, we found two rare classes of galaxies that were never noticed or studied before, E+A galaxies with broad emission lines and strong <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span>-emitting galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Apart from these, the algorithm detects a number of different \u2018instrumental\u2019 outliers, and can be used to detect pipeline failures in new or ongoing surveys. Most importantly, since the sole input to the algorithm is the data, with no physical rules or user specifications, and we find that it is able to detect some of the most interesting phenomena in the SDSS sample, this algorithm can be used to search for new objects that represent new phenomena \u2013 searching for the truly unknown unknowns.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From a performance perspective, the increasing volume and complexity of astronomical data requires the development of new algorithms for detection, classification and analysis of large data sets. The LSST, for example, is expected to conduct 32 trillion observations of 40 billion objects (Ivezic et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). These data sets can no longer be placed on a single compute node nor can they be analysed at once with a single processor. The framework of DFS has evolved as a possible solution to this challenge and parallelization had become an essential methodology in it. The RF-based outlier detection we propose is completely parallel and operates naturally in the DFS framework. Furthermore, the algorithm is suitable for ongoing surveys where static data are replaced by data streams \u2013 new data are chunked and decision trees are trained without the need to re-run the process on the entire data set. RF's ability to operate with missing values is an additional important feature. Finally, the algorithm can work with an extremely large number of features with little to no cost in execution time.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438727 id=\"58438727\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgments</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank our referee, Y. Ascasibar, for useful comments and suggestions that helped improve this manuscript. We thank G. Ferland, N. Foerster Schreiber, A. Gal-Yam, O. Graur, T. Heckman, D. Maoz, B. M\u00e9nard, H. Netzer, P. Nugent, E. Ofek, J. X. Prochaska and D. Watson who helped us identify some of the unusual objects we found, and gave us valuable advice regarding this manuscript. DP is partially supported by Grant No 2014413 from the United States\u2013Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The bulk of our computations was performed on the resources of the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center, which is supported by the Office of Science of the U.S. Department of Energy under Contract No. DE-AC02-05CH11231. The spectroscopic analysis was made using <span class=\"small-caps\">ipython</span> (P\u00e9rez &amp; Granger\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). We also used the following <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> packages: pyspeckit,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> scikit-learn<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> (Pedregosa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and astropy.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work made extensive use of the SDSS-III<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a> data. Funding for SDSS-III has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation and the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science. SDSS-III is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS-III Collaboration including the University of Arizona, the Brazilian Participation Group, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Carnegie Mellon University, University of Florida, the French Participation Group, the German Participation Group, Harvard University, the Instituto de Astrofisica de </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib7\" data-legacy-id=\"bib7\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib7\" href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Andrae</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div></span>, <span class=\"name class=\"given-names\">M.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">A&amp;A</div>, <div class=\"volume\">522</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">A21</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201014169\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" We note that some galaxies are classified into multiple categories; in this case, we present the galaxy in every class (and table) it belongs to.</p>                        <a id=\"58438743\" class=\"chapter-para\">(2) SDSS MJD of the observation.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN054\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN054\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(3) SDSS fibre ID of the galaxy.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN055\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN055\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(4) Redshift from SDSS pipeline, whenever available we use <em>z</em><sub>NOQSO</sub> that is more reliable.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN056\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN056\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(5) Best-fitting template from the SDSS galaxy composites by Dobos et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p></span></div><span class=\"articleListNewPopContent articleListNewAndPopular-ContentView-MostRecent hasContent\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"newPopularList-Article_RightRailB0Article_RightRail_ArticleNewPopularCombined\" class=\"fb\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-layout widget-layout--vert\">\r\n            <div class=\"widget-columns widget-col-1\">\r\n                    <div class=\"col\">\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3878\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3878/6041709?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"chapter-para\">(5) Additional comments, if the redshift given by the SDSS pipeline is wrong due to broad emission lines we note the correct redshift.</p></span></div><span (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span>2012).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn class=\"chapter-para\">(4) Redshift from SDSS pipeline, whenever available we use <em>z</em><sub>NOQSO</sub> which is more reliable.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA; content-id=\"TFN052\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(1) SDSS plate ID of the galaxy.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN053\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN053\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(2) SDSS MJD of the observation.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN054\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN054\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(3) SDSS fibre ID of the galaxy.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN055\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN055\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(4) Redshift from SDSS pipeline, whenever available we use <em>z</em><sub>NOQSO</sub> that is more reliable.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN056\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN056\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(5) Best-fitting template from the SDSS galaxy composites by Dobos et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span>2012).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN057\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN057\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(6) Additional dust reddening to be applied in order to obtain the continuum shape of the galaxy.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig class=\"chapter-para\">(4) Redshift from SDSS pipeline, whenever available we use <em>z</em><sub>NOQSO</sub> that is more reliable.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN027\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN027\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(5) Additional comments, if the redshift given by the SDSS pipeline is wrong we note the correct redshift.</p></span></div><span (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n            hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\"     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438599 id=\"58438599\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">How can we discover objects we did not know existed within the large data sets that now abound in astronomy? We present an outlier detection algorithm that we developed, based on an unsupervised Random Forest. We test the algorithm on more than two million galaxy spectra from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and examine the 400 galaxies with the highest outlier score. We find objects which have extreme emission line ratios and abnormally strong absorption lines, objects with unusual continua, including extremely reddened galaxies. We find galaxy\u2013galaxy gravitational lenses, double-peaked emission line galaxies and close galaxy pairs. We find galaxies with high ionization lines, galaxies that host supernovae and galaxies with unusual gas kinematics. Only a fraction of the outliers we find were reported by previous studies that used specific and tailored algorithms to find a single class of unusual objects. Our algorithm is general and detects all of these classes, and many more, regardless of what makes them peculiar. It can be executed on imaging, time series and other spectroscopic data, operates well with thousands of features, is not sensitive to missing values and is easily parallelizable.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: data analysis&quot;\">methods: data analysis</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: general&quot;\">galaxies: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: peculiar&quot;\">galaxies: peculiar</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438601 id=\"58438601\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The amount of astronomical data and its complexity grows rapidly, thus introducing astronomy to the era of Big Data science. Ongoing and future large surveys provide astronomers with a wealth of information to be analysed and extracted from rich and complex data types. The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) has provided the community with multicoloured images of approximately one third of the sky, and spectra of more than three million objects (York et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). The Palomar Transient Factory (PTF; Law et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and Pan-STARRS (Kaiser et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) monitored the variable night sky and studied numerous asteroids, variable stars, supernovae, active galactic nuclei (AGN) and more. Future surveys will increase by orders of magnitude the number of available objects and the information each of these holds. This includes most notably Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) (Ivezic et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), DESI (Levi et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and ZTF (Bellm\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). These challenge astronomers to move on from the traditional data analysis and visualization techniques and develop new, Big-Data appropriate, tools (Pesenson, Pesenson &amp; McCollum\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In view of this accelerating growth, astronomers start to develop automated tools in order to detect, characterize and classify objects based on the immense amount of information they are gathering. Following that, it is necessary to point towards objects that hold the largest amount of new information by developing automated decision-making tools that can process large numbers of objects and draw our specific attention. Supervised Machine Learning (ML) algorithms are used to detect predefined objects of interest, and unsupervised learning algorithms to classify objects and find correlations in high dimensional data (Collister &amp; Lahav\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Re Fiorentin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Daniel et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Morales-Luis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Richards et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Fustes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; S\u00e1nchez Almeida &amp; Allende Prieto\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Masci et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Baron et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Hocking et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Miller\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Wright et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Djorgovski et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Lochner et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Mackenzie, Pichara &amp; Protopapas\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Rubin &amp; Gal-Yam\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; for additional references and review see Ball &amp; Brunner\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The natural step after classification and the analysis of different clusters is outlier detection and characterization. Outliers can be objects that were not intended to be included in the original sample, various errors, extreme objects that reside on the tail of well characterized distributions, and completely new objects that offer the opportunity to unveil new physics. To paraphrase Donald Rumsfeld:<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> normal objects are the \u2018known knowns\u2019; outliers of kinds discovered before are \u2018known unknowns\u2019; but the most interesting, and challenging to find in large data sets, are the \u2018unknown unknowns\u2019, objects we did not know we should be looking for (Norris <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83a\" data-open=\"bib83a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Our goal in this paper is to present such an outlier detection algorithm and its application on the well-studied sample of the SDSS galaxy spectra, as a first test.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Random Forest (RF; Breiman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>; Breiman\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) is being used extensively in astronomy, though as a supervised learning algorithm. Its main advantages are that it offers a feature importance ranking, and it can be easily parallelizable. Studies train RF to distinguish between different classes of objects based on their features. This is being done by construction of a sample in which objects are already (manually or via a different method) labelled. This sample is the training sample with which the algorithm is trained to distinguish between different classes of objects. These decision rules are then applied to a sample of interest with no labels. RF is used for classification of transients in PTF (Bloom et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and in the Dark Energy Survey (Goldstein et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), and it was recently proposed for gravitational wave searches of black hole binary coalescence (Baker et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our outlier detection is based on an unsupervised RF, thus we do not have labelled data, and expect the algorithm to learn the data through its features with no additional user-defined input. Our algorithm is based on the work of Shi &amp; Horvath (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), but with modifications that make it suitable for this task. For other anomaly detection algorithms, see Goix (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, e.g. the work of Liu, Ting &amp; Zhou\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). We test the algorithm on one of the most extensively studied samples \u2013 the SDSS galaxy spectra. The 12th data release (DR12) of SDSS includes spectra of more than 2 million galaxies, approximately half of which were released to the public 7\u00a0yr ago. These galaxies were characterized and classified thoroughly, and unusual objects were found, making it a useful benchmark (see for example Andrae, Melchior &amp; Bartelmann\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; S\u00e1nchez Almeida et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ascasibar &amp; S\u00e1nchez Almeida\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Huertas-Company et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As we show below, we find different kinds of outliers that were found by previous studies, but more importantly, some of the outliers we find are new, even in a sample as thoroughly studied as this one. We show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> a sample of outlying galaxies that our algorithm detects, some of them are further discussed in later sections. Clearly, we find objects with a wide variety of properties.</p>                        <a id=\"58438608\" scrollto-destination=\"58438608\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=F18FoaO62tix20edX0GhLACQbnGW5NLYlTpsVrhAtXwiPOFgYfx0F1QlSOArReuuX9K4BJZ2MZ~QVzUQPZZoUh~FA-Br23jTGj0yjtjRMUX3ZWAwe4h23crvo3f4RELxjeupLUU341wwhL1M1EpmWmiXgnDesYvyyOcwVKuIUDOU-MKse6hmd~YnoIv8gWJMwkTNnxSWItHywVgjiLWxAKbuIkY546jw-M3WK-HUA9daHec6SJkUqqQos4PvcrTP1DDBR9ROhEUAaYT0l9z6tvk70mq8NhTDpWwAgSsHzIP4C2H4sE-~30l14rY~TgrUGcapfwa6pebuGTFcF79X9Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\"
