outlier detection algorithm, sporting a large variety of unusual features, all found within a single run of the algorithm.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=F18FoaO62tix20edX0GhLACQbnGW5NLYlTpsVrhAtXwiPOFgYfx0F1QlSOArReuuX9K4BJZ2MZ~QVzUQPZZoUh~FA-Br23jTGj0yjtjRMUX3ZWAwe4h23crvo3f4RELxjeupLUU341wwhL1M1EpmWmiXgnDesYvyyOcwVKuIUDOU-MKse6hmd~YnoIv8gWJMwkTNnxSWItHywVgjiLWxAKbuIkY546jw-M3WK-HUA9daHec6SJkUqqQos4PvcrTP1DDBR9ROhEUAaYT0l9z6tvk70mq8NhTDpWwAgSsHzIP4C2H4sE-~30l14rY~TgrUGcapfwa6pebuGTFcF79X9Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A sample of the outliers we find with the outlier detection algorithm, sporting a large variety of unusual features, all found within a single run of the algorithm.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438608/stw3021fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438608\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=z0M4GURF8tkieJThBih1tIX9Bk8nDOgUfLoxk4bABAvNlfrm-nZsNhKFxqhkf1SCeDN5jRxLOE92riq3pfWZ6ChmKZGzSmeu69uWiWOzp6f7YqlQujG67ejFjJL50qUfcSQOZbz1OEm-nI~0GHJi1g3ayvRF2~8yHTK3GDaKxqp~zG3ry6NbfrKN01x2KcuiY7KkUK2wsIdfvqPasalsikizpGy4Edjc4jk5rVRNKe0IWGpENluqny8RiFrTejsfePklyMVn5LYUniBnk48Rvl9YVUFIJdo9DSW42m4~PNclGKFafWEivK3b8LCcr2PiRS8PE81qM79RfBVZvQYU5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438608&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A sample of the outliers we find with the outlier detection algorithm, sporting a large variety of unusual features, all found within a single run of the algorithm.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We describe the galaxy sample in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> and present the outlier detection algorithm in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. We then present and discuss the 400 weirdest spectra found by the algorithm in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. We conclude with a discussion regarding other potential uses of the algorithm in astronomy in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438610 id=\"58438610\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DATA SET</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our sample consists of all the galaxy spectra from SDSS DR12 (Alam et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), obtained with both the SDSS and BOSS spectrographs (see Ahn et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Although the spectrographs differ in fibre diameter and wavelength coverage, we do not divide our sample based on the spectrograph that was used. We have 2379\u00a0168 galaxy spectra in total.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to avoid being confused by bad sky subtractions and calibration errors, we use the \u2018and_mask\u2019 that marks pixels that are bad throughout all the subexposures of a given object. We discard pixels that are marked in \u2018and_mask\u2019 and their closest neighbours (one on each side). We completely remove all objects that have more than 700 bad pixels marked in the \u2018and_mask\u2019 and remain with 2355\u00a0926 spectra. We further discard the pixels in the wavelength range 5565\u20135590\u2009\u00c5 in the observers frame due to residual sky emission that occurs in a large number of the objects.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The SDSS spectroscopic pipeline obtains the redshift of an object by cross-matching its spectrum to template spectra of stars, galaxies and quasars. However, in BOSS, galaxies are often classified as quasars with unrealistic fit parameters and the original redshift estimation is incorrect. Therefore, another fit is done, with no quasar templates, which yields a better fit and redshift estimation, <em>z</em><sub>noqso</sub> (Bolton et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). For every object with <em>z</em><sub>noqso</sub> available, we use it instead of the standard redshift. We shift the spectra to the rest-frame wavelength, and then interpolate the spectra to an identical wavelength grid from 2250 to 10\u00a0100\u2009\u00c5\u00a0with 0.5\u2009\u00c5\u00a0resolution, and normalize the flux using the median flux of the spectrum. Redshift is a very non-linear variable, and working in the observer frame would complicate any classification task significantly. Here, domain knowledge allows us to remove the effect of redshift in pre-processing. It is important to note that, as we show below, objects with erroneous redshifts assigned by the SDSS pipeline are found naturally as outliers by our algorithm. We do not extrapolate, and use NULL values at wavelength where we do not have information. We finally apply a running median filter with a window size of 2.5\u2009\u00c5 (i.e. 5\u00a0pixels) to pixels that are not NULL, which is roughly the resolution of the spectrograph. This is done in order to remove residual cosmic rays and noise. The width of the filter is small enough to have little effect on real spectral lines. Overall, we perform a limited pre-analysis of the data and the steps detailed above only discard 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the data.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438614 id=\"58438614\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 OUTLIER DETECTION ALGORITHM</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The algorithm we discuss is general and can be implemented on images, time series (such as light curves) and photometry, similarly to our current application to spectroscopic data. The input to the algorithm is a matrix in which the rows represent the objects in the sample (galaxy spectra in our case) and the columns represent the features of the data. In our case, the features are simply the flux values at each wavelength, thus we have 2355\u00a0926 objects with 15\u00a0700 features each (i.e. 15\u00a0700 interpolated flux values).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to detect outliers, one can define a distance measure between every two objects in the sample, we achieve this task by using RF. An RF refers to the general technique of random decision forests, an ensemble learning method that is used for regression and classification. RF operates by constructing a set of decision trees during training. Every such tree splits the training data into the known classes by using rules learned from the data features. Each tree in the ensemble is built from a sample drawn with replacement from the objects in the sample and only a randomly selected subset of the features is used as a splitting criterion. Then, the RF averages the predictions of the decision trees, and due to this randomness, the resulting model is general and has low variance (Breiman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>; Breiman\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). Constructing each decision tree with a subset of the objects and a subset of the features makes the RF naturally parallelizable and extremely fit for usage in the framework of distributed file systems (DFS).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the objects in our sample are not labelled and there is no external information input to the algorithm from the user, we perform unsupervised learning with RF, as described in Shi &amp; Horvath (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) though with some key modifications. We construct a synthetic data matrix with the same dimensions as our sample data (2355\u00a0926\u00a0\u00d7\u00a015\u00a0700): each feature (column) in the synthetic data is built by sampling from the marginal distribution of the same feature in the original data. The process of creating the synthetic data is illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> in a simplified example, where each object has only two features, distributed as seen in the left-hand panel. The synthetic data are shown in the right-hand panel, where one can see that the marginal distributions of the original and synthetic data match, while the covariance between the features remains only in the original data.</p>                        <a id=\"58438618\" scrollto-destination=\"58438618\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=srz63r0S17z2N5JFZpEuv0yMFkx0t8uAPm4IVxPcYAJLIolEBxrvakGj0GGVv6TGa00bpX2-yMcRwV4G7NLUvKGIQDtZFNAFmhCkTbNaiOw-AmRrQRFG~x1V~5zqPbgzjCS3ZrrYRTVmHn9ZgaTme9vjqup2aZb6IX7n61XgtSZP7blXPEMNl1HCw7ZF6oJ8S2IfxfR3M3AHNNYIX4~GVzSgESY7Mtp0ugYaLM7n3BUMYta8zkzDvT1mc2Irau~uyzaL8Jk~wBtSnPKI-3bJy2IV0pQFsK8YvAcErk1y-lzY0Sxs2G-zeRzMS2qTRDt4v5PNgk6nhTjUKRPAe6ePuQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustration of the synthetic data construction: we sample points from the marginal distributions of the original data (left-hand panel) and define it as the synthetic data (right-hand panel) for a given feature (that is a single flux measurement). While the marginal distribution of the two samples remain identical, the covariance (i.e. the dependence between the different features) exists only in the original data.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438618/stw3021fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438618\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Y3oT7~H8QQv2Og6lzxlds~pgYt2oNLPAe~mKpBfuM9EWAVhVlmTfQf4QGsjnGPYbuirsww91b3Ood1d~f0xspPAickgRzr7g9hgDaOBKoRVluQYfpwz7~EnVmO9C0B7EnWmFeR4TRWp3A3-iscve9ST1d8b77Jx9ki0CS9aLcfXDY~21H4Uh1UK42AKaxYCpwOtwkraeG9DAOZmVZtQxh1~43zGjJ8FIkhW23tJkDFFJB5~tTk2Qywyg3ESlJ503KKD6TZ6xqlKf0e3Q6-B1pnw1eHEAGiWANY4ntqpIGexiovKFrPMFt5hjW~BTwmXCgHC9Q1grv7pn-x2FNxlpMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438618&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustration of the synthetic data construction: we sample points from the marginal distributions of the original data (left-hand panel) and define it as the synthetic data (right-hand panel) for a given feature (that is a single flux measurement). While the marginal distribution of the two samples remain identical, the covariance (i.e. the dependence between the different features) exists only in the original data.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=srz63r0S17z2N5JFZpEuv0yMFkx0t8uAPm4IVxPcYAJLIolEBxrvakGj0GGVv6TGa00bpX2-yMcRwV4G7NLUvKGIQDtZFNAFmhCkTbNaiOw-AmRrQRFG~x1V~5zqPbgzjCS3ZrrYRTVmHn9ZgaTme9vjqup2aZb6IX7n61XgtSZP7blXPEMNl1HCw7ZF6oJ8S2IfxfR3M3AHNNYIX4~GVzSgESY7Mtp0ugYaLM7n3BUMYta8zkzDvT1mc2Irau~uyzaL8Jk~wBtSnPKI-3bJy2IV0pQFsK8YvAcErk1y-lzY0Sxs2G-zeRzMS2qTRDt4v5PNgk6nhTjUKRPAe6ePuQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustration of the synthetic data construction: we sample points from the marginal distributions of the original data (left-hand panel) and define it as the synthetic data (right-hand panel) for a given feature (that is a single flux measurement). While the marginal distribution of the two samples remain identical, the covariance (i.e. the dependence between the different features) exists only in the original data.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438618/stw3021fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438618\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Y3oT7~H8QQv2Og6lzxlds~pgYt2oNLPAe~mKpBfuM9EWAVhVlmTfQf4QGsjnGPYbuirsww91b3Ood1d~f0xspPAickgRzr7g9hgDaOBKoRVluQYfpwz7~EnVmO9C0B7EnWmFeR4TRWp3A3-iscve9ST1d8b77Jx9ki0CS9aLcfXDY~21H4Uh1UK42AKaxYCpwOtwkraeG9DAOZmVZtQxh1~43zGjJ8FIkhW23tJkDFFJB5~tTk2Qywyg3ESlJ503KKD6TZ6xqlKf0e3Q6-B1pnw1eHEAGiWANY4ntqpIGexiovKFrPMFt5hjW~BTwmXCgHC9Q1grv7pn-x2FNxlpMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438618&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustration of the synthetic data construction: we sample points from the marginal distributions of the original data (left-hand panel) and define it as the synthetic data (right-hand panel) for a given feature (that is a single flux measurement). While the marginal distribution of the two samples remain identical, the covariance (i.e. the dependence between the different features) exists only in the original data.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Once we have the synthetic data, we can translate the problem to the language of supervised learning \u2013 we label the original data as real and the synthetic data as synthetic. The total labelled data which consist of both the real and synthetic samples are the input to the traditional RF classification algorithm. We note that there is no need to divide the sample into training, validation, and test sets as typically done when performing supervised learning, since we do not use the trained forest as a predictor for new, unlabelled measurements. We train the forest to distinguish between real and synthetic, and since the difference between the classes is the lack of covariance in the synthetic data, the forest identifies features which show strong covariance and rates them higher in its features importance scheme. In this framework, spectral lines will show as correlations on short scales, between nearby wavelengths, while continuum slopes manifest themselves as more subtle correlations (typically) between distant wavelength ranges. Noise is largely uncorrelated, except perhaps for the influence of the point spread function that introduces short-range correlations in spectra. We apply the RF training to the illustration data from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and show in the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> the probability of an object to be classified as real by the trained RF. One can see that although the real and synthetic data occupy the same region in parameter space, the RF learns the region of the real objects well.</p>                        <a id=\"58438620\" scrollto-destination=\"58438620\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=H3VDuC-wAP5XRLc5MXWokCr-d4EFLLbvzBN7PIO99UfqrQEM5zi7CdlIpF5YjZeDHeb1txQJjJoQtnCEQWFS6WxLZ6CMulxtpMpw0OCpBNw68e4YMwvcYScUsEEuxD~L6cxfF15U8UVchccDJmzgsk4XhnE7LvahDVfrWiOH614Bh6W9QpbZUvbcu96JMXOuoS1gKHISyTs-GEihPj4qyitWttyG78ncIxDc-fMXgKUl62NlV-tcn~vRufr2G0Sil81KmLPHtygnaW0LjOYdSkk5pOCiQU6rGn1osjD5KwJyYrQtSRPT1402QzN-SxzdYppr2FtCu6rX44HA-6nI6Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Application of the algorithm to the illustration data from Fig.\u00a02. The left-hand panel shows a colour map of the probability of an object to be classified as real by the trained RF. One can see that although the real and synthetic data occupy the same region in feature space, the RF provides good predictions for the location of real objects. The right-hand panel shows the real objects, their colour represents their weirdness score, where dark blue represents high weirdness score and yellow represents a low weirdness score.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438620/stw3021fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438620\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=sNdLL-XD9isD3ktqKjq1ymnRwDzB6qXIzc~u9BETQmRvZ3gTCuVM95M4Q5NSkhTqbLa5on9P0YoPuvsgWXioJIZXIi1TiHUyogCr~xF1UI0OrZD4a5bggFN4Zgv2SSM9NKEz8gFfjTY-LA6D7D3NfWrk5Tyk7oTjhCPHEOQ~Qlg-hSV2mVsIBc4x5pdm6kY3tJ49DB-8jcdKBZ4YPs-TXcB6xhsy7R5ZXNB~VoKLD6WUqduSzYfHTkB2UPiQ3Hmk-ZLvlQolo-iCmdDrWJhJmvFwqqFZOyW~sAGIvnVxiMxB9XoMVIz2ZoFQwkdhbUdn99SCX1~sc2YwsmBGqtFB4Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438620&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Application of the algorithm to the illustration data from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The left-hand panel shows a colour map of the probability of an object to be classified as real by the trained RF. One can see that although the real and synthetic data occupy the same region in feature space, the RF provides good predictions for the location of real objects. The right-hand panel shows the real objects, their colour represents their weirdness score, where dark blue represents high weirdness score and yellow represents a low weirdness score.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=H3VDuC-wAP5XRLc5MXWokCr-d4EFLLbvzBN7PIO99UfqrQEM5zi7CdlIpF5YjZeDHeb1txQJjJoQtnCEQWFS6WxLZ6CMulxtpMpw0OCpBNw68e4YMwvcYScUsEEuxD~L6cxfF15U8UVchccDJmzgsk4XhnE7LvahDVfrWiOH614Bh6W9QpbZUvbcu96JMXOuoS1gKHISyTs-GEihPj4qyitWttyG78ncIxDc-fMXgKUl62NlV-tcn~vRufr2G0Sil81KmLPHtygnaW0LjOYdSkk5pOCiQU6rGn1osjD5KwJyYrQtSRPT1402QzN-SxzdYppr2FtCu6rX44HA-6nI6Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Application of the algorithm to the illustration data from Fig.\u00a02. The left-hand panel shows a colour map of the probability of an object to be classified as real by the trained RF. One can see that although the real and synthetic data occupy the same region in feature space, the RF provides good predictions for the location of real objects. The right-hand panel shows the real objects, their colour represents their weirdness score, where dark blue represents high weirdness score and yellow represents a low weirdness score.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438620/stw3021fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438620\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=sNdLL-XD9isD3ktqKjq1ymnRwDzB6qXIzc~u9BETQmRvZ3gTCuVM95M4Q5NSkhTqbLa5on9P0YoPuvsgWXioJIZXIi1TiHUyogCr~xF1UI0OrZD4a5bggFN4Zgv2SSM9NKEz8gFfjTY-LA6D7D3NfWrk5Tyk7oTjhCPHEOQ~Qlg-hSV2mVsIBc4x5pdm6kY3tJ49DB-8jcdKBZ4YPs-TXcB6xhsy7R5ZXNB~VoKLD6WUqduSzYfHTkB2UPiQ3Hmk-ZLvlQolo-iCmdDrWJhJmvFwqqFZOyW~sAGIvnVxiMxB9XoMVIz2ZoFQwkdhbUdn99SCX1~sc2YwsmBGqtFB4Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438620&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Application of the algorithm to the illustration data from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The left-hand panel shows a colour map of the probability of an object to be classified as real by the trained RF. One can see that although the real and synthetic data occupy the same region in feature space, the RF provides good predictions for the location of real objects. The right-hand panel shows the real objects, their colour represents their weirdness score, where dark blue represents high weirdness score and yellow represents a low weirdness score.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Having the trained forest, we take only the real objects and propagate them through the decision trees in the forest. Every object, in every tree, ends up in a terminal node (leaf) with a predicted class, either real or synthetic. In order to define a measure of similarity between objects, we count how often every pair of objects were classified as real in the same leaf of a given tree. This number, <em>N</em><sub>leaf</sub>, can range from 0 to the number of trees in our forest. <em>N</em><sub>leaf</sub> is a measure of the similarity between these two objects since objects that have a similar path inside the decision tree have similar features, and as a consequence are represented by the same model. We normalize <em>N</em><sub>leaf</sub> by dividing it by the number of trees in the forest which classify both objects as real, <em>N</em><sub>trees</sub>, giving us a similarity measure for every pair of objects. We define the distance between objects <em>i</em> and <em>j</em> as <em>D<sub>ij</sub></em>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>N</em><sub>leaf</sub>/<em>N</em><sub>trees</sub>. <em>D<sub>ij</sub></em> can range from 0 (objects that ended up in the same leaf in all the trees), which is the distance of an object to itself, to 1 for objects that never ended up in the same leaf.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that the standard way to measure distances between objects with RF is counting the number of tress in which the objects ended up in the same leaf, regardless of the leaf prediction (e.g. Shi &amp; Horvath\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), in this case, <em>N</em><sub>trees</sub> is constant and equals to the number of trees in the forest. However, we find that the quality of the outliers improves when taking into account only leaves that predict both of the objects to be real. This may be due to the fact that a model (the path in a decision tree) that describes a synthetic object does not describe well a real object and vice versa. The galaxies in our sample are classified as synthetic by a decision tree with a probability of up to 25\u00a0per\u00a0cent. This probability depends on the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the galaxies, such that the probability to be classified as synthetic increases with decreasing SNR. We note however that each decision tree has access to a limited number of features and therefore a galaxy with high SNR can be classified as synthetic in some subset of the trees, thus adding noise to the distance measure. We further refer the reader to the work by Shi &amp; Horvath (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), where they discuss different methods of synthetic data construction, distance assignment, and discuss the difference and similarity to the Euclidean distance.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using this distance measure, we can cluster the objects but our purpose is to find outliers. The distance between all the pairs of objects is a matrix with dimensions 2355\u00a0926\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02355\u00a0926, more than 20TB in double precision. Since we are interested in outlying objects, which have a large distance from most of the other objects in the data set, it is enough to average the distances of a given object to all the others, resulting in a 2355\u00a0926-sized vector that represents the \u2018weirdness\u2019 score of each object. This vector is of a reasonable size and we can sort it and extract the objects with the highest weirdness score from the entire population \u2013 the outliers. The sorted vector of averaged distances essentially orders the galaxies from the most mundane, with a weirdness score of 0, to the most unusual, with a score of 1. Therefore, the threshold for the outlying objects is user defined. We also note that due to the randomness of the RF in its feature and object selection, the decision trees vary from one run to the next, and the weirdness score that we obtain is not unique. However, we find that when using a sufficient number of decision trees (see details in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>), an object with a high weirdness score in one run will have a high weirdness score in different runs as well.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure the weirdness score for the illustration data shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and show it in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, where dark blue represents objects with high weirdness score and yellow represents objects with a low weirdness score. One can see that objects that are located in the tail of the distribution and noisy points tend to have higher weirdness scores. We show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> a histogram of the weirdness score for all the galaxies in our sample. One can see that the distribution is smooth and decreases monotonically with the weirdness score. The presence of peaks in the histogram would have implied the existence of clusters of objects, composed of galaxies that have a short distance to the cluster members, but a long distance to galaxies in different clusters. The smoothness of the distribution that we measure may imply that the classifier is sensitive even to small differences between seemingly similar galaxies. This is essentially overfitting, which is typically bad for supervised algorithms that are expected to generalize well to new measurements, but serves our purpose to find outliers. Alternatively, a smooth distribution in the averaged distance can happen if the galaxy spectra form a continuous sequence in spectral shape (e.g. Ascasibar &amp; S\u00e1nchez Almeida\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we analyse the 400 weirdest objects, which lie to the right of the dashed blue line.</p>                        <a id=\"58438625\" scrollto-destination=\"58438625\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=1Sc~WEXzMo4zHZzd6I8OsPTg5QkaM3xW7GFB1FqPrdBrp3qH~ne4S1VLC91sNY60r7~6LsM4CKMJ19RRep9uh2W1C8TZlIjFaqgCFUcoivTtHOAQzSxNKvk1MfWjpu2RaaO-vmw-I9jV2ZaI47fGxrY6k6cMV6p7OYb~BOj7emNOAupLmg77dbRLNj6Wte6gEnsGcnIPodRXx8ndBCksbXD1iPmFDSjY7JwaQpX5doJ6FhHSB-BxI-27wkry1SqEf~u2MJZ4UNrZDOoFLFnmmpOUZf4HH3dqGLYX3UDPwvSRdvzca9kttl4irvQkZrdZSJoMYChAA5bm5qLBcx21xA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of the weirdness score for every object in our sample. One can see that the distribution is smooth and decreases as one approaches large values. We study in this paper the 400 objects that lie to the right of the dashed blue line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438625/stw3021fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438625\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=G~YEYhdkWWd3IfyAl~K2G2~IJI6o~3pa2Cvj3zHFsIlWHCdyijGYaGN5OrvXG5~lSr7AiJjAkaOaZ1FNWHRAfKFvrTdBVLW2dSzN8oxGB30sfoHR4y6ww~tKY4UMNmVRKoEd3XBiXi2DsBFG7qXVMyuAwhuLigdmnz5Jpo6R28mB-zm~i778vCuN0mGVneb9lV0yGAwiNAIS913IyBfOPz5sKm9d3N9EcxKNUXOgcz-PHkDby4f4YBeNuecGd0OZR~qJOWiKKyFWisAcjK9SjRlDPVJLNte9jWARMX9XOA~fWVhntBWu7NmVF9yq4YFv-JTSUHv7IdyTVbwaa3LdkA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438625&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of the weirdness score for every object in our sample. One can see that the distribution is smooth and decreases as one approaches large values. We study in this paper the 400 objects that lie to the right of the dashed blue line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=1Sc~WEXzMo4zHZzd6I8OsPTg5QkaM3xW7GFB1FqPrdBrp3qH~ne4S1VLC91sNY60r7~6LsM4CKMJ19RRep9uh2W1C8TZlIjFaqgCFUcoivTtHOAQzSxNKvk1MfWjpu2RaaO-vmw-I9jV2ZaI47fGxrY6k6cMV6p7OYb~BOj7emNOAupLmg77dbRLNj6Wte6gEnsGcnIPodRXx8ndBCksbXD1iPmFDSjY7JwaQpX5doJ6FhHSB-BxI-27wkry1SqEf~u2MJZ4UNrZDOoFLFnmmpOUZf4HH3dqGLYX3UDPwvSRdvzca9kttl4irvQkZrdZSJoMYChAA5bm5qLBcx21xA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of the weirdness score for every object in our sample. One can see that the distribution is smooth and decreases as one approaches large values. We study in this paper the 400 objects that lie to the right of the dashed blue line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438625/stw3021fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438625\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=G~YEYhdkWWd3IfyAl~K2G2~IJI6o~3pa2Cvj3zHFsIlWHCdyijGYaGN5OrvXG5~lSr7AiJjAkaOaZ1FNWHRAfKFvrTdBVLW2dSzN8oxGB30sfoHR4y6ww~tKY4UMNmVRKoEd3XBiXi2DsBFG7qXVMyuAwhuLigdmnz5Jpo6R28mB-zm~i778vCuN0mGVneb9lV0yGAwiNAIS913IyBfOPz5sKm9d3N9EcxKNUXOgcz-PHkDby4f4YBeNuecGd0OZR~qJOWiKKyFWisAcjK9SjRlDPVJLNte9jWARMX9XOA~fWVhntBWu7NmVF9yq4YFv-JTSUHv7IdyTVbwaa3LdkA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438625&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of the weirdness score for every object in our sample. One can see that the distribution is smooth and decreases as one approaches large values. We study in this paper the 400 objects that lie to the right of the dashed blue line.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438626 id=\"58438626\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Implementation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As noted above, RF is a naturally parallelizable algorithm due to the randomness of its object and feature selection. The size (2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02355\u00a0926 objects) and complexity (15\u00a0700 features) of our data prevent us from applying this algorithm with the entire data loaded to memory and the analysis to be done with a single process. Instead, we break the data into eight bins of SNR of equal size, each bin contains roughly 300\u00a0000 galaxy spectra. We define the SNR of a spectrum as the median SNR per pixel, as given by the SDSS pipeline.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to shorter running time, we find that dividing the spectra into the SNR bins improves the quality of the outliers we find. We show the distribution of galaxy SNR in the SDSS in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, where one can see a smoothly declining distribution, except for a prominent peak at SNR\u00a0\u223c\u00a02.5 (with roughly 700\u00a0000 galaxies). Like other machine-learning classifiers, RF builds a model that is mostly sensitive to the common object in the sample, while objects that are rare are not well described. Therefore, when training without SNR bins, the decision trees are optimized to distinguish between real and synthetic data for a galaxy with SNR\u2009\u223c\u20092.5, but not for galaxies with higher SNR. In practice, the decision trees rank wavelengths with prominent emission lines such as H\u03b1 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> high in the feature importance ranking, while ignoring the weaker emission lines such as H\u03b2, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {I}]}$|\u2060</span>, and ignoring absorption lines, since the information of a galaxy with SNR\u00a0\u223c\u20092.5 is mostly contained in these strong emission lines. We therefore divide the sample into SNR bins and indeed find that the feature importance of weak emission lines and absorption lines increases for bins of higher SNR, while prominent emission lines are ranked high in all of the bins.</p>                        <a id=\"58438629\" scrollto-destination=\"58438629\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=YQOWF0zx7WJl907sQehsjE45tD-eD-xxx3ZLMEO7VP0TXnypjqLIw2ywZH09bWGcjE09hwbRS2mbsM9wAmi5XywGQP1DvFLQoL8MfPBfa-A91LjBxVKvCdIRl9qLaR80m84N3PcsntSso13Lfr5j5263xjh4QeEQcWvm49eDldmfsBTWs-bBKZE8W6AJA0Xd6iyagKGlxIvFXPi7yPmkqeShWqjHidX1JYTc9YRQwWBKko6jMeE16rKbkgNON1Be0TbTMsdC8hhhN0vAEn8e4Ci3AfvGjPM3SEF5bcvqVkxkhpR18v1kepgS~LIGYqF116ERodvQRuc98xdLOn-ZaQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of the SNR of the galaxies in our sample. We define the SNR as the median SNR per pixel, as given by the SDSS pipeline. One can see that apart from a prominent peak in the distribution at SNR\u00a0\u223c\u20092.5, the number of galaxies decreases smoothly for increasing SNR.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438629/stw3021fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438629\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Gf9prVluKiWNKluzIRzjfCiawfyuPfys14FFiCLLt6o9MEa6LzkdJT6Si46KDpVHY2QHnmFC16t8hc0iN3yFmMGQ-8t7pZTrthva~I0TFxw3U1mE6TE-PrGDSqlrQ4AFbkzRkKl4idtyoG4VzR5cAWkia~yMrVAJ-RexlpsiYX~Gmw04Q0t9FdaPWrYweZC8yi0nQz1gWWF5NzBAeEWyS5MQxr85VKBwKLq4UuWTdi5qfi3G~Oa0p3LiMA1qGQo0sPBSvRSorwBMTCVtZzV4xQ2I1WqxKuKRpndwCBGVEpSnGOKqUCK~Dq7vtB3Kic6jAbKjZjibB5uRteXKM65ngQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438629&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of the SNR of the galaxies in our sample. We define the SNR as the median SNR per pixel, as given by the SDSS pipeline. One can see that apart from a prominent peak in the distribution at SNR\u00a0\u223c\u20092.5, the number of galaxies decreases smoothly for increasing SNR.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=YQOWF0zx7WJl907sQehsjE45tD-eD-xxx3ZLMEO7VP0TXnypjqLIw2ywZH09bWGcjE09hwbRS2mbsM9wAmi5XywGQP1DvFLQoL8MfPBfa-A91LjBxVKvCdIRl9qLaR80m84N3PcsntSso13Lfr5j5263xjh4QeEQcWvm49eDldmfsBTWs-bBKZE8W6AJA0Xd6iyagKGlxIvFXPi7yPmkqeShWqjHidX1JYTc9YRQwWBKko6jMeE16rKbkgNON1Be0TbTMsdC8hhhN0vAEn8e4Ci3AfvGjPM3SEF5bcvqVkxkhpR18v1kepgS~LIGYqF116ERodvQRuc98xdLOn-ZaQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of the SNR of the galaxies in our sample. We define the SNR as the median SNR per pixel, as given by the SDSS pipeline. One can see that apart from a prominent peak in the distribution at SNR\u00a0\u223c\u20092.5, the number of galaxies decreases smoothly for increasing SNR.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438629/stw3021fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438629\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Gf9prVluKiWNKluzIRzjfCiawfyuPfys14FFiCLLt6o9MEa6LzkdJT6Si46KDpVHY2QHnmFC16t8hc0iN3yFmMGQ-8t7pZTrthva~I0TFxw3U1mE6TE-PrGDSqlrQ4AFbkzRkKl4idtyoG4VzR5cAWkia~yMrVAJ-RexlpsiYX~Gmw04Q0t9FdaPWrYweZC8yi0nQz1gWWF5NzBAeEWyS5MQxr85VKBwKLq4UuWTdi5qfi3G~Oa0p3LiMA1qGQo0sPBSvRSorwBMTCVtZzV4xQ2I1WqxKuKRpndwCBGVEpSnGOKqUCK~Dq7vtB3Kic6jAbKjZjibB5uRteXKM65ngQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438629&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of the SNR of the galaxies in our sample. We define the SNR as the median SNR per pixel, as given by the SDSS pipeline. One can see that apart from a prominent peak in the distribution at SNR\u00a0\u223c\u20092.5, the number of galaxies decreases smoothly for increasing SNR.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Within a given SNR bin, we build 50 redundant chunks that contain 10\u00a0000 objects, and while the galaxy spectra within a given chunk are unique, a specific galaxy spectrum can be included in several different chunks. We construct 200 decision trees for each of these chunks, while using only a subset of the features in the construction of a single tree (a square root of the number of features is used for a given decision tree, which is a typical choice). Therefore, for a given SNR bin, we build 10\u00a0000 decision trees while using 125 features for each tree. We test different numbers of objects per chunk and find that for 5000\u201320\u00a0000 galaxies in a chunk, the weirdness score distribution is the same, resulting in the same quality of outliers. However, when using 1000\u20133000 galaxies per chunk the result is degraded (e.g. supernovae and stars do not always have a high weirdness score, and standard galaxies sometimes have a high weirdness score), and the distribution in weirdness score appears flatter. We also note that increasing the number of decision trees for a fixed number of observations generally results in a better and more general classifier but increases the training time substantially. For our data set, we find that the distribution in weirdness score stabilizes and barely changes once we reach 200 trees per 10\u00a0000 objects. This process is identical to the RF training procedure we presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> and the construction of decision trees per chunk is executed in parallel on multiple computer nodes. We use the decision tree classifier and RF classifier implementation in scikit-learn<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> (Pedregosa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Once we have the decision trees from the parallel processes, we merge them into a forest. The phase of propagating an object through the trees and comparing its leaf to that of the other objects is done in parallel as well. The parallelization in this case is object based \u2013 we pair the reference object with all the other objects and compute the distance between the reference object to the entire sample and then we average it. These details were tailored to the data at hand, and to our available computational resources. We stress that they affect execution time but not our scientific results. In total the process takes 12\u00a0h on 128 CPUs to obtain the weirdness score. The bulk of our computations was performed on the resources of the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a></p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438632 id=\"58438632\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Dimensionality reduction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Dimensionality reduction and feature selection methods are often proposed when dealing with large-size and complex data. The goal of dimensionality reduction techniques is to extract the strongest, most prominent features in the data and use them for classification or regression problems. These methods assume that the data can be well represented in a lower dimensional space, thus allowing for faster and (sometimes) better statistical inference. A common method is principal component analysis (PCA) that performs a linear decomposition of the data and provides eigenvectors and their strength coefficients for every object in the data set (e.g. Vanden Berk et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Zhang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Re Fiorentin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Rogers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Bailey\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). When modelling a spectrum, the linearity of PCA may be a disadvantage due to the non-linearity of spectral lines. Thus, it is not clear that applying PCA prior to the forest construction is beneficial for our algorithm.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Nevertheless, we apply PCA decomposition on the 10\u00a0000-sized chunks and use the coefficients provided by the decomposition as the features for the forest construction and outlier detection. We test different number of input coefficients: using 10\u00a0000, 5000, 2000, 1000, 500 and 100. In all the cases, the result suffers. Outlying objects tend to have a few coefficients with large (positive and negative) values, compared to the values for the same coefficients of standard objects. These large coefficients are not modelled well by the forest and tend to fall in the same leaf of a given decision tree, thus appearing similar to each other. Standard spectra that are intrinsically alike also tend to fall in the same leaf and appear similar. These two groups (intrinsically similar objects and outlying objects) show the same summed distances and therefore cannot be separated with a distance criterion. So while PCA might be advantageous for a classification problem with RF, by mitigating overfitting, it impairs our weirdness measure.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are dimensionality reduction algorithms that are not linear. Richards et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) apply diffusion maps to galaxy spectra for data parametrization and dimensionality reduction prior to using the spectra in a regression problem. Vanderplas &amp; Connolly (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and Daniel et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) use locally linear embedding (LLE) as a non-linear dimensionality reduction technique for classification of the SDSS spectra. Although these methods show great promise in the dimensionality reduction field, we chose not to use them since RF, contrary to many ML algorithms, deals with large number of features well, and applying these methods is expensive both in terms of running time and available memory. Furthermore, it is not trivial to apply these methods on millions of objects in the DFS framework and on data streams. More importantly, as noted above, the better they work, the more they are likely to harm our algorithm for outlier detection.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438636 id=\"58438636\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Comparison with other outlier detection algorithms</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">There are several outlier detection algorithms that are based on unsupervised learning which are widely used in various fields. These algorithms can be divided into two types. The first type is distance-based anomaly detection, in which a distance is computed between every pair of objects in the sample and outliers are defined as objects that are distant from most of the objects in the sample. This includes Euclidian-based distance assignment, PCA-decomposition-based distance assignment, and unsupervised RF distance assignment. The running time of these algorithms scales as <em>O</em>(<em>N</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>N</em> is the number of objects in the sample, since a pairwise distance must be computed. The second type of algorithms focus on isolating outliers rather than modelling the entire data and defining outliers as objects that deviate from this model. The most popular such algorithm is Isolation Forest (iForest; Liu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Such algorithms are typically linear in time. We refer the reader to Liu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and Goix (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) for comparison between different algorithms for different data sets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compare the quality of the outliers we find with the following algorithms: One-Class SVM (Sch\u00f6lkopf et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), iForest (Liu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), standard unsupervised RF (Shi &amp; Horvath\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and our method introduced here. While our method is distance based, it is not as fast as iForest for example, but it is naturally parallelizable, reducing wall-time. We gauge the quality of the outliers we find with the various methods qualitatively, using domain knowledge. For example, we expect supernovae and stars to have high weirdness scores, and galaxies that are only brighter but otherwise normal to have low scores. We also compare the number of false positives found by these algorithms, that is, the number of standard-looking objects that are marked as outliers by the algorithms.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Visually inspecting the 400 weirdest galaxies found by each of these algorithms, we find that our method significantly outperforms the others, finding essentially only interesting galaxies, as thoroughly discussed below. The standard unsupervised RF algorithm tends to pick a larger number of false positives. For One-Class SVM and iForest, the galaxies that are found as outliers include mostly galaxies with residual cosmic rays, galaxies with extremely strong emission lines, stars, and a few false positives. Generally, we find that these algorithms detect objects that show outlying properties in specific features (i.e. wavelengths) but are not sensitive to outlying relation between features such as extremely reddened galaxies, outlying line ratios, and unusual emission lines. Although the former are indeed outliers in a statistical sense, the covariance-based outliers are more interesting and offer the opportunity to discover subtle changes that represent an outlying physical behaviour.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438640 id=\"58438640\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 OUTLYING GALAXIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We systematically inspect the 400 weirdest galaxies that we find. We caution the reader that their relative numbers are not very meaningful, since our choice to study 400 is arbitrary, and limited by the time necessary to inspect all the aspects of each galaxy, as we do below. This includes visual inspection of the SDSS spectrum and imaging, line measurements where applicable, a literature search (since this sample was so extensively studied) and other more specific measurements for specific cases. There are undoubtedly many more interesting sources with a marginally lower weirdness score. We encourage our readers to explore further. A table with a weirdness score for all the 2M galaxies is available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.wise-obs.tau.ac.il/~dovip/weird-galaxies/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.wise-obs.tau.ac.il/\u223cdovip/weird-galaxies/</a>, and an <span class=\"small-caps\">ipython</span> notebook with the algorithm is available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/dalya/WeirdestGalaxies\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/dalya/WeirdestGalaxies</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Out of 400, we call 10 objects \u2018bad spectra\u2019 and they consist of objects with calibration problems and sky contamination, we find 47 stars classified as galaxies by the SDSS pipeline. 27 objects we call \u2018blends\u2019, which includes galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses, chance alignment of two objects and multiple emission line systems. We find 186 galaxies with unusual emission-line ratios. 13 galaxies sport an unusually broad [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission, in fact, it is so broad in some cases that the SDSS pipeline mistakes it for a broad H\u03b1 emission line at a wrong redshift. We also find 33 galaxies with extreme Balmer absorption up to H\u03b4 and beyond, and 38 objects with an excess of NaID absorption. 18 outliers are galaxies that host supernovae, and 9 outliers show unusual emission lines (e.g. coronal lines, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|\u2060</span>). We find 41 galaxies with unusual velocity structures \u2013 out of these, 11 galaxies show an additional structure around the H\u03b1\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> complex and 13 galaxies show double-peaked emission lines. We show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> a pie chart that summarizes all the outlying objects and their classification. Out of the 400 outliers, only 74 outliers were previously reported by other studies \u2013 in all of these cases, the authors have constructed a specific algorithm that is tailored exactly to find the kind of objects they are looking for. We list all the outlying galaxies in Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a> with classification and references to previous studies when relevant. Throughout this section, we note specific galaxies with their SDSS name (e.g. SDSS J131027.46+182617.4) and their SDSS PLATE-MJD-FIBER.</p>                        <a id=\"58438643\" scrollto-destination=\"58438643\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=vgmz8VIkcOmZFbjU-96-o~9n9D96GRk583f0Nx9XySej-7dz~7nrcXyw3LuiaZ10EsqhewG-OKcoUU2fydGSd7zuogf22uf2v9xlEQq6Hz~W-jo65fpKenUhiEWF4JuXfX~OIwnf2K6S-6hNGhq0GpoX42FEQBrFxnr0eIlMgnqrjD2ha4g5eSpaV2tIViJIT9ipI-Ysw8MRmsAHb5xN891hfMsmD2XuGXhfPfF8jN9f4ZZLay0M~wxQCR4jK04nayMCXCQjNZCqcTdC11X1gdykLLQs4OHCv2ONVvG5nlEIKFLYON3jGa2h8QBaYH~47~FgZzznLiUb8712hd5ibQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distributions of the classes of outlying objects we find. It is interesting that only a small fraction (2.5\u00a0per\u00a0cent) are due to instrumental problems.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=vgmz8VIkcOmZFbjU-96-o~9n9D96GRk583f0Nx9XySej-7dz~7nrcXyw3LuiaZ10EsqhewG-OKcoUU2fydGSd7zuogf22uf2v9xlEQq6Hz~W-jo65fpKenUhiEWF4JuXfX~OIwnf2K6S-6hNGhq0GpoX42FEQBrFxnr0eIlMgnqrjD2ha4g5eSpaV2tIViJIT9ipI-Ysw8MRmsAHb5xN891hfMsmD2XuGXhfPfF8jN9f4ZZLay0M~wxQCR4jK04nayMCXCQjNZCqcTdC11X1gdykLLQs4OHCv2ONVvG5nlEIKFLYON3jGa2h8QBaYH~47~FgZzznLiUb8712hd5ibQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distributions of the classes of outlying objects we find. It is interesting that only a small fraction (2.5\u00a0per\u00a0cent) are due to instrumental problems.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438643/stw3021fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438643\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=G7nCvR4X7VCat-ShLJE8LnP9ykbu8-v3wKnqTZj1tSaddDbQXCb5~BnpiOkxzrOULW72OSZgxjzAKG~YkTPZvqPy0KW5b1CqTjaUn9NGhIClqb3Y8iBR-H~wk-X0eiPZ4DprvLxq9TBCwiL79HM6EcPv~~HUWnTwQams7zMVc1ndPfNHIFOVRrtZuSxiT1bE1G-gccqXfLGoRdL7VzbmMjXSNmiOxvIuLEUHXuWTnAt4BzYn7tMEPbwvNV7KP0MUVDbQgebhmFlUxhL6EBsc2ty7q2Ke~3f0DSr4MkCaN9vMUksareC2zvjL15KfnYmjCWqJoBDvdluPrjBOqhrA6w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438643&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distributions of the classes of outlying objects we find. Clearly, we find a wide variety of phenomena. It is interesting that only a small fraction (2.5\u00a0per\u00a0cent) are due to instrumental problems.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438644 id=\"58438644\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Unusual velocity structure</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 42 galaxies with an unusual velocity structure in their emission lines. Out of these, 11 galaxies show an additional structure around the H\u03b1\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> complex, 13 galaxies have double-peaked emission lines, and 3 show two broad components in the H\u03b1 and H\u03b2. We also find 13 galaxies with unusually broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission, and the remaining 5 galaxies show a number of interesting velocity components in their emission lines. We list these five objects in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> one of the four galaxies that shows the most complex velocity structure as an example. SDSS J135338.10+313325.1 (2117-54115-230) has a number of velocity components in its Balmer and forbidden lines. We mark the rest-frame wavelengths of the emission lines based on the redshift estimation of the SDSS. One can see that this galaxy has two <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission peaks and another blueshifted component, probably due to an outflow. In the Balmer emission lines, one can see a broad component that is redshifted compared to the central rest-frame wavelength (more prominent in the H\u03b1 emission). The galaxy seems disturbed in the SDSS imaging, and this velocity structure could arise from asymmetries near the centre of the galaxy that is picked up by the spectroscopic fibre. We also note SDSS J113818.38+060620.1 (4767-55946-889), which has an ultra-luminous, galaxy-wide narrow line region and is studied by Schirmer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) as it is a \u2018green bean\u2019. Schirmer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) construct a sample of 29 such galaxies from SDSS DR8, and claim them to be among the rarest objects in the Universe.</p>                        <a id=\"58438647\" scrollto-destination=\"58438647\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=NSS3DQXH0nt5F3INf-b23WGH~mCXRA3ClhCkJOSIZrwEKWpA7yOUioNQLtr4uA6Re9PNq0BfNrcw4zxlTXcEeWRU3eCxWRKmQnFz~lyNK9tBzTzoW0SoN-MBQ0V9xUuAqt-80-c8wCNxlUF1Zvq1dnMYekd5mpbmaEgsWMIoZbhTuuPza9CYw9smtDwScPd-BMpJ2BOT-5PF29qKfesjWU1PtGa9R53PzaSItzrh4oOTrjIHWRLhr9kHkB3u3aZC0nb7dAdzRF29siaebSLWfmFwV1hzIN8Gt~Ni4c6BFpNzMeCnKXiMKlj7Z3H8AsBJZYRkfyK1rkisJ7F~rziUPA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J135338.10+313325.1 (2117-54115-230) has a number of velocity components in its Balmer and forbidden lines. There are two $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$ emission peaks and another blueshifted component, probably due to an outflow (left-hand panel). In the Balmer emission lines, one can see a broad component that is redshifted (see the right-hand panel). The vertical dashed lines mark the rest-frame central wavelength of emission lines, based on the redshift estimation of the SDSS pipeline.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438647/stw3021fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438647\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=iG5g1A1WQDKfxSq-pC25NK3yap5ijOmSjlWpbsab20GWEc4QZAAVG4Wwh7F6d2aXtE5qs8uM5wkx9OqnuCtstgWIK7BLe1-MCVAWJJLKgHKQfQgE4dqri5IGPFlJJEB6xxCvHkDehJvEBItFBnl6guey3ZyONNVuSHrCUO0U642u6Fr75SQR0c~cXqMrrA~-HUQC2AGZiqDwKmBqbxKRyNy38zKZXi49tMhhM24tvmgIxM3946y~kFvhJBMknrWiMSEA-~yKz-SlkW75v6w10he7pNyktzNpaYDuXq5l2sdp936Ydd6-H~dcMFZ1-jST2-UsXdzVXmG~xnZjbeXuAA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438647&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J135338.10+313325.1 (2117-54115-230) has a number of velocity components in its Balmer and forbidden lines. There are two <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission peaks and another blueshifted component, probably due to an outflow (left-hand panel). In the Balmer emission lines, one can see a broad component that is redshifted (see the right-hand panel). The vertical dashed lines mark the rest-frame central wavelength of emission lines, based on the redshift estimation of the SDSS pipeline.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=NSS3DQXH0nt5F3INf-b23WGH~mCXRA3ClhCkJOSIZrwEKWpA7yOUioNQLtr4uA6Re9PNq0BfNrcw4zxlTXcEeWRU3eCxWRKmQnFz~lyNK9tBzTzoW0SoN-MBQ0V9xUuAqt-80-c8wCNxlUF1Zvq1dnMYekd5mpbmaEgsWMIoZbhTuuPza9CYw9smtDwScPd-BMpJ2BOT-5PF29qKfesjWU1PtGa9R53PzaSItzrh4oOTrjIHWRLhr9kHkB3u3aZC0nb7dAdzRF29siaebSLWfmFwV1hzIN8Gt~Ni4c6BFpNzMeCnKXiMKlj7Z3H8AsBJZYRkfyK1rkisJ7F~rziUPA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J135338.10+313325.1 (2117-54115-230) has a number of velocity components in its Balmer and forbidden lines. There are two $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$ emission peaks and another blueshifted component, probably due to an outflow (left-hand panel). In the Balmer emission lines, one can see a broad component that is redshifted (see the right-hand panel). The vertical dashed lines mark the rest-frame central wavelength of emission lines, based on the redshift estimation of the SDSS pipeline.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438647/stw3021fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438647\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=iG5g1A1WQDKfxSq-pC25NK3yap5ijOmSjlWpbsab20GWEc4QZAAVG4Wwh7F6d2aXtE5qs8uM5wkx9OqnuCtstgWIK7BLe1-MCVAWJJLKgHKQfQgE4dqri5IGPFlJJEB6xxCvHkDehJvEBItFBnl6guey3ZyONNVuSHrCUO0U642u6Fr75SQR0c~cXqMrrA~-HUQC2AGZiqDwKmBqbxKRyNy38zKZXi49tMhhM24tvmgIxM3946y~kFvhJBMknrWiMSEA-~yKz-SlkW75v6w10he7pNyktzNpaYDuXq5l2sdp936Ydd6-H~dcMFZ1-jST2-UsXdzVXmG~xnZjbeXuAA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438647&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J135338.10+313325.1 (2117-54115-230) has a number of velocity components in its Balmer and forbidden lines. There are two <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission peaks and another blueshifted component, probably due to an outflow (left-hand panel). In the Balmer emission lines, one can see a broad component that is redshifted (see the right-hand panel). The vertical dashed lines mark the rest-frame central wavelength of emission lines, based on the redshift estimation of the SDSS pipeline.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438648 id=\"58438648\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-1>4.1.1 Additional structure near H\u03b1</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 11 objects with an additional structure near the H\u03b1\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> complex. The stellar continuum contribution in these galaxies is stronger than nebular emission, mostly near H\u03b2, thus similar features are not easily detected in H\u03b2 emission. In order to isolate the emission of the gas from the stellar component, we subtract the best-fitting population synthesis model for each of the galaxies. We use <span class=\"small-caps\">ppxf</span> (Cappellari\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), which is a public code that extracts the stellar kinematics and stellar population from absorption-line spectra of galaxies (Cappellari &amp; Emsellem\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). The code uses the MILES library, which contains single stellar population synthesis models from Vazdekis et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). In several galaxies, we obtain unrealistic stellar population fits due to the broad H\u03b1 emission. We therefore ignore pixels that are dominated by the broad emission features prior to the fitting, and obtain good fits.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The emission spectra of these galaxies show a wide range of properties. For some of the galaxies, we detect a similar emission structure around H\u03b2, suggesting that the broad features are due to Balmer emission, and in some of these, the broad emission is not centred around the central wavelength of the narrow emission, suggesting an outflow or a complex geometry (e.g. SDSS J154327.02+075442.1, 1724-53859-116, which shows an outflow in the Balmer emission lines). We find that several galaxies show diagonally shaped continua (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.5.2</a>), which suggests that the broad H\u03b2 emission is absorbed by dust reddening and is not detected due to our limited SNR. Furthermore, we find that while for five of the galaxies the additional structure can be attributed to a broad H\u03b1 emission, or to two H\u03b1 velocity components which are blended, the remaining six show asymmetric structures that cannot be described by a broad Gaussian. We list these objects in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present two examples of such objects in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. SDSS J013402.54\u2212094627.0 (0663-52145-0306; top panels) shows an asymmetric profile, which cannot be well represented by a single or double Gaussian and is not centred around the H\u03b1 emission line. After subtracting the best stellar population synthesis model from the spectrum, we detect two broad emission components around H\u03b2, which suggests that the broad feature around H\u03b1 is due to Balmer emission (rather than <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission or a mix of the two). However, using two broad emission components for H\u03b1 (and all the narrow emission lines) we are not able to reproduce the shape of the emission we observe. We find that adding an additional broad component in absorption can reproduce the profile we observe. Broad Balmer absorption is typically seen in type II supernova ejecta (see for example Faran et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) or extremely dense outflows in high-redshift quasars (see Williams et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a> and references therein). An alternative interpretation for this profile is a circular, relativistic, Keplerian disc that is observed in a small fraction of AGN (Eracleous &amp; Halpern\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). SDSS J124144.54+350345.9 (2022-53827-0286; bottom panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>) has a more symmetric structure, only slightly shifted from the H\u03b1 wavelength. We detect the same structure in H\u03b2 after subtracting the stellar population contribution. In both of these cases, we do not detect continuum emission from an accretion disc.</p>                        <a id=\"58438652\" scrollto-destination=\"58438652\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=CYLWp-W1XiNAz8bqv7eytiFtZCOLIliHQujnzXNr8Tji13kD8WlQfWgzqgUCza-Itt3djcWTY7HUnvXgT5Hf6GlBjfcoJrkyliZTo7LEXu~VGj8ATxekeoIVFEXl7YHqs~HSCaHx~J~eIEQot6LqnX~30wPUdvb9mYSJczpCSpRqH1PHFEcftS2YopBOZjsUMsV-rYqwEQ~tSF19Zpuje8-pFllT5PAkWb5wfQtOH5TiUKd6QGhJK6mFKA7QW8-kbTeQ1yR-8VMalcS31zfggJuL4DQXaUUVAEvEyfeaLcepUYl9MEN4XvMvrKFReNImt5GEZyS~VpoDOI2JMrtTzg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Two examples of galaxies with an additional structure near the H\u2013[N\u2009ii] complex. SDSS J124144.54+350345.9 (2022-53827-286; bottom panels) has a more symmetric structure, with a centroid that is slightly shifted from the H\u03b1 wavelength. In both of the cases, we find similar structure in H\u03b2 after we subtract the best stellar population synthesis model, though we do not detect continuum emission from an accretion disc.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438652/stw3021fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438652\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=G0AHqkE5t2YSGPJQGcYhWLpgwi7XWhIwnRkHMPWKfAP0cSUlfeL0U~br4G8mtEUFaWih6EX3yWUBzMGpKoV4rLldliuiaZFi1EtxQvz~lkKS3B-nl6YZj84GUCn-HAxrk2k1RFVVMX8eq7UsUQe36ULYAe51yvMRtOr~B-cz-f3b5EH5FirOK9AySmBW8wG~8nfwVCbAC68snlD2hir2TIzxBd1qRtnh2aQymVZz92PSdVX1FRPzjMPs67qOBv90w2zDrSzhu6tuet7j-KS2i3oEyd3Xn7AjLsGkpPd54Ej3He4HlBPqO34Nsa1t4txf0MEXjX-Zp2km11VvQJvdyA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438652&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two examples of galaxies with an additional structure near the H\u2013[N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] complex. SDSS J124144.54+350345.9 (2022-53827-286; bottom panels) has a more symmetric structure, with a centroid that is slightly shifted from the H\u03b1 wavelength. SDSS J013402.54\u2212094627.0 (663-52145-306; top panels) has an unusual asymmetric emission near H\u03b1 and no emission near H\u03b2. SDSS J124144.54+350345.9 (2022-53827-286; bottom panels) has a more symmetric structure, with a centroid that is slightly shifted from the H\u03b1 wavelength.
