SDSS J013402.54\u2212094627.0 (663-52145-306; top panels) has an unusual asymmetric emission near H\u03b1 and no emission near H\u03b2. SDSS J124144.54+350345.9 (2022-53827-286; bottom panels) has a more symmetric structure, with a centroid that is slightly shifted from the H\u03b1 wavelength. In both of the cases, we find similar structure in H\u03b2 after we subtract the best stellar population synthesis model, though we do not detect continuum emission from an accretion disc.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438653 id=\"58438653\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-2>4.1.2 Double-peaked emission line galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Another subset of objects consists of galaxies with double-peaked emission lines, of which we find 13, 10 of which show narrow and 3 show broad double-peaked emission lines. Previous studies conducted searches in the SDSS spectroscopic data with the purpose of finding double-peaked emission lines in galaxies and AGN up to the seventh data release (DR7; Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Liu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Smith et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ge et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Pilyugin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a> and references therein). Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) searched for binary AGN and by visual inspection of SDSS AGN spectra found 148 spectra with a double-peaked <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> profile. Pilyugin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) looked for galaxies with two simultaneous starbursts and by visual inspection of the SDSS spectra found a few hundreds of galaxies with double-peaked emission lines, and studied 55 of them, which had a reliable two component decomposition. Ge et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) compiled the first systematic sample of 3030 double-peaked emission lines objects.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Out of the 10 galaxies with double-peaked narrow emission lines, 2 were reported by previous studies. SDSS J103007.07+412353.5 (1360-53033-0186) is part of the sample presented by Pilyugin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and Ge et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). SDSS J131642.90+175332.6 (5867-56034-0304) is discussed specifically by Xu &amp; Komossa (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), where the authors suggested and discussed a few scenarios that can potentially account for the double-peaked profiles of all of the lines, such as a binary AGN, galaxy merger and jet\u2013cloud interaction. This object is of a particular interest, since it shows double emission profiles in all its nebular lines and an additional broad component [full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of 1400\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>] in most of its forbidden lines. Two additional objects (out of the 10) are worth noting since the SDSS pipeline failed to estimate their redshift correctly: SDSS J223623.78+112824.0 (5049-56103-0273) and J163228.43+541449.2 (6788-56428-0257). The velocity separation between the two peaks is 550\u2009 and 710\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, higher compared to the velocity separation of double-peaked galaxies (see velocity separation distribution in Pilyugin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We present, as an example, the object SDSS J163228.43+541449.2 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> (black) compared to the best-fitting model of the SDSS pipeline (pink) that mistakes the redshift to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.214, identifying the broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> line as H\u03b1. We estimate the redshift of the two emission line components to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.590 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.594 with a velocity separation of 710\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. These galaxies were not reported in previous studies.</p>                        <a id=\"58438656\" scrollto-destination=\"58438656\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=BjvE-SrpETiIafCYA7QuOAHbp6jsoeN4jZPxsxsdyV6G~fEYxvC5UixxB7rRtBF9PnjLGKDvEZfCuAb4Acwo2eQC3eI~LG4etc8W4s9jpiXfKxEkr7tEbBsIMJ8JLze9PYkUjzjUuXHu5aZyCkTUCXIbj1mQe0MVcE3SfLTM8Xl59sSg7YF34B~NZCwsnoSjANwsleOCPy-8-7xEtTFklKgeuTy0s~X1jyfxMyBZnTUocQtZD3tAN4B5GYsj998Nvu9ONr~ujwDRZKKEmLMNqMM1UtZ8XHxkIA3nJhBWAD5-7z96zS8VIkwtslcF-8yEGA6c8dwO651iMxABcmNpvQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example of an object with double-peaked emission lines in the observer frame (SDSS J163228.43+541449.2; 6788-56428-257). The object shows two strong sets of emission lines that are separated by 700\u00a0km\u2009s\u22121 (black line). The SDSS pipeline estimates the redshift of the object to be z\u00a0=\u00a00.214, fitting a model where a broad H\u03b1 component accounts for the wide and double $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$ line (SDSS model in pink). We estimate the redshift of the emission line components to be z\u00a0=\u00a00.590 and z\u00a0=\u00a00.594, and mark the $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$ and H\u03b2 emission line wavelengths in the observers frame according to our redshift estimation. The galaxy shows extremely symmetric components, compared to other double-peaked emission line galaxies, which may indicate that we are seeing a disc-like structure.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438656/stw3021fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438656\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=wK3RLiHxlF-04w6l1sKoqwXC3wRQQrbBitsGF4vyOEe016tdK4PXUIaZAPM1AtYBlPuIcJx93HgaEvHR1zTbxYPIEPVp~jEc88vsNvJccoh04k8vYqFokwo~BP6Qz7TMfOpRWkPnNG7nAcomtpuFkdZ4xsVSEh4iiwdpMv6QwkQP-vAIHUk0wBMaMzAei-oDqsNu6cXYbRZNl68Yr-wu1YH7j-sZvFI9p67CydIMRhA34VO4dvxGsFh6Q4apqUf002xPzXqcxRGEtvuMoL3DAkSLxiSZdG0SEFbVYPKP9TjZisoOOMpnSiej-aKeXRZxq5ptli5dgmfgMYy2834mLQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438656&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of an object with double-peaked emission lines in the observer frame (SDSS J163228.43+541449.2; 6788-56428-257). The object shows two strong sets of emission lines that are separated by 700\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (black line). The SDSS pipeline estimates the redshift of the object to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.214, fitting a model where a broad H\u03b1 component accounts for the wide and double <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> line (SDSS model in pink). We estimate the redshift of the emission line components to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.590 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.594, and mark the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> and H\u03b2 emission line wavelengths in the observers frame according to our redshift estimation. The galaxy shows extremely symmetric components, compared to other double-peaked emission line galaxies, which may indicate that we are seeing a disc-like structure.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=BjvE-SrpETiIafCYA7QuOAHbp6jsoeN4jZPxsxsdyV6G~fEYxvC5UixxB7rRtBF9PnjLGKDvEZfCuAb4Acwo2eQC3eI~LG4etc8W4s9jpiXfKxEkr7tEbBsIMJ8JLze9PYkUjzjUuXHu5aZyCkTUCXIbj1mQe0MVcE3SfLTM8Xl59sSg7YF34B~NZCwsnoSjANwsleOCPy-8-7xEtTFklKgeuTy0s~X1jyfxMyBZnTUocQtZD3tAN4B5GYsj998Nvu9ONr~ujwDRZKKEmLMNqMM1UtZ8XHxkIA3nJhBWAD5-7z96zS8VIkwtslcF-8yEGA6c8dwO651iMxABcmNpvQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example of an object with double-peaked emission lines in the observer frame (SDSS J163228.43+541449.2; 6788-56428-257). The object shows two strong sets of emission lines that are separated by 700\u00a0km\u2009s\u22121 (black line). The SDSS pipeline estimates the redshift of the object to be z\u00a0=\u00a00.214, fitting a model where a broad H\u03b1 component accounts for the wide and double $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$ line (SDSS model in pink). We estimate the redshift of the emission line components to be z\u00a0=\u00a00.590 and z\u00a0=\u00a00.594, and mark the $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$ and H\u03b2 emission line wavelengths in the observers frame according to our redshift estimation. The galaxy shows extremely symmetric components, compared to other double-peaked emission line galaxies, which may indicate that we are seeing a disc-like structure.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438656/stw3021fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438656\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=wK3RLiHxlF-04w6l1sKoqwXC3wRQQrbBitsGF4vyOEe016tdK4PXUIaZAPM1AtYBlPuIcJx93HgaEvHR1zTbxYPIEPVp~jEc88vsNvJccoh04k8vYqFokwo~BP6Qz7TMfOpRWkPnNG7nAcomtpuFkdZ4xsVSEh4iiwdpMv6QwkQP-vAIHUk0wBMaMzAei-oDqsNu6cXYbRZNl68Yr-wu1YH7j-sZvFI9p67CydIMRhA34VO4dvxGsFh6Q4apqUf002xPzXqcxRGEtvuMoL3DAkSLxiSZdG0SEFbVYPKP9TjZisoOOMpnSiej-aKeXRZxq5ptli5dgmfgMYy2834mLQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438656&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of an object with double-peaked emission lines in the observer frame (SDSS J163228.43+541449.2; 6788-56428-257). The object shows two strong sets of emission lines that are separated by 700\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (black line). The SDSS pipeline estimates the redshift of the object to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.214, fitting a model where a broad H\u03b1 component accounts for the wide and double <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> line (SDSS model in pink). We estimate the redshift of the emission line components to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.590 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.594, and mark the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> and H\u03b2 emission line wavelengths in the observers frame according to our redshift estimation. The galaxy shows extremely symmetric components, compared to other double-peaked emission line galaxies, which may indicate that we are seeing a disc-like structure.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find three galaxies that show double-peaked broad emission lines, all of them are reported by previous studies as well. Due to this structure, the SDSS pipeline fails to fit a correct redshift to two of them, fitting the broad double-peaked H\u03b1 emission as Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission. For SDSS J013253.31\u2212095239.3 (662-52147-180), the SDSS estimate the redshift to be 5.73, while we measure it to be 0.259. The broad emission components belong probably to H\u03b1 emission (and not the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>), since we observe the same structure in H\u03b2. These components are located at a velocity of 2880 (blueshifted) and \u22124890\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (redshifted). SDSS J114051.58+054631.1 (838-52378-460) also show two broad emission lines, offset by 4600 and \u22125800\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and we estimate its redshift to be 0.131. For additional information, we refer the reader to the studies that discovered and studied these objects: Strateva et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), Wu &amp; Liu (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), Bian et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) and Strateva et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). We list all the double-peaked galaxies in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438658 id=\"58438658\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-3>4.1.3 Broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission line</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 13 galaxies with relatively broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission lines. For four of these objects, the SDSS pipeline fails to fit a model with a correct redshift, identifying the unusual <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> as H\u03b1. We derive the redshift of the objects by fitting the H\u03b2, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>4959\u2009\u00c5, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0complex, with just three Gaussians, and extract the FWHM of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> 5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0line. The values we derive range from 600\u2009 to 1000\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to compare the FWHM of our <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0emission line to that of the general population, we use the MPA-JHU catalogue, which contains emission line measurements of 927\u00a0552 galaxies from SDSS DR7 (Kauffmann et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003a</a>; Brinchmann et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Tremonti et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). They also derived the velocity of all the forbidden lines (they constrained the velocity to be the same in all the forbidden lines in their fitting process) and converted it to FWHM value, assuming a Gaussian profile. We use galaxies for which the velocity measurement is at least three times higher than its uncertainty, thus rejecting low-SNR objects. We show in the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> the histogram of the FWHM of the entire galaxy population compared to the FWHM of our objects. One can see that these objects are located on the tail of the distribution of the entire population. As an example, we present SDSS J165205.39+430902.3 (6031-56091-0007) in the right-hand panel (black). The redshift derived by the SDSS is <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.244, while the redshift we derive is <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.634, and we measure a FWHM of 930\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> for the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission line. We note that in the case of broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission, samples constructed from the SDSS can be incomplete and biased due to incorrect redshift estimation. At a redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.5, where H\u03b1 is outside the SDSS wavelength range, broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission can be confused with broad H\u03b1 and Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission, and indeed there are hundreds of quasars with incorrect redshift estimation in the SDSS data base (see Reyes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Yuan, Strauss &amp; Zakamska\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). We list the broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission line galaxies in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58438661\" scrollto-destination=\"58438661\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=Rq7i7hmwXckta6LEScVStO34mRDMqJuLF7XjFyZDUB-pv4HHzSOC1opdj1IZJEdkI3S0WZWpchDFpha0BL2BLdcVKsfYJrAG-J~4R7glTQ30uqbFh-jipHLNrJZ0b7i-l2wMyXNkht0RTR14rdQsr4eHLEh0AnKMsTF4l3d~xC14Ng6cwFKq2z33AQDdQxIzS-vkyEtZoY4Vl9SExRpM5KyqD-6YPGL-uA1gwdi4Y7yklSJ9uZi1mkE3B7j2BT74alMhKr4UfORcutN2iHjHeoMvQKC5i5zuj2MdpvmnJxKc2rtjVsqVyVlPf-sCcT-M2METP1g-U5PJBn4oF2pxWw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of the FWHM of the forbidden emission lines of galaxies from the MPA-JHU catalogue (left-hand panel), compared to the FWHM of the $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0emission line we measure for our objects. One can see that our objects reside in the tail of the width distribution. As an example, we show SDSS J165205.39+430902.3 (6031-56091-0007; right-hand panel; black), z\u00a0=\u00a00.634, where H\u03b2, $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$4959\u2009\u00c5and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$5007\u2009\u00c5 are marked with blue-dashed lines. The FWHM of $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0is 930\u2009km\u2009s\u22121 (pink).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438661/stw3021fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438661\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=UyZhh-h0w~aACKBxL-3QvEM2g6LRaS0djqmmj0dQeXkIbyBD3lHIknhq2Jd4kUM5VfzXG8GratAT2tN0HZd5rzd6giEINfVjSuTyG9rOSyD7wEAtd6elbBiveviNH0-f8EY6i1-kWsRk0tAAa~jYJUI~8i50UdsKgdzo~NT0xciR2pBO3fv9HT7GUZM6caMPJGklv-fK5pLkGhMxNECe8OSQup3FIFC3pEY8PqCRW4gILrlhD7FzRLKa-DQ6qL0bSjwzl92kZe8a6sbq0Pq2RQyzi~YXBMfFO3X5xqkUC9-SDIlZaRHF5yOPgAD9F2s2nAYZJUs7T3R3s7cTz5CUoA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438661&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of the FWHM of the forbidden emission lines of galaxies from the MPA-JHU catalogue (left-hand panel), compared to the FWHM of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0emission line we measure for our objects. One can see that our objects reside in the tail of the width distribution. As an example, we show SDSS J165205.39+430902.3 (6031-56091-0007; right-hand panel; black), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.634, where H\u03b2, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>4959\u2009\u00c5and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>5007\u2009\u00c5 are marked with blue-dashed lines. The FWHM of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0is 930\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (pink).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=Rq7i7hmwXckta6LEScVStO34mRDMqJuLF7XjFyZDUB-pv4HHzSOC1opdj1IZJEdkI3S0WZWpchDFpha0BL2BLdcVKsfYJrAG-J~4R7glTQ30uqbFh-jipHLNrJZ0b7i-l2wMyXNkht0RTR14rdQsr4eHLEh0AnKMsTF4l3d~xC14Ng6cwFKq2z33AQDdQxIzS-vkyEtZoY4Vl9SExRpM5KyqD-6YPGL-uA1gwdi4Y7yklSJ9uZi1mkE3B7j2BT74alMhKr4UfORcutN2iHjHeoMvQKC5i5zuj2MdpvmnJxKc2rtjVsqVyVlPf-sCcT-M2METP1g-U5PJBn4oF2pxWw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of the FWHM of the forbidden emission lines of galaxies from the MPA-JHU catalogue (left-hand panel), compared to the FWHM of the $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0emission line we measure for our objects. One can see that our objects reside in the tail of the width distribution. As an example, we show SDSS J165205.39+430902.3 (6031-56091-0007; right-hand panel; black), z\u00a0=\u00a00.634, where H\u03b2, $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$4959\u2009\u00c5and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$5007\u2009\u00c5 are marked with blue-dashed lines. The FWHM of $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0is 930\u2009km\u2009s\u22121 (pink).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438661/stw3021fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438661\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=UyZhh-h0w~aACKBxL-3QvEM2g6LRaS0djqmmj0dQeXkIbyBD3lHIknhq2Jd4kUM5VfzXG8GratAT2tN0HZd5rzd6giEINfVjSuTyG9rOSyD7wEAtd6elbBiveviNH0-f8EY6i1-kWsRk0tAAa~jYJUI~8i50UdsKgdzo~NT0xciR2pBO3fv9HT7GUZM6caMPJGklv-fK5pLkGhMxNECe8OSQup3FIFC3pEY8PqCRW4gILrlhD7FzRLKa-DQ6qL0bSjwzl92kZe8a6sbq0Pq2RQyzi~YXBMfFO3X5xqkUC9-SDIlZaRHF5yOPgAD9F2s2nAYZJUs7T3R3s7cTz5CUoA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438661&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of the FWHM of the forbidden emission lines of galaxies from the MPA-JHU catalogue (left-hand panel), compared to the FWHM of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0emission line we measure for our objects. One can see that our objects reside in the tail of the width distribution. As an example, we show SDSS J165205.39+430902.3 (6031-56091-0007; right-hand panel; black), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.634, where H\u03b2, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>4959\u2009\u00c5and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>5007\u2009\u00c5 are marked with blue-dashed lines. The FWHM of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span>5007\u2009\u00c5\u00a0is 930\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (pink).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In many galaxies, the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission lines show an additional blueshifted component, which is usually interpreted as being due to outflows. Forbidden lines are used to study the kinematics of galaxies, since in most of the cases they have narrow resolved profiles (unlike the H\u03b1 and H\u03b2 for example). As a consequence, different velocity components can be separated and studied. However, broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> lines that can be well described by a single Gaussian are rare (e.g. Alexander et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Greene et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Harrison et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Carniani et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Zakamska et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438663 id=\"58438663\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 E+A galaxies</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">E+A galaxies (also known as k+a galaxies, \u2018post-starburst\u2019, and H\u03b4-strong galaxies) are galaxies with strong Balmer H\u03b4 absorption in their spectra, with values typically larger than 4\u20135\u2009\u00c5. The emission in these galaxies is dominated by A-stars, with lifetimes of around 1\u00a0Gyr. Therefore, stars were formed recently, O- and B-stars have all evolved past the main sequence, but A-stars have not yet. Consequently, E+A galaxies must have undergone a recent (and quite abrupt) change in their star formation. These galaxies comprise 3\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the general galaxy population (Goto et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), and in many of them, it appears that a significant fraction of the galaxy stellar mass was created in the starburst (20\u201360\u00a0per\u00a0cent). A special subclass of these are galaxies that do not show H\u03b1 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission lines, indicating that these galaxies are not currently star forming, but have undergone a recent starburst. These galaxies are observed during a short-lived phase in their evolution, and are fewer than 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent of the galaxy population (Goto et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Goto\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Balogh et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Goto\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Melnick &amp; De Propris\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Alatalo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Out of 400 outlying galaxies, we identify strong H\u03b4 absorption in 33, 28 of which were discussed in previous studies of such galaxies (see references above). We look for H\u03b1 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission in our objects and find that only 7 out of 33 show emission lines that indicate ongoing star formation, while 26 do not. We list the H\u03b4 strong galaxies we find in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A5</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note specifically SDSS J132401.63+454620.6 (1463-53063-262), which shows strong H\u03b4 absorption and a broad emission components near the H\u03b1 emission line. We show the object in the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. We start by fitting a stellar population synthesis model to account for the stellar continuum, like in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1.1</a>. We find a good fit with a population of stars of age 0.05\u20130.1\u00a0Gyr, as expected for E+A galaxies. We then subtract the stellar contribution in order to study the properties of the emitting gas.</p>                        <a id=\"58438667\" scrollto-destination=\"58438667\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=hNZy8SITQoFgdu9meoGyur~hklZ-VodwyFJrzQfRq1wjf7y0yDDzlbl-~uk1YBOoulqekMiTAuwSyyN~39MEa0K84x0ggrujcJ8Yw4SAoQ3cfXbQWhaITVpLGjFtN6oPKhbLh~EUKZQLmQnp8KTGXg9F0MwThjCGDLucb7fhCEtO2teI9GKYCpRFqtJmcmcfINB53zHUCW65FNmFhX0dKL-zXkT0Py9N3t6M0DLLHS5ZOC42hmGRAoQkaKEL2ZoyRCdZEm4D~C9C7NXhYmOVDr2ZzO~I2emPvyEYyyeEQwflIenwplzz5SW2uNxTwzzGetCLtvFkS20ne9R4DWObFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J132401.63+454620.6 (1463-53063-262) \u2013 H\u03b4 strong galaxy that also has a broad H\u03b1 emission line (left-hand panel). This object is peculiar, since the strength of the H\u03b4 indicates a recent change in its star formation activity; however, an AGN is still detectable through broad H\u03b1 emission. We fit the lines (right-hand panel), find that the FWHM of the broad H\u03b1 component is 2150\u2009km\u2009s\u22121 and that the line ratio $\\mathrm{log\\,[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\alpha }=0.28$ is consistent with gas that is exposed to hard X-ray radiation.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438667/stw3021fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438667\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Zip9fMpT9KbICFDgoYmHnV--NnSYelQ65nWGJrMrqLzNygBsf7MPRxjwc2XfhP~26HsVwwhRcPAlOOTZUbMZLX8Nite0a9OArZGP9RjfJZOLdSEF1Y6mgA6l96Rv9wbglXOTa1RMTaO0912eTIXAx0T9Ub3ShNy~sbaExe9BEm1a9Qo4h4zjFaMKcVc1Tfw1m53OjGPQEIsLZoCFqAeyRC8lvcdCy2JveirkpUQfvDUU5m9tXFor-uO4Mt1P6oqQVXb-9imYxm8GjjrQgJPVrAVsgJhFm65~BRWKtVn-F4XB6oCXIEXovlFQxgd7CWj3zakxKj3n9EnGB4wK3FOU3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438667&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J132401.63+454620.6 (1463-53063-262) \u2013 H\u03b4 strong galaxy that also has a broad H\u03b1 emission line (left-hand panel). This object is peculiar, since the strength of the H\u03b4 indicates a recent change in its star formation activity; however, an AGN is still detectable through broad H\u03b1 emission. We fit the lines (right-hand panel), find that the FWHM of the broad H\u03b1 component is 2150\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and that the line ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\alpha }=0.28$|</span> is consistent with gas that is exposed to hard X-ray radiation.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=hNZy8SITQoFgdu9meoGyur~hklZ-VodwyFJrzQfRq1wjf7y0yDDzlbl-~uk1YBOoulqekMiTAuwSyyN~39MEa0K84x0ggrujcJ8Yw4SAoQ3cfXbQWhaITVpLGjFtN6oPKhbLh~EUKZQLmQnp8KTGXg9F0MwThjCGDLucb7fhCEtO2teI9GKYCpRFqtJmcmcfINB53zHUCW65FNmFhX0dKL-zXkT0Py9N3t6M0DLLHS5ZOC42hmGRAoQkaKEL2ZoyRCdZEm4D~C9C7NXhYmOVDr2ZzO~I2emPvyEYyyeEQwflIenwplzz5SW2uNxTwzzGetCLtvFkS20ne9R4DWObFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J132401.63+454620.6 (1463-53063-262) \u2013 H\u03b4 strong galaxy that also has a broad H\u03b1 emission line (left-hand panel). This object is peculiar, since the strength of the H\u03b4 indicates a recent change in its star formation activity; however, an AGN is still detectable through broad H\u03b1 emission. We fit the lines (right-hand panel), find that the FWHM of the broad H\u03b1 component is 2150\u2009km\u2009s\u22121 and that the line ratio $\\mathrm{log\\,[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\alpha }=0.28$ is consistent with gas that is exposed to hard X-ray radiation.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438667/stw3021fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438667\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Zip9fMpT9KbICFDgoYmHnV--NnSYelQ65nWGJrMrqLzNygBsf7MPRxjwc2XfhP~26HsVwwhRcPAlOOTZUbMZLX8Nite0a9OArZGP9RjfJZOLdSEF1Y6mgA6l96Rv9wbglXOTa1RMTaO0912eTIXAx0T9Ub3ShNy~sbaExe9BEm1a9Qo4h4zjFaMKcVc1Tfw1m53OjGPQEIsLZoCFqAeyRC8lvcdCy2JveirkpUQfvDUU5m9tXFor-uO4Mt1P6oqQVXb-9imYxm8GjjrQgJPVrAVsgJhFm65~BRWKtVn-F4XB6oCXIEXovlFQxgd7CWj3zakxKj3n9EnGB4wK3FOU3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438667&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J132401.63+454620.6 (1463-53063-262) \u2013 H\u03b4 strong galaxy that also has a broad H\u03b1 emission line (left-hand panel). This object is peculiar, since the strength of the H\u03b4 indicates a recent change in its star formation activity; however, an AGN is still detectable through broad H\u03b1 emission. We fit the lines (right-hand panel), find that the FWHM of the broad H\u03b1 component is 2150\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and that the line ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\alpha }=0.28$|</span> is consistent with gas that is exposed to hard X-ray radiation.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We start by fitting a single component to the narrow H\u03b1 emission and two additional narrow components to the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission and find that these cannot account for the entire emission. We therefore fit an additional, broad, component that is centred around the H\u03b1 central wavelength. The best-fitting profile is presented in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. The FWHM we obtain for the broad H\u03b1 is 2150\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. We also measure the line ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> for the narrow components and find it to be 0.28, consistent with gas that is exposed to hard X-ray radiation. We note however that the forbidden lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> show weak broad features that are marginally detected; thus, it is possible that the broad emission around H\u03b1 is composed of both H\u03b1 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> contributions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is clear that this object is of special interest. The stellar composition of the galaxy suggests that star formation has started simultaneously in the entire galaxy (due to the narrow age distribution that we find) and that the galaxy has undergone a recent shutdown of its star formation (i.e. no O- and B-stars). On the other hand, we measure broad emission components that may suggest either AGN heating or shocked gas due to recent merger or nuclear outflows. In terms of the cosmic cycle (e.g. Hopkins et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), this galaxy may represent a very short-lived phase in general galaxy evolution, where the star formation had already terminated due to AGN feedback though enough gas is still left to fuel the accretion disc (see for example Springel, Di Matteo &amp; Hernquist\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Netzer\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Studying this galaxy and similar ones may allow one to study the feedback mechanisms that terminate star formation, which we do in Baron et\u00a0al. (in preparation).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438670 id=\"58438670\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Unusual emission lines</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 3 galaxies that show coronal lines in their spectra, and 10 galaxies with strong <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span>\u00a05200\u2009\u00c5\u00a0emission. We list these galaxies in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A6</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438672 id=\"58438672\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-1>4.3.1 Coronal line emitters</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">High ionization or coronal lines arise in gas that is exposed to soft X-ray radiation. Several studies have suggested a connection between extreme coronal line emitters (ECLEs) and tidal disruption events (TDE), in which a star is tidally disrupted as it enters the tidal radius of a massive black hole (Komossa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Wang et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) were the first to conduct a systematic search for TDEs in the SDSS spectroscopic data by looking for ECLEs. They detected ECLEs by either looking for extreme coronal lines (at least one line is at least 20\u00a0per\u00a0cent as strong as the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> line) or coronal lines from a galaxy that is classified as an H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> region on the BPT diagram. The authors found seven objects in total that satisfy the criteria, one of them is found as an outlier by our algorithm (SDSS J093801.63+135317.0; 2580-54092-0470). It is worth noting that out of the seven objects in their sample, only four objects are classified as galaxies by the SDSS pipeline (rather than QSO) and enter our sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find two additional galaxies with coronal lines ([Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">x</span>] 6376\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 6088\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 5722\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">xiv</span>] 5304\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 3759\u2009\u00c5); these galaxies do not meet the criteria of Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), since they are classified as AGN in the BPT diagnostic diagram. We show an example of such galaxy, SDSS J120041.39+314746.2 (6473-56363-672), in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>, where one can see the emission lines [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 6088\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 5722\u2009\u00c5 and [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">xiv</span>] 5304\u2009\u00c5. Gelbord, Mullaney &amp; Ward (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) look for forbidden high ionization lines in the SDSS DR6 and find 63 objects, some of which are classified by the SDSS pipeline as galaxies and some as QSOs.</p>                        <a id=\"58438675\" scrollto-destination=\"58438675\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=gMnzyShh4Pzj6M3g3ix27he4rZ7A9-QFCKNslCg0azcscMaadKq2KpwbvkuZqMb3sfiad8yINsjIdmXv8iHSVANtPZXh63IAwTUUyMpRdRUAzgvtOsVZR~T~dvqLjnV8ZD29le0chwGtLoiFb20djo422VyeVhFvn2dIwX5JZim2CkLFahmVbMR~7MciRWjDaJMWAZrZYJry1sacQ56Qnmx9CkWf0qpCdoFM3KCUUYMiBs4zoaKXfKS-0pGrXDYPbko7cZZpL0pNDW5Haz4T4~uldBDYYHFtYUtPIYBSEqbAsU0G1DhDnPlz89NeZSvKnw3kErLyDQqI9GBXcjfSzA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Galaxy with detected high ionization emission lines. SDSS J120041.39+314746.2 (6473-56363-672) is a galaxy at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.116 for which we detect the coronal lines: [Fe\u2009x] 6376\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009vii] 6088\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009vii] 5722\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009xiv] 5304\u2009\u00c5 and [Fe\u2009vii] 3759\u2009\u00c5. This galaxy is not reported by Wang et\u00a0al. (2012), since it is classified as AGN from its line diagnostics.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438675/stw3021fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438675\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=0hc7nHnEBXiFBAnsQRY5Ki-UW5jdPNZ-iVU4B0TNqlpiv8cQpyeC6R0kkK~kMmFM9wb62gUwV9v5XLKULirrgzahGrqpCTZHb6rHtZFHqxPKzSVIl3wbm72KldetJ5yvoVbB-fm0zczXDgaULe5s15C2XQaxUJNyKqfCW-QYEnxuFY1keuN7r1opiDK0quPSHBcGva6JULoiwX6AOo72ckH9mrmuZm9zbKmqYS9wlj9IDgld~~TO-cbnTr4vq6qvBmQdtgSDYwgUAQgYZZSPZzuSYOce3F9n5WpIh5VmPoBrsVewY6QGgSP-LalVg9VeVYFuTW~VJ4BjIsYIvUUe6w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438675&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy with detected high ionization emission lines. SDSS J120041.39+314746.2 (6473-56363-672) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.116 for which we detect the coronal lines: [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">x</span>] 6376\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 6088\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 5722\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">xiv</span>] 5304\u2009\u00c5 and [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 3759\u2009\u00c5.
