This galaxy is not reported by Wang et\u00a0al. (2012), since it is classified as AGN from its line diagnostics.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438675/stw3021fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438675\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=0hc7nHnEBXiFBAnsQRY5Ki-UW5jdPNZ-iVU4B0TNqlpiv8cQpyeC6R0kkK~kMmFM9wb62gUwV9v5XLKULirrgzahGrqpCTZHb6rHtZFHqxPKzSVIl3wbm72KldetJ5yvoVbB-fm0zczXDgaULe5s15C2XQaxUJNyKqfCW-QYEnxuFY1keuN7r1opiDK0quPSHBcGva6JULoiwX6AOo72ckH9mrmuZm9zbKmqYS9wlj9IDgld~~TO-cbnTr4vq6qvBmQdtgSDYwgUAQgYZZSPZzuSYOce3F9n5WpIh5VmPoBrsVewY6QGgSP-LalVg9VeVYFuTW~VJ4BjIsYIvUUe6w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438675&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy with detected high ionization emission lines. SDSS J120041.39+314746.2 (6473-56363-672) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.116 for which we detect the coronal lines: [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">x</span>] 6376\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 6088\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 5722\u2009\u00c5, [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">xiv</span>] 5304\u2009\u00c5 and [Fe\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">vii</span>] 3759\u2009\u00c5. This galaxy is not reported by Wang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), since it is classified as AGN from its line diagnostics.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438676 id=\"58438676\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-2>4.3.2 Visible <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission line</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 10 galaxies that show an emission line at 5200\u00a0\u00c5, for 8 of them one must subtract the best-fitting population synthesis model in order to detect the emission line (as done is Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1.1</a>). We show an example of such galaxy in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>. SDSS J102339.63+041110.6 (575-52319-200) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.290, classified as a composite (i.e. both H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> region and AGN radiation are prominent radiation sources) using the BPT diagram. Furthermore, the galaxy is a member of a galaxy cluster and is detected in radio emission (FIRST catalogue).</p>                        <a id=\"58438678\" scrollto-destination=\"58438678\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=vOoWtU--2S7Vu3nxOVllIil9qkzHmvS-WsSsJ~dniHD6uXyGrA5xH8poeFHWARwnQAHtRunoou9IG02fmKF57fnDe-FW7zoVJAVYiqzv7AtRu0uOBzCT8xrkWvPbCS8Z~pdZRX3CJqWd8j60eCrDSzeCd8TYxeQUC0LDHHJizSC1-Vz99YvCA7EknwlbDdv5qzpO5cRoAs25HEIYAllftecmuMIH-O5gkuPhBam6zxn4heUtiyNnxUbAcy4Nm6zqRuK0DGzg-LBdvILe8ZX6mkO0QxiOtcTpWRKr1oI0pMtlIEgKN-zXCeEEtqT7m8MxSaXZKqLGVXP8I36M2MdCIw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"An example of a galaxy with unusually strong $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$ emission. SDSS J102339.63+041110.6 (575-52319-200) is a galaxy at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.290 and it is a member of a galaxy cluster, and it is detected in radio emission. We measure the ratio $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]/H\\,\\beta }=0.33$ in the spectrum, while in planetary nebulae the $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$ emission is 10\u2013100\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438678/stw3021fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438678\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=AQ4VRC-LRGvamOEyB3jzGt5EmJkkOBzzafi6keoe5WWxRn-lpTHFh8SPjUl3J7myK5nJKoqk-~Kv1ACG8s3vU3Q79vDK6FfRyg9gp0UGu0kFb4o5vkmUqhhWIsyFGpwsS-4fX0Pc4mzKnl~2G3LPm~xK-se-SkbIE9q9aBZM6if8bwWR8WbVBOrjcjQR9ojrZpcou9ewks5qVu6UcS0Mv29-6iTHEY56B-vid8W~TLF9tWhuPI1oMc36TlvKtZ0dmBuU9OklKM4Bvqx48cK9LrYQXLRweYcoCA-mckTKf-y9SLBmCsamRpQi8I4MuRFDwLZAzvSslPayVElNMM0dcA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438678&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">An example of a galaxy with unusually strong <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission. SDSS J102339.63+041110.6 (575-52319-200) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.290 and it is a member of a galaxy cluster, and it is detected in radio emission. We measure the ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]/H\\,\\beta }=0.33$|</span> in the spectrum, while in planetary nebulae the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission is 10\u2013100\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=vOoWtU--2S7Vu3nxOVllIil9qkzHmvS-WsSsJ~dniHD6uXyGrA5xH8poeFHWARwnQAHtRunoou9IG02fmKF57fnDe-FW7zoVJAVYiqzv7AtRu0uOBzCT8xrkWvPbCS8Z~pdZRX3CJqWd8j60eCrDSzeCd8TYxeQUC0LDHHJizSC1-Vz99YvCA7EknwlbDdv5qzpO5cRoAs25HEIYAllftecmuMIH-O5gkuPhBam6zxn4heUtiyNnxUbAcy4Nm6zqRuK0DGzg-LBdvILe8ZX6mkO0QxiOtcTpWRKr1oI0pMtlIEgKN-zXCeEEtqT7m8MxSaXZKqLGVXP8I36M2MdCIw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"An example of a galaxy with unusually strong $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$ emission. SDSS J102339.63+041110.6 (575-52319-200) is a galaxy at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.290 and it is a member of a galaxy cluster, and it is detected in radio emission. We measure the ratio $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]/H\\,\\beta }=0.33$ in the spectrum, while in planetary nebulae the $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$ emission is 10\u2013100\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438678/stw3021fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438678\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=AQ4VRC-LRGvamOEyB3jzGt5EmJkkOBzzafi6keoe5WWxRn-lpTHFh8SPjUl3J7myK5nJKoqk-~Kv1ACG8s3vU3Q79vDK6FfRyg9gp0UGu0kFb4o5vkmUqhhWIsyFGpwsS-4fX0Pc4mzKnl~2G3LPm~xK-se-SkbIE9q9aBZM6if8bwWR8WbVBOrjcjQR9ojrZpcou9ewks5qVu6UcS0Mv29-6iTHEY56B-vid8W~TLF9tWhuPI1oMc36TlvKtZ0dmBuU9OklKM4Bvqx48cK9LrYQXLRweYcoCA-mckTKf-y9SLBmCsamRpQi8I4MuRFDwLZAzvSslPayVElNMM0dcA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438678&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">An example of a galaxy with unusually strong <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission. SDSS J102339.63+041110.6 (575-52319-200) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.290 and it is a member of a galaxy cluster, and it is detected in radio emission. We measure the ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]/H\\,\\beta }=0.33$|</span> in the spectrum, while in planetary nebulae the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission is 10\u2013100\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We fit Gaussians to the emission lines H\u03b2, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>, H\u03b1, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and the line at 5200\u00a0\u00c5. We find that the FWHM of the 5200\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0emission line is consistent with the FWHM of the forbidden lines for both of the galaxies. We identify the emission line at 5200\u2009\u00c5\u00a0as emission from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|\u2060</span>, using the emission-line catalogue conducted by Kaler, Shaw &amp; Browning (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>, see references therein). <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission is usually observed in planetary nebulae and its strength is typically 10\u2013100\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2 emission, it is also detected in composite quasar spectra with a typical strength that is 10\u00a0times weaker than H\u03b2 (Zakamska &amp; Greene\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). In our galaxies, the EW ratio of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> ranges from 0.33 to 1. However, we note one case in the literature where the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission strength is comparable to the H\u03b2 emission, PKS 2322-12 (Costero &amp; Osterbrock\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1977</a>), which is a narrow-line radio galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While galaxies often show strong emission from singly ionized nitrogen (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>), atomic nitrogen is not observed in emission since it is too easy to ionize. Atomic nitrogen can exist in cool areas where it is shielded from ionizing radiation and can be seen in weak emission, most likely due to photoexcitation. An alternative scenario, which can potentially produce stronger <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> emission, can take place in cool cluster filaments, where the shielded atomic nitrogen is excited by shocks or hard penetrating X-ray photons (Ferland et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). These scenarios however do not explain how we see such strong emission in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span> in these galaxies. This may require photoionization calculations that are beyond the scope of this paper.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438681 id=\"58438681\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Unusual emission lines ratios</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Most of the galaxies in this subsample are of known classes, but their emission lines lie at the extreme of their population's respective distribution. These objects show outlying line ratios \u2013 156 of them are outliers on the BPT line diagnostic diagram, and there are 30 galaxies for which only the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{H\\,\\alpha {\\rm -}[N\\,\\small {II}]{\\rm -}[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> complex is detected. Furthermore, they show relatively weak H\u03b1 emission compared to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438683 id=\"58438683\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4-1>4.4.1 Outliers on the BPT diagram</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Prominent emission lines in galaxies have been used to study the physical properties of galaxies and their dominant source of radiation. Baldwin, Phillips &amp; Terlevich (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1981</a>) proposed a diagnostic diagram (known today as the BPT diagram) based on the ratios <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> to separate among gas that is exposed to hard radiation fields, planetary nebulae and H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions. Veilleux &amp; Osterbrock (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>) refined this scheme and added two additional diagnostic diagrams with the ratios <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {I}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|\u2060</span>, based on photoionization models. The SDSS, providing millions of galaxy spectra, has had a great impact on the classification of galaxies and allowed a clean and significant characterization of the different types of galaxies and the transitions between them (Kauffmann et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003b</a>; Kewley et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> a BPT diagram for the emission line ratios: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\beta }$|\u2060</span>. We show typical galaxies from the MPA-JHU catalogue in grey, on a logarithmic colour scale. For our outlying galaxies, we measure the emission lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|\u2060</span>, H\u03b1, H\u03b2 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> by integration over Gaussians profiles that we fit: the H\u03b1, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> are modelled jointly with 5 Gaussians at fixed rest-frame wavelengths and the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> and H\u03b2 profiles are similarly measured with 3 Gaussians. We examine the goodness of the fit by eye, and when needed we add additional Gaussian component (e.g. if a profile is not symmetric) or allow the rest-frame wavelength to shift. We mark the emission line ratios of our outliers in green.</p>                        <a id=\"58438686\" scrollto-destination=\"58438686\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=LQ6o9geEGQhP6lhCSGQdJXIcKCU8b8AZRUaHc2hyAXSpT~m2pEG3wBJedwExvUvUN-z0iKkRv4bOci1n0T1FCLN6jahBDSWCQFByVeuL~HmaFlEzblJCOeyDXtOKk7Syeu6VdR-mqGCwnW2fEgWcey90umFUodRiWadPhADNHzxDIrD88r-rwVv8oUVKcOpMZMqSQQjQbuYs9uKJWNGnTeNZgTaibINu2y2hKmTHa5YU0lQnEMZ4xxRapLyUQz9QUg3hR4K3MziptVlMIMAdIp~kC4CNKP4eN1rpqxmMKtPfuFWgp3h8JZz5hNjacAzwSwDbEYWGSXxj4xTk38KqbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"BPT diagrams based on the $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$ emission line ratios (left-hand panel) and $\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$ ratios (right-hand panel). The grey background represents the density of SDSS galaxies (927\u00a0552 galaxies from DR7) on a logarithmic colour scale. Outlying galaxies are marked with green circles. Outlier galaxies that are classified as H\u2009ii regions in one diagnostic and as AGN in another are each plotted with the same marker and colour in both panels. The classification limits are taken from the extreme starburst limit by Kewley et\u00a0al. (2001, Ke01; blue line) and composite galaxies by Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (2003a, Ka03; black line).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438686/stw3021fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438686\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=bs3B5zMwthrzccP651JfJve8hnQQ0hMgm5fdwPlshheOUNft61NlNf3o0LjZR-jnosc3QFA6C5JW23AUhXWDX1l4hpqdo~tnuCOqHIaHCgiA9jpwdi5nHvgioO6iSTV~A8SPszIWW08ly-eKc5AGt8-bOm8UuXoixoe6RCkj1nOmfVsWyWXV~2WCXrfRMgfZpnt8DSrMsl3LbsKKE-50D2C7C8qV8JKli-LReX4LSHCbeLDX4LUb2VZdFHEp6tvima1TUJki39JKVJCJSNZ89qrB~5myn9zPg615dgQbXGrp8kJRBdcmZ0aen7izpgCGGECxwRZUOxM079jzi5RuSw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438686&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">BPT diagrams based on the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> emission line ratios (left-hand panel) and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> ratios (right-hand panel). The grey background represents the density of SDSS galaxies (927\u00a0552 galaxies from DR7) on a logarithmic colour scale. Outlying galaxies are marked with green circles. Outlier galaxies that are classified as H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions in one diagnostic and as AGN in another are each plotted with the same marker and colour in both panels. The classification limits are taken from the extreme starburst limit by Kewley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>, Ke01; blue line) and composite galaxies by Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003a</a>, Ka03; black line).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=LQ6o9geEGQhP6lhCSGQdJXIcKCU8b8AZRUaHc2hyAXSpT~m2pEG3wBJedwExvUvUN-z0iKkRv4bOci1n0T1FCLN6jahBDSWCQFByVeuL~HmaFlEzblJCOeyDXtOKk7Syeu6VdR-mqGCwnW2fEgWcey90umFUodRiWadPhADNHzxDIrD88r-rwVv8oUVKcOpMZMqSQQjQbuYs9uKJWNGnTeNZgTaibINu2y2hKmTHa5YU0lQnEMZ4xxRapLyUQz9QUg3hR4K3MziptVlMIMAdIp~kC4CNKP4eN1rpqxmMKtPfuFWgp3h8JZz5hNjacAzwSwDbEYWGSXxj4xTk38KqbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"BPT diagrams based on the $\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$ emission line ratios (left-hand panel) and $\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ and $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$ ratios (right-hand panel). The grey background represents the density of SDSS galaxies (927\u00a0552 galaxies from DR7) on a logarithmic colour scale. Outlying galaxies are marked with green circles. Outlier galaxies that are classified as H\u2009ii regions in one diagnostic and as AGN in another are each plotted with the same marker and colour in both panels. The classification limits are taken from the extreme starburst limit by Kewley et\u00a0al. (2001, Ke01; blue line) and composite galaxies by Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (2003a, Ka03; black line).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438686/stw3021fig14.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438686\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig14.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=bs3B5zMwthrzccP651JfJve8hnQQ0hMgm5fdwPlshheOUNft61NlNf3o0LjZR-jnosc3QFA6C5JW23AUhXWDX1l4hpqdo~tnuCOqHIaHCgiA9jpwdi5nHvgioO6iSTV~A8SPszIWW08ly-eKc5AGt8-bOm8UuXoixoe6RCkj1nOmfVsWyWXV~2WCXrfRMgfZpnt8DSrMsl3LbsKKE-50D2C7C8qV8JKli-LReX4LSHCbeLDX4LUb2VZdFHEp6tvima1TUJki39JKVJCJSNZ89qrB~5myn9zPg615dgQbXGrp8kJRBdcmZ0aen7izpgCGGECxwRZUOxM079jzi5RuSw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438686&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig14.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">BPT diagrams based on the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> emission line ratios (left-hand panel) and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]/H\\,\\beta }$|</span> ratios (right-hand panel). The grey background represents the density of SDSS galaxies (927\u00a0552 galaxies from DR7) on a logarithmic colour scale. Outlying galaxies are marked with green circles. Outlier galaxies that are classified as H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions in one diagnostic and as AGN in another are each plotted with the same marker and colour in both panels. The classification limits are taken from the extreme starburst limit by Kewley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>, Ke01; blue line) and composite galaxies by Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003a</a>, Ka03; black line).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Kewley, Jansen &amp; Geller (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) analysed the effect of a fixed aperture size on metallicity, star formation rate and reddening, and concluded that a minimum aperture covering a fraction of \u224820 per\u00a0cent is required for the spectral properties to approximate the global values, which translates to a lower limit on redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.04 (for the SDSS spectrograph). Out of the 156 emission line galaxies with unusual ratios, only 86 satisfy this criterion. One can see that the outlier galaxies show emission line ratios that reside on the tails of the distribution of the entire population, which explains their weirdness score.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">15 outliers are classified as H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> regions with one diagnostic and AGN with another diagnostic. We show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a> examples for such cases. We use two separating criteria: Kewley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) who used a combination of population synthesis models and photoionization models to produce a theoretical upper limit that separates between starbursts and AGN-dominated galaxies (Ke01; blue line), Kauffmann et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003a</a>) modified this limit by including composite galaxies that contain significant contribution from both star formation and AGN (Ka03; black line). Individual objects that show this duality are marked with the same colour and symbol in the two panels, for convenience. We list the 156 BPT outliers in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A7</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438689 id=\"58438689\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4-2>4.4.2 Weak H\u03b1 emission</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify 30 galaxies with emission in H\u03b1, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[S\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> but none in H\u03b2 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|\u2060</span>. Therefore, in order to study their gas emission properties, we fit and subtract a stellar population synthesis model (as in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1.1</a>). These galaxies have unusually large <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> and S[II] over H\u03b1 ratios (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha } \\approx 0.1$|\u2060</span>). Some of the objects are low-redshift galaxies, with an angular size a few times the diameter of the SDSS fibre, so the spectrum only samples a small fraction of the gas near the galactic centre.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, we find seven objects with <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.065, and by comparison of their Petrosian radius (from SDSS photometry) to the fibre diameter, we verify that the SDSS fibre indeed captures 20 per cent or more of the galactic light. We measure the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> line ratio for our objects and present it in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a> compared to the line ratio histogram of the MPA-JHU catalogue of galaxies from the SDSS (left-hand panel), where one can see that our objects reside on the tail of this distribution. We give an example of such a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.138 for which <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$|</span> (right-hand panel). We list these galaxies in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A8</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58438692\" scrollto-destination=\"58438692\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=q13B8JWCngyh4zsNwezAG9Rl7TkV6J3UuTBZ0BxbmVkgZyo6d7HoGZQf1KkGqz0YT8V4I~0~1uoHhRSSBS7ZHfw8gPqcJTgo2Z~ekf6twqRTQHybzi1DbrTJC-sekGRgLZhFRFSKx1z--Sl0P~88YEjkx-gpPoVy-eXEFYRqwwrUCpW5cnqjlfUQXQWrB2t6dSOh-TGrrMQHUiKOeD5ekhR1062Y9sB7FDd6UAXgTaZC3KgznWdDYM6kNuNbs9XTXxPUw2cBCsC~IL4PcfnSczA6zbGVLu2F82bwqqCtYg~D1IXHq-zg~M74PwoTU0Bw6X35i5hy32uwbBy7TikLLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between the $\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ line ratio of the 24 outlying galaxies (pink) and the general galaxy population (grey histogram) using the MPA-JHU catalogue of SDSS galaxies (left-hand panel). One can see that the galaxies we find are located on the tail of the general distribution and have unusual line ratios, greater than most of the galaxies in SDSS. We give an example of such a galaxy (SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1; 7054-56575-500) at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.138 that has a ratio $\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438692/stw3021fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438692\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=IhDbD9ztvMRHvstnBNmkf3XyqK2-L~xIsbRW5sU0EinZcn0kFEUMRYiFljd-bOY~0F-3rdGgB4rppdz8Mnh0pql0SqeyeNC4BAp7qLNY7nYXCiJKrei4r1mCkR~QBnIoNOX~vMGzFAC3EvvXC6qy9IERYLHRHtk0ncmp8OgPVUpOL4fWKkhsEmLRA-YNmmg1foUWg5w6KhgH-6cx-mBWVPRQ6~UW13tvbk~4hRketCjW7r6yHz6GhwY9OZq2MM-FpevVxZc0oxTMBTNqTQiWCi7r5xuUq9JoQGibBKUkG2tV5ToNR0ZjL08d1EA7a0tsarmmF-Gj6NVqDdNTWKuyAQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438692&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> line ratio of the 24 outlying galaxies (pink) and the general galaxy population (grey histogram) using the MPA-JHU catalogue of SDSS galaxies (left-hand panel). One can see that the galaxies we find are located on the tail of the general distribution and have unusual line ratios, greater than most of the galaxies in SDSS. We give an example of such a galaxy (SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1; 7054-56575-500) at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.138 that has a ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=q13B8JWCngyh4zsNwezAG9Rl7TkV6J3UuTBZ0BxbmVkgZyo6d7HoGZQf1KkGqz0YT8V4I~0~1uoHhRSSBS7ZHfw8gPqcJTgo2Z~ekf6twqRTQHybzi1DbrTJC-sekGRgLZhFRFSKx1z--Sl0P~88YEjkx-gpPoVy-eXEFYRqwwrUCpW5cnqjlfUQXQWrB2t6dSOh-TGrrMQHUiKOeD5ekhR1062Y9sB7FDd6UAXgTaZC3KgznWdDYM6kNuNbs9XTXxPUw2cBCsC~IL4PcfnSczA6zbGVLu2F82bwqqCtYg~D1IXHq-zg~M74PwoTU0Bw6X35i5hy32uwbBy7TikLLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between the $\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$ line ratio of the 24 outlying galaxies (pink) and the general galaxy population (grey histogram) using the MPA-JHU catalogue of SDSS galaxies (left-hand panel). One can see that the galaxies we find are located on the tail of the general distribution and have unusual line ratios, greater than most of the galaxies in SDSS. We give an example of such a galaxy (SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1; 7054-56575-500) at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.138 that has a ratio $\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438692/stw3021fig15.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438692\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig15.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=IhDbD9ztvMRHvstnBNmkf3XyqK2-L~xIsbRW5sU0EinZcn0kFEUMRYiFljd-bOY~0F-3rdGgB4rppdz8Mnh0pql0SqeyeNC4BAp7qLNY7nYXCiJKrei4r1mCkR~QBnIoNOX~vMGzFAC3EvvXC6qy9IERYLHRHtk0ncmp8OgPVUpOL4fWKkhsEmLRA-YNmmg1foUWg5w6KhgH-6cx-mBWVPRQ6~UW13tvbk~4hRketCjW7r6yHz6GhwY9OZq2MM-FpevVxZc0oxTMBTNqTQiWCi7r5xuUq9JoQGibBKUkG2tV5ToNR0ZjL08d1EA7a0tsarmmF-Gj6NVqDdNTWKuyAQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438692&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig15.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha }$|</span> line ratio of the 24 outlying galaxies (pink) and the general galaxy population (grey histogram) using the MPA-JHU catalogue of SDSS galaxies (left-hand panel). One can see that the galaxies we find are located on the tail of the general distribution and have unusual line ratios, greater than most of the galaxies in SDSS. We give an example of such a galaxy (SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1; 7054-56575-500) at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.138 that has a ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/H\\,\\alpha } = 0.17$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">High <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[N\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> emission line ratios are generally attributed to LINER galaxies (see for example Kewley et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a> and references within), though the ratios we measure for our outlier galaxies deviate from the typical ratio produced by a LINER galaxy. These galaxies can therefore be extreme cases of LINER galaxies in which we do not detect the H\u03b2 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> emission due to limited SNR, or high dust extinction along the line of sight to the AGN. Alternatively, the high emission line ratio can be due to shock ionization from galactic-scale winds (Heckman\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>; Dopita &amp; Sutherland\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; L\u00edpari et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Veilleux, Cecil &amp; Bland-Hawthorn\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Allen et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). One can find in the literature additional examples of high <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{log\\,[S\\,\\small {II}]/{\\rm H}\\,\\alpha }$|</span> emission line ratios measured with integral field spectroscopy within individual lines of sight in galaxies (e.g. Singh et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a> and Cheung et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438694 id=\"58438694\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5>4.5 Extremely red and sodium excess galaxies</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 47 galaxies that have extremely red continua and/or unusually strong sodium absorption.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438696 id=\"58438696\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5-1>4.5.1 Sodium excess galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">38 galaxies have very strong sodium (NaID 5889, 5895\u2009\u00c5) absorption, some with extremely red continua as well. There is some debate in the literature regarding the origin of the NaID excess objects \u2013 one explanation is that the NaID excess is related to the interstellar medium (ISM), either due to galactic-scale gaseous outflows in star-forming galaxies or cool gas that resides in the disc, another explanation is that the absorption is stellar, and due to variations in metal abundance. van Dokkum &amp; Conroy (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, and references therein) suggested that an initial mass function (IMF) in early-type galaxies with a larger number of low-mass stars (less than 0.3\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>) may lead to stronger NaID absorption.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to address these questions, Jeong et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a>) compiled a catalogue of roughly 1000 NaID excess objects up to SDSS DR7. They limited themselves to the redshift range <em>z</em> \u2264 0.08 and applied further colour cuts to ensure the completeness of their sample, from which they identified the NaID excess objects. The authors used the absorption line measurements of all the galaxies in the SDSS performed by Oh et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and defined the index fNaD as follows: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{{\\rm fNaD} = \\frac{{\\rm NaD}_{{\\rm observed}} - {\\rm NaD}_{{\\rm model}}}{{\\rm NaD}_{{\\rm model}}}},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where NaD<sub>observed</sub> is the observed NaD line strength and NaD<sub>model</sub> is the expected model NaD line strength. The expected NaD<sub>model</sub> is also taken from Oh et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), where the authors fitted population synthesis models from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and stellar templates by S\u00e1nchez-Bl\u00e1zquez et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and calculated internal reddening due to dust. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> chose 1603 galaxies for which <em>f</em>NaD\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.5 (i.e. observed strength is 50\u00a0per\u00a0cent stronger than expected by model; see fig. 1 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a>) and defined them as their sodium excess objects.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 24 galaxies that were not part of the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> sample, some for obvious reasons such as the redshift cut, the SDSS data release, and the colour cuts they performed. We find four galaxies that satisfy the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> cuts in DR7 but were not part of their sample, possibly due to erroneous measurement of the observed NaD. We present in the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a> the histogram of the NaID excess objects from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> compared to the outlying galaxies we find. In the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig16\" data-open=\"fig16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a>, we show an example of such outlying galaxy, at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.024, compared to the best SDSS model of this galaxy. One can see that the observed NaID is more than double the strength expected from the model. We list the NaID excess objects in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A9</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"58438700\" scrollto-destination=\"58438700\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig16\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=zOpNBgPHvhJlE8YirNWRWgK~PLQETRM5hnKib648QIIYKPR1YS0xESj1esheJHkrvbTNpScCyru8fGFVf~VMjMNyuugqxF6YZLgzenS-~-i6OsiuRNITO6L9O1usDi~mJAwAe9Ud8JM-iVOT4UHboINAd~xCRZVLoaE6cU9C8KGk~wfB87FqBe5-PQoDGJH64NsH4vRHNzy5cvVukwfMYxLTT-6IXiJiHmtCR1WmFEwOd2MWV7j1BgVym412EzRa66wwZHIatoZYvbpS2MAekUMES1G9jkBlDwNHyEUf24rXhnGXLsobrQKjWCuvKEvhegUikXiIYo32DhibHdoDQA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of NaID excess index (see Section\u00a04.5.1 for definition) of the NaID excess objects studied by JE13 (grey bars); these are the 1603 galaxies that have the most extreme discrepancy between the observed NaID and the NaID predicted from a standard model of a galaxy. We mark the indices of the 13 outlying objects our algorithms finds, which are also present in the JE13 sample. The right-hand panel presents the galaxy SDSS J123308.44+262057.6 (2235-53847-0086), which is not included in the JE13 catalogue, at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.024 (black), compared to the SDSS best-fitting model (green). One can see that the observed NaID absorption is more than double what is expected from to the best-fitting model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438700/stw3021fig16.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438700\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=xu1zjSqpGMoqs4ZqtGQZwO4Casmf6bmINxrLR1iWTzWFHFB4f3kukvXXI~-8yPzErsr4K5xnzajyr85V3li8KXs0KhW7OCck44XBjWZbh3rXAqC8JxB7UJBB2QnJQsgwGqP8CLcxO9Lt1s8ROnf4ZxQIjIGCs8xOWHlwx6mtpyk5lc2Q7AqPKGx8zwb3VNW9fROaudaB2FngXbre28p3G3b0wzG~D7PuUSGpL4dwqw7qgsAeGeBbR7QHS2CQyfI2zLopJ27fLGUy91ygkyal2q3hhkkG4f4j7A0nCYfjlBtvF~L-9TOOYIwS92kUqmjsyvCfEz4ZSMbwfYP8tPTcvg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438700&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of NaID excess index (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.5.1</a> for definition) of the NaID excess objects studied by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> (grey bars); these are the 1603 galaxies that have the most extreme discrepancy between the observed NaID and the NaID predicted from a standard model of a galaxy. We mark the indices of the 13 outlying objects our algorithms finds, which are also present in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> sample. The right-hand panel presents the galaxy SDSS J123308.44+262057.6 (2235-53847-0086), which is not included in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> catalogue, at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.024 (black), compared to the SDSS best-fitting model (green). One can see that the observed NaID absorption is more than double what is expected from to the best-fitting model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig16\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=zOpNBgPHvhJlE8YirNWRWgK~PLQETRM5hnKib648QIIYKPR1YS0xESj1esheJHkrvbTNpScCyru8fGFVf~VMjMNyuugqxF6YZLgzenS-~-i6OsiuRNITO6L9O1usDi~mJAwAe9Ud8JM-iVOT4UHboINAd~xCRZVLoaE6cU9C8KGk~wfB87FqBe5-PQoDGJH64NsH4vRHNzy5cvVukwfMYxLTT-6IXiJiHmtCR1WmFEwOd2MWV7j1BgVym412EzRa66wwZHIatoZYvbpS2MAekUMES1G9jkBlDwNHyEUf24rXhnGXLsobrQKjWCuvKEvhegUikXiIYo32DhibHdoDQA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of NaID excess index (see Section\u00a04.5.1 for definition) of the NaID excess objects studied by JE13 (grey bars); these are the 1603 galaxies that have the most extreme discrepancy between the observed NaID and the NaID predicted from a standard model of a galaxy. We mark the indices of the 13 outlying objects our algorithms finds, which are also present in the JE13 sample.
