One can see that the observed NaID absorption is more than double what is expected from to the best-fitting model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438700/stw3021fig16.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438700\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig16.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=xu1zjSqpGMoqs4ZqtGQZwO4Casmf6bmINxrLR1iWTzWFHFB4f3kukvXXI~-8yPzErsr4K5xnzajyr85V3li8KXs0KhW7OCck44XBjWZbh3rXAqC8JxB7UJBB2QnJQsgwGqP8CLcxO9Lt1s8ROnf4ZxQIjIGCs8xOWHlwx6mtpyk5lc2Q7AqPKGx8zwb3VNW9fROaudaB2FngXbre28p3G3b0wzG~D7PuUSGpL4dwqw7qgsAeGeBbR7QHS2CQyfI2zLopJ27fLGUy91ygkyal2q3hhkkG4f4j7A0nCYfjlBtvF~L-9TOOYIwS92kUqmjsyvCfEz4ZSMbwfYP8tPTcvg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438700&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig16.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of NaID excess index (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.5.1</a> for definition) of the NaID excess objects studied by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> (grey bars); these are the 1603 galaxies that have the most extreme discrepancy between the observed NaID and the NaID predicted from a standard model of a galaxy. We mark the indices of the 13 outlying objects our algorithms finds, which are also present in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> sample. The right-hand panel presents the galaxy SDSS J123308.44+262057.6 (2235-53847-0086), which is not included in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JE13</a> catalogue, at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.024 (black), compared to the SDSS best-fitting model (green). One can see that the observed NaID absorption is more than double what is expected from to the best-fitting model.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=58438701 id=\"58438701\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5-2>4.5.2 Extremely red galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 19 galaxies that are extremely red, most of them show a diagonally shaped continuum. We use the galaxy composite catalogue by Dobos et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a>). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> classified all the galaxies in SDSS DR7 by colour, nuclear activity and star formation activity, and constructed a set of spectra with high SNR and high resolution. They fitted the continuum of the composite spectra using the population synthesis models by Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and found that the composite spectra represent the different galaxy populations well. Using the best stellar population synthesis model, they extracted the best metallically and the optical depth of interstellar dust. The <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> composites are divided into colours \u2013 red, green and blue \u2013 and into classes \u2013 passive, star forming, H\u03b1 detected, AGN and H\u03b1 detected (for objects which show both nuclear activity and substantial star formation), LINERs and Seyfert galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Composite spectra that belong to the same class of galaxies (passive for example) but in a different colour bin differ not only in dust optical depth but also in metallicity and stellar population. We therefore use all the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> composite spectra and apply additional dust reddening to them in order to reach the continuum shape we observe in our galaxies. We use the prescription by Fitzpatrick (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) for the additional dust extinction and find the best composite spectrum and the additional dust reddening to be applied to this composite in order to reproduce the continuum shape of our galaxies. We find that for all of our objects, the reddest composite spectrum is a better fit than the green and the blue. For these <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> derive metallicity value of <em>Z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.02.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The dust reddening we find ranges from <em>E</em>(<em>B\u2212V</em>) = 0.3 to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{{\\rm {\\it E}}}{(B-V}) = 0.9$|</span> for our outlying galaxies; this is in addition to the dust that is derived by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> in their stellar population synthesis models, giving in total colour excesses between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{{\\rm {\\it E}}}{ (B-V)}$|</span>= 0.5 and 2.2. We show two examples of extremely red galaxies and their best <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> composite plus additional reddening in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig17\" data-open=\"fig17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">17</a>. We find that the best-fitting composite for SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel) belongs to the H\u03b1 detected class, with colour excess derived from population synthesis of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{{\\rm {\\it E}}}{(B-V)} = 0.15$|</span> but with an additional E(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00.95. The second object (right-hand panel), SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-0115), is best described by a LINER galaxy composite with a total of E(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00.98. We list these galaxies in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl10\" data-open=\"tbl10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A10</a>, where we note specifically the galaxy SDSS J044023.25+245402.0 (1257-52944-314) with E(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a01.6, caused by MW dust. These galaxies are rare in SDSS due to colour selection.</p>                        <a id=\"58438705\" scrollto-destination=\"58438705\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig17\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 17.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig17.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=DB0UZ2Z7g-9dGTCIDKA9mGiuPC81cZ5QnkgBnbIupa~smdggyZoTzv5oueVMrOmQCUY4OkL1tJFGOVqLQCM0qUlioDhb~nLYuxaGRwGWpmVEmk9Gyg0N0iljtNwbH10Sdd3TrsuQ6OgUQQV9qKvl86Lc8L78~DAgfFTK2fl34ROMh-Ilwv6qZOpgO3VMB31rZCA-qxKZJdvhwoEHxoSAYEH4iCzHkW55eAA9w9~mSI4peJyxfkIwch5iucJcY9S677moEjZGSa1wX8y~9JpZtZP1TVsJryAAkppsddSSXFbvbMc18lt1FbclC6BAX6nxLPUtnP5KuXqZ~k1BO46pxw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of two galaxies that show diagonally shaped continua. We fit the galaxies with the galaxy composites constructed by DO12 with additional reddening in order to match their red colours. SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with an \u2018H\u03b1 detected\u2019 composite with total dust reddening of EB\u00a0\u2212\u00a0V\u00a0=\u00a01.1 (pink) and SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-115; right-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with a LINER composite with total EB\u00a0\u2212\u00a0V\u00a0=\u00a00.98.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438705/stw3021fig17.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438705\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig17.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=nTuAxkbJJxsuJm10HJbUwPg5ccOGlv7w6pViZz3mk14ZoWvu~CKw0or2dYE7zG2GCBLae-d0xnIj9dP-X26ybpHfA70T9Y0~-0tDCTxGrM4ghXh1ySFZFz-4yrb8ynEi-TlrqAsn0UiRbWtgg34F10RJVIJRoyjpUtxP3PIhiL0rZHax6l1whPasiGmZTKu4ggZGVPJCh3-ZpZT3YkhLf8JfOlZM66d7DBMSTczix4f0YlFc2l3lljhgxP647mskmJx2XwG4l6Sgrjh~taol9mPoEKZsWvv-o8k-~1kmHUn0qRRzmJSHX7MLiYsSzMoh3DCnBHM-yiNS0qQgb5PGSA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438705&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of two galaxies that show diagonally shaped continua. We fit the galaxies with the galaxy composites constructed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> with additional reddening in order to match their red colours. SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with an \u2018H\u03b1 detected\u2019 composite with total dust reddening of E<sub><em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.1 (pink) and SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-115; right-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with a LINER composite with total E<sub><em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.98.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig17\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 17.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig17.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=DB0UZ2Z7g-9dGTCIDKA9mGiuPC81cZ5QnkgBnbIupa~smdggyZoTzv5oueVMrOmQCUY4OkL1tJFGOVqLQCM0qUlioDhb~nLYuxaGRwGWpmVEmk9Gyg0N0iljtNwbH10Sdd3TrsuQ6OgUQQV9qKvl86Lc8L78~DAgfFTK2fl34ROMh-Ilwv6qZOpgO3VMB31rZCA-qxKZJdvhwoEHxoSAYEH4iCzHkW55eAA9w9~mSI4peJyxfkIwch5iucJcY9S677moEjZGSa1wX8y~9JpZtZP1TVsJryAAkppsddSSXFbvbMc18lt1FbclC6BAX6nxLPUtnP5KuXqZ~k1BO46pxw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Examples of two galaxies that show diagonally shaped continua. We fit the galaxies with the galaxy composites constructed by DO12 with additional reddening in order to match their red colours. SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with an \u2018H\u03b1 detected\u2019 composite with total dust reddening of EB\u00a0\u2212\u00a0V\u00a0=\u00a01.1 (pink) and SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-115; right-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with a LINER composite with total EB\u00a0\u2212\u00a0V\u00a0=\u00a00.98.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438705/stw3021fig17.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438705\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig17.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=nTuAxkbJJxsuJm10HJbUwPg5ccOGlv7w6pViZz3mk14ZoWvu~CKw0or2dYE7zG2GCBLae-d0xnIj9dP-X26ybpHfA70T9Y0~-0tDCTxGrM4ghXh1ySFZFz-4yrb8ynEi-TlrqAsn0UiRbWtgg34F10RJVIJRoyjpUtxP3PIhiL0rZHax6l1whPasiGmZTKu4ggZGVPJCh3-ZpZT3YkhLf8JfOlZM66d7DBMSTczix4f0YlFc2l3lljhgxP647mskmJx2XwG4l6Sgrjh~taol9mPoEKZsWvv-o8k-~1kmHUn0qRRzmJSHX7MLiYsSzMoh3DCnBHM-yiNS0qQgb5PGSA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438705&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig17.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Examples of two galaxies that show diagonally shaped continua. We fit the galaxies with the galaxy composites constructed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">DO12</a> with additional reddening in order to match their red colours. SDSS J024721.99\u2212043259.1 (7054-56575-500; left-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with an \u2018H\u03b1 detected\u2019 composite with total dust reddening of E<sub><em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.1 (pink) and SDSS J024639.41\u2212080525.9 (7057-56593-115; right-hand panel; black) is best reproduced with a LINER composite with total E<sub><em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.98.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438706 id=\"58438706\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-6>4.6 Galaxies hosting supernovae</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 18 galaxies in which a supernova happens to have exploded when the spectrum was taken. Supernova rates are of order one per galaxy per century (e.g. Li et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), or one per 5000 weeks. Assuming a supernova maintains a luminosity comparable to its host's for about a week, there should be hundreds of such objects in the SDSS galaxy sample, which is rare but not ridiculously so. There are several studies whose main goal is the detection of supernovae in the galaxy spectra of the SDSS, and they found 15 of our objects. In all of these studies, the galaxy spectra are fitted with galaxy eigenspectra that are obtained from PCA analysis of SDSS galaxies. Supernova detection is then carried out on the residual between the galaxy spectrum and its best eigenspectra fit, using various methods of template fitting: Madgwick et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) used wavelet transform in order to obtain a residual which is noiseless, and then cross-correlated it with a set of type Ia spectral templates. Tu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), Krughoff et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), Graur &amp; Maoz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and Graur, Bianco &amp; Modjaz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) used PCA or singular value decomposition (SVD) of supernovae spectroscopic templates to fit the residual. In all of these cases, it was necessary to use both galaxy and supernova templates in order to detect the supernovae. We list the outlying galaxies with supernovae in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl11\" data-open=\"tbl11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A11</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) is reported here for the first time since the galaxy is part of DR10, while Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) worked with the DR9 galaxy sample. We present in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig18\" data-open=\"fig18\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">18</a> the galaxy spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel) where one can notice additional, broad, features that the best SDSS model does not account for. We subtract the best-fitting SDSS model from the spectrum and normalize the residual with a continuum fit and compare the residual to a type Ia supernova template from Nugent, Kim &amp; Perlmutter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) 2\u00a0d after the <em>B</em>-band maximum. This is shown in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig18\" data-open=\"fig18\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">18</a>. One can see that the supernova template matches well the broad residual features in our galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"58438709\" scrollto-destination=\"58438709\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig18\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 18.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig18.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=KpLln~2-yKPi5GU~maXO6yyhbsRJCfI4kEeKpo4LaavYUBB9ZTezQ1UCJ6~H2cBfH9isC8gaF7emkaeHG4ykCLqplskH8QH~V4IVLnpIDT4g9Maf-F83xyFToxBvf~~EmwZmDTfmMeCr8HLFkxHEguUa1hhD7AIa2uHU9TOLJNWuAoRDdr3-sWc7dDlTnF4I5KpPCPQX65~lhE8xA7YM67iHnRDl9HXa~dVfizX5sZJf0ZAVfbsDu8NXjj7HsU5KcqZCkbYSb5nyapsc9gsRcaBvy4GFrzTiF~-hrDRZhkhMuuKQF4LV03qqlF2ohH6M8wtDSFkLOAudnknkVwdcgQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel), where one can see that the SDSS model fails to account for some broad features in the spectrum. We subtract the model from the spectrum and normalize it with a continuum fit (right-hand panel; black) and compare it to a supernova template (2\u00a0d after the peak) which we also normalize (green). One can see that the supernova template is able to account for the residual broad features in the galaxy spectrum.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438709/stw3021fig18.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438709\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig18.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=M7twKoKw7TbcL3ZBsd7iBpTuwO7R3jcXLKgixI~w3BNpruNC0LPaDIPk7f-YPedxLXAa6czvX4EcwyPMtGL29UaZ-pf1aK0MNKvdpT5zO36iqSIcMicmIs8U~MT0dPLJTGWei76wLteL6xh1xuxmEOY6ppAVkdBa0NoCNl61Pxo4ZBc6P35~rqJ8HeNZaeHN2Y9Wc0LrEhaOTygk-2361wvptbfV66C3BJcrZ9qynm-8fFfZr5Fyccq4bi80pxlhjjRs6xwferbDmg3drI027Xi~SWMiAHLC92Dr-ntMFWOF0VxRo-eH-gCXZfsnG9RHJdc3JC51z~1ADOcqLIqj5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438709&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel), where one can see that the SDSS model fails to account for some broad features in the spectrum. We subtract the model from the spectrum and normalize it with a continuum fit (right-hand panel; black) and compare it to a supernova template (2\u00a0d after the peak) which we also normalize (green). One can see that the supernova template is able to account for the residual broad features in the galaxy spectrum.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig18\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 18.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig18.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=KpLln~2-yKPi5GU~maXO6yyhbsRJCfI4kEeKpo4LaavYUBB9ZTezQ1UCJ6~H2cBfH9isC8gaF7emkaeHG4ykCLqplskH8QH~V4IVLnpIDT4g9Maf-F83xyFToxBvf~~EmwZmDTfmMeCr8HLFkxHEguUa1hhD7AIa2uHU9TOLJNWuAoRDdr3-sWc7dDlTnF4I5KpPCPQX65~lhE8xA7YM67iHnRDl9HXa~dVfizX5sZJf0ZAVfbsDu8NXjj7HsU5KcqZCkbYSb5nyapsc9gsRcaBvy4GFrzTiF~-hrDRZhkhMuuKQF4LV03qqlF2ohH6M8wtDSFkLOAudnknkVwdcgQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel), where one can see that the SDSS model fails to account for some broad features in the spectrum. We subtract the model from the spectrum and normalize it with a continuum fit (right-hand panel; black) and compare it to a supernova template (2\u00a0d after the peak) which we also normalize (green). One can see that the supernova template is able to account for the residual broad features in the galaxy spectrum.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438709/stw3021fig18.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438709\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig18.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=M7twKoKw7TbcL3ZBsd7iBpTuwO7R3jcXLKgixI~w3BNpruNC0LPaDIPk7f-YPedxLXAa6czvX4EcwyPMtGL29UaZ-pf1aK0MNKvdpT5zO36iqSIcMicmIs8U~MT0dPLJTGWei76wLteL6xh1xuxmEOY6ppAVkdBa0NoCNl61Pxo4ZBc6P35~rqJ8HeNZaeHN2Y9Wc0LrEhaOTygk-2361wvptbfV66C3BJcrZ9qynm-8fFfZr5Fyccq4bi80pxlhjjRs6xwferbDmg3drI027Xi~SWMiAHLC92Dr-ntMFWOF0VxRo-eH-gCXZfsnG9RHJdc3JC51z~1ADOcqLIqj5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438709&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig18.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J080821.09+005035.3 (4745-55892-0018) spectrum and its best SDSS model (left-hand panel), where one can see that the SDSS model fails to account for some broad features in the spectrum. We subtract the model from the spectrum and normalize it with a continuum fit (right-hand panel; black) and compare it to a supernova template (2\u00a0d after the peak) which we also normalize (green). One can see that the supernova template is able to account for the residual broad features in the galaxy spectrum.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J085425.56+180507.0 (2281-53711-0149) and SDSS J085436.69+180552.9 (2281-53711-0156) are also reported here for the first time. These spectra were in DR7, but the SDSS pipeline failed to fit the correct redshift to them, mistaking the H\u03b1 emission for Ly\u2009\u03b1 at high redshift. We derive the correct redshift by fitting the narrow <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> and H\u03b1 emission lines, finding redshifts of 0.094 and 0.211, respectively. For this reason, they were missed by Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Using the same fitting procedure as described in Graur &amp; Maoz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), we find that SDSS J085425.56+180507.0 is either a type Ia or a type Ic near maximum light. SDSS J085436.69+180552.9 is most likely a type Ia near peak (O. Graur, private communication).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438711 id=\"58438711\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-7>4.7 Blends</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We find 27 outliers that are blends of two objects. These include 6 galaxy\u2013galaxy gravitational lenses, 9 spectra with two sets of emission lines, and 12 spectra that appear unusual due to chance alignment of a galaxy and a nearby star. We list the galaxies that are contaminated by nearby stars in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl12\" data-open=\"tbl12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A12</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple studies were carried out with the goal of finding gravitationally lensed galaxies in the SDSS spectroscopic data (Bolton et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Brownstein et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Tsalmantza &amp; Hogg\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Shu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). These studies focused on galaxies with two sets of nebular emission lines at redshifts that differ significantly. For example, Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) used the best-fitting model obtained by the SDSS pipeline and subtracted it from the spectrum, resulting in a residual spectrum. The residual spectrum underwent a match-filtering algorithm that was designed to find an additional set of emission lines. Tsalmantza &amp; Hogg (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) used a data-driven model that recovered most of the known galaxy lenses in the SDSS by constructing basis functions for dimensionality reduction. Overall, up to DR12, these studies have found 392 galaxy lens candidates in the SDSS. We list the six galaxy lenses our algorithm recovers in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl13\" data-open=\"tbl13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A13</a>, all of which were reported by previous studies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The second subset consists of objects with two sets of emission lines that were not previously reported as galaxy lenses. The second set of nebular emission lines is due to a close companion (i.e. at a small angular separation) to the primary galaxy, and in most of the objects the primary and the companion galaxy are somewhat to well distinguished in the SDSS imaging. For each of the objects, we fit two sets of emission lines with Gaussians in order to ascertain that all the nebular lines of the secondary set differ by the same velocity compared to the primary set of lines and measure the redshift of the secondary object. In all of the cases, the redshift produced by the SDSS pipeline belongs to the more luminous set of emission lines. We find that for seven out of eight of the objects the secondary set of emission lines is emitted by gas at a lower redshift than the primary. For three of the pairs, we find an SDSS spectrum of the secondary galaxy as well as the primary, and find that the redshift estimation of the secondary galaxy is equal to the redshift we derive from the second set of emission lines in the primary's object spectrum. We present an example of such galaxy in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig19\" data-open=\"fig19\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">19</a>, where we show the SDSS image of the primary and secondary galaxy (left-hand panel; the cross indicates the primary object) and the spectrum of the primary, shifted to its rest frame, where one can see two sets of emission lines. The first set of emission lines is at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the second set at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063, which is the redshift of the secondary galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"58438715\" scrollto-destination=\"58438715\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig19\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 19.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig19.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=QipTlMwfxehqcB8AE9yUGyuyJIAqoqVLLhywlAuYykrhjd4hIYUtcdY-GNa4wtSdbLHpMMxU5dKOHEteHXB48jJiS8FD2VueuF6XusmDE6n5sCdwMAOjAfpmvo3iZ9mmyT7NI87HYrdxHbKpt6rOd3B1rpcmSoK9a6cGP1WvFMDDOBNdZXEyQVdAYGOxU-MOME6cOs4ePddW1jzh8f1r-1qk3jVDhBkQ9S-CsAu10sk-ovnlmH4D8Y62BXHgNAue0GPrPfVW0747URXmgL42Ht0ziQ6jD2EDfwwxfUXaq4LbmvAirJUqNeg4BpAszF-E4HRhhrYfIyBCpjiL~z2CaA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example of a galaxy with two sets of emission lines. The primary galaxy (SDSS J161754.02+320627.4; 1420-53146-528), marked with a cross in the image from the SDSS (left-hand panel), is at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.117. The secondary galaxy (SDSS J161753.62+320633.8) is at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.063 and the gas in its outskirts is along the line of sight towards the primary galaxy. The spectrum of the primary galaxy (right-hand panel) consists of two sets of emission lines, one at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the other at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.063.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438715/stw3021fig19.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438715\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig19.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=GwrJe88rlpoDoUNRdt1r7S~gbFBMYygPYfdyyyJmuAHSLFCGx2f~4RkvtcKQHAhj0LV~jzRkFPTGYOrSbbKpOmXk-BNWAmsUdQ2nUD~YBoxBpiRKjMEcP7304fqHSbKYiY4RA3GS9IOs1pzRLmqiwrDHpbOLqby8bXCP9HiPgJh0cqezf-LGkW2yXrmWkwown2NUfgvpgzlhJ~jz0BY~G9dkrs9LGd5tDd0DKYWHJ2ZW3mDdKbg7EqQM7-n20iP456EqAwyZ48Oo~~NIrNZlnvIhZszLZvH66msgIuWxsanLncN-2swv54dRcAv1Rqd5zxasE7BDuRo8x42bxLljBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438715&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of a galaxy with two sets of emission lines. The primary galaxy (SDSS J161754.02+320627.4; 1420-53146-528), marked with a cross in the image from the SDSS (left-hand panel), is at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117. The secondary galaxy (SDSS J161753.62+320633.8) is at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063 and the gas in its outskirts is along the line of sight towards the primary galaxy. The spectrum of the primary galaxy (right-hand panel) consists of two sets of emission lines, one at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the other at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig19\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 19.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig19.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=QipTlMwfxehqcB8AE9yUGyuyJIAqoqVLLhywlAuYykrhjd4hIYUtcdY-GNa4wtSdbLHpMMxU5dKOHEteHXB48jJiS8FD2VueuF6XusmDE6n5sCdwMAOjAfpmvo3iZ9mmyT7NI87HYrdxHbKpt6rOd3B1rpcmSoK9a6cGP1WvFMDDOBNdZXEyQVdAYGOxU-MOME6cOs4ePddW1jzh8f1r-1qk3jVDhBkQ9S-CsAu10sk-ovnlmH4D8Y62BXHgNAue0GPrPfVW0747URXmgL42Ht0ziQ6jD2EDfwwxfUXaq4LbmvAirJUqNeg4BpAszF-E4HRhhrYfIyBCpjiL~z2CaA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example of a galaxy with two sets of emission lines. The primary galaxy (SDSS J161754.02+320627.4; 1420-53146-528), marked with a cross in the image from the SDSS (left-hand panel), is at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.117. The secondary galaxy (SDSS J161753.62+320633.8) is at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.063 and the gas in its outskirts is along the line of sight towards the primary galaxy. The spectrum of the primary galaxy (right-hand panel) consists of two sets of emission lines, one at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the other at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.063.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438715/stw3021fig19.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438715\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig19.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=GwrJe88rlpoDoUNRdt1r7S~gbFBMYygPYfdyyyJmuAHSLFCGx2f~4RkvtcKQHAhj0LV~jzRkFPTGYOrSbbKpOmXk-BNWAmsUdQ2nUD~YBoxBpiRKjMEcP7304fqHSbKYiY4RA3GS9IOs1pzRLmqiwrDHpbOLqby8bXCP9HiPgJh0cqezf-LGkW2yXrmWkwown2NUfgvpgzlhJ~jz0BY~G9dkrs9LGd5tDd0DKYWHJ2ZW3mDdKbg7EqQM7-n20iP456EqAwyZ48Oo~~NIrNZlnvIhZszLZvH66msgIuWxsanLncN-2swv54dRcAv1Rqd5zxasE7BDuRo8x42bxLljBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438715&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig19.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of a galaxy with two sets of emission lines. The primary galaxy (SDSS J161754.02+320627.4; 1420-53146-528), marked with a cross in the image from the SDSS (left-hand panel), is at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117. The secondary galaxy (SDSS J161753.62+320633.8) is at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063 and the gas in its outskirts is along the line of sight towards the primary galaxy. The spectrum of the primary galaxy (right-hand panel) consists of two sets of emission lines, one at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.117 and the other at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.063.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We list all the objects in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl14\" data-open=\"tbl14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a>, and note the redshift of the primary and secondary sets of lines. One of the objects, SDSS J160818.74\u2212002745.4 (345-51690-229), is an exception, since no clear companion can be seen in the imaging. Furthermore, the secondary set of emission lines is at a higher redshift than the primary galaxy, and these two sets are separated only by 2860\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The spectrum provided by the SDSS is a median spectrum that consists of a few subexposures of the same galaxy, each of them undergoes a separate wavelength solution, sky subtraction and flux calibration. The calibrated spectra are then combined using a median filter. A wrong wavelength solution could cause the median spectrum (with which we work) to appear as a spectrum with two (or more) sets of emission lines. We compare the subexposures of J160818.74-002745.4 and find two sets of emission lines in all of them, indicating that this is not an instrumental error.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note an additional object, SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773), for which the secondary redshift estimation is based only on two emission lines, one of which is marginally detected. The primary redshift of the galaxy is <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133 and no clear companion is detected in the imaging. However, we find an unidentified emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observer's frame, and its FWHM is inconsistent with the FWHM of the emission lines of the galaxy. Assuming the unidentified emission line is due to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> 3727\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the rest frame of a background galaxy, we estimate the redshift of the background galaxy to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733. We show the spectrum of the galaxy in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig20\" data-open=\"fig20\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">20</a>, where the supposedly <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission is marked with a green dashed line (left-hand panel). In the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig20\" data-open=\"fig20\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">20</a>, we mark the wavelength of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> 5007\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame for the redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733, which match a weak feature in the spectrum. The FWHM values of both of them are consistent with each other. The flux of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission is in the range expected from star forming galaxies at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733, thus no magnification is needed in order to explain the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission strength. We therefore conclude that their background galaxy is not strongly lensed.</p>                        <a id=\"58438718\" scrollto-destination=\"58438718\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig20\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 20.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/m_stw3021fig20.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&amp;Signature=N09VPJuF00xmZJBIl7QCqXbqwyyEE6JY7LURHj5IoLNbhzw7YHUPQssdW2CSxk7xYku2EN9PqkI~wB~uqJTKt9MJ5wB6GzMhWm6nnWwREh15k1qSvG~VF2a0ew85elVVci918YyF6ElsfGDxZcj-aJP3qGm3iZ1kpovRkbYFqHSxN0a2cXyVMFX4A-iFiNth24IzTUUgPf-7K3VF1PLcJWAHSwsFambuGW2~9TzfHA1uOkoPeemoWYLdw6TgHlumlLMDwYZ6MV~xyKquhtd2mI07rvwGmJS9jofUwlM1ygrPvmIoMg5lue3yz7cOy9fEyol4gJ6KfkQ~yn9giZ0ImQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773) is a galaxy at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.133 for which we detect an emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame. This emission line is broader than the emission lines that belong to this galaxy (left-hand panel) and does not match in wavelength to any known emission lines at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.133. Assuming the emission line is due to $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$ 3727\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the rest frame of a background galaxy, we estimate the redshift of the background galaxy to be z\u00a0=\u00a00.733. We mark in the right-hand panel the wavelength of $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$ 5007\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame for the redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.733, which matches a weak feature in the spectrum. Since the flux of the supposed $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$ emission is within the range expected for galaxies at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.7, we conclude that this galaxy is another case of galaxy\u2013galaxy chance alignment.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438718/stw3021fig20.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438718\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig20.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Nf6QsfwTndMsLiNx5kdZOdnU3FPRyPdQmSve1Rvrp~bGIIFBOg4vL0AQhtA1GJc5AM8eUFpxW6wBS2RZgsnK43KynvK3P6HrN8qSMYbua8HOpMSmHS6MshDOst~ejxYbngs6IOCWiKbekMq2kOL~et6gAtO0TyUqxmOMQaUj9Pce9lS55KnptVVPeSV8HjT6mfsAYcsoWnTHgL3QqtpehlvLsjhoEZWxfePC3vg~rk19xYqe5Ca2Wsxd70fb1aYsfDDauS4nbIECgI4ZwMsBLn8HZYVxxJyGOh-hAvHjQywBaRXIu-nMNtyySSZzewec9tad~3ODyg7nns2GL~0s5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438718&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133 for which we detect an emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame. This emission line is broader than the emission lines that belong to this galaxy (left-hand panel) and does not match in wavelength to any known emission lines at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133. Assuming the emission line is due to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> 3727\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the rest frame of a background galaxy, we estimate the redshift of the background galaxy to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733. We mark in the right-hand panel the wavelength of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> 5007\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame for the redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733, which matches a weak feature in the spectrum. Since the flux of the supposed $\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$ emission is within the range expected for galaxies at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a00.7, we conclude that this galaxy is another case of galaxy\u2013galaxy chance alignment.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/58438718/stw3021fig20.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"58438718\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/465/4/10.1093_mnras_stw3021/1/stw3021fig20.jpeg?Expires=1611466760&Signature=Nf6QsfwTndMsLiNx5kdZOdnU3FPRyPdQmSve1Rvrp~bGIIFBOg4vL0AQhtA1GJc5AM8eUFpxW6wBS2RZgsnK43KynvK3P6HrN8qSMYbua8HOpMSmHS6MshDOst~ejxYbngs6IOCWiKbekMq2kOL~et6gAtO0TyUqxmOMQaUj9Pce9lS55KnptVVPeSV8HjT6mfsAYcsoWnTHgL3QqtpehlvLsjhoEZWxfePC3vg~rk19xYqe5Ca2Wsxd70fb1aYsfDDauS4nbIECgI4ZwMsBLn8HZYVxxJyGOh-hAvHjQywBaRXIu-nMNtyySSZzewec9tad~3ODyg7nns2GL~0s5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=58438718&ar=2568826&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw3021fig20.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J210931.70+080114.8 (4079-55363-773) is a galaxy at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133 for which we detect an emission line in wavelength 6460\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame. This emission line is broader than the emission lines that belong to this galaxy (left-hand panel) and does not match in wavelength to any known emission lines at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.133. Assuming the emission line is due to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> 3727\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the rest frame of a background galaxy, we estimate the redshift of the background galaxy to be <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733. We mark in the right-hand panel the wavelength of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {III}]}$|</span> 5007\u00a0\u00c5\u00a0in the observers frame for the redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.733, which matches a weak feature in the spectrum. Since the flux of the supposed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[O\\,\\small {II}]}$|</span> emission is within the range expected for galaxies at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.7, we conclude that this galaxy is another case of galaxy\u2013galaxy chance alignment.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=58438719 id=\"58438719\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-8>4.8 Calibration errors, source confusion and sky contamination</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This group of outliers is a mixed bag of objects that are broadly defined as not being astronomically \u2018interesting\u2019. This includes calibration errors and SDSS pipeline misclassifications. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we remove pixels that are marked as bad by the SDSS pipeline, and we also apply a median filter for the removal of residual cosmic rays and unresolved sky emission. The SDSS also provides quality flags for all the plates and all their spectra. Since we do not limit ourselves to plates of good quality only, it is inevitable that some bad spectra exist in our data set. Additionally, our algorithm finds the relatively few objects that were misclassified by the SDSS pipeline, and we include them here.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">First, we identify 41 galaxy spectra that are in fact single stars. Additionally, we find five spectra of white dwarfs that were mistakenly identified as galaxies, four of these were previously reported as white dwarfs by Girven et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and Kleinman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and one of them, SDSS J103259.82+442202.2 (2567-54179-177), is reported here for the first time. SDSS J141118.31+481257.6 (1671-53446-0010) is identified as a galaxy at redshift 0.135 by the SDSS pipeline. However, it is actually an AM Canum Venaticorum star, which is a rare type of cataclysmic variable star, where a white dwarf accretes hydrogen-poor matter from a compact companion star (Anderson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). We list these in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl15\" data-open=\"tbl15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>. Finally, 10 objects suffer from various problems such as bad sky subtraction and wrong flux calibration (i.e. flux level from the blue and red arms of the spectrograph do not match; Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl16\" data-open=\"tbl16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438722 id=\"58438722\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CONCLUSIONS AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have introduced an outlier detection algorithm that is based on an unsupervised implementation of RF. By construction, the algorithm learns the most important features of the data and their interconnections; it is completely general and can be applied to imaging data, time series and other spectroscopic objects as well. Out of 2355\u00a0926 galaxies that compose the input sample, we chose 400 galaxies with the highest weirdness score. We find objects with unusual emission line ratios, and complex velocity structures, extremely red objects, objects with extremely strong absorption lines (i.e. sodium and H\u03b4), galaxies which host supernovae, or have rare emission lines.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The algorithm finds a large variety of outliers arising from a large variety of physical environments. It is sensitive to the ratio between emission lines, thus to the radiation field that gas in a galaxy is exposed to, and to the metallically of the gas. It is sensitive to the widths of emission lines i.e. objects with extreme velocity dispersion, or with a number of different velocity components. It is sensitive to the shape of the continuum and to its connection to the strength of the emission lines and absorption lines. It recovers a number of rare phenomena that are subject to great attention in the astronomical community: H\u03b4-strong galaxies, outflows and shocks, supernovae, galaxy-lenses, double-peaked emission lines that may be due to galaxy mergers or binary BHs. Only about a fifth of the objects we find were discovered in previous studies, using specific algorithms that isolate a single type of objects they were looking for (or searching by eye). Our algorithm detects all of them in one fell swoop. Despite how thoroughly SDSS has been explored before, we found two rare classes of galaxies that were never noticed or studied before, E+A galaxies with broad emission lines and strong <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{[N\\,\\small {I}]}$|</span>-emitting galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Apart from these, the algorithm detects a number of different \u2018instrumental\u2019 outliers, and can be used to detect pipeline failures in new or ongoing surveys. Most importantly, since the sole input to the algorithm is the data, with no physical rules or user specifications, and we find that it is able to detect some of the most interesting phenomena in the SDSS sample, this algorithm can be used to search for new objects that represent new phenomena \u2013 searching for the truly unknown unknowns.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From a performance perspective, the increasing volume and complexity of astronomical data requires the development of new algorithms for detection, classification and analysis of large data sets. The LSST, for example, is expected to conduct 32 trillion observations of 40 billion objects (Ivezic et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). These data sets can no longer be placed on a single compute node nor can they be analysed at once with a single processor. The framework of DFS has evolved as a possible solution to this challenge and parallelization had become an essential methodology in it. The RF-based outlier detection we propose is completely parallel and operates naturally in the DFS framework. Furthermore, the algorithm is suitable for ongoing surveys where static data are replaced by data streams \u2013 new data are chunked and decision trees are trained without the need to re-run the process on the entire data set. RF's ability to operate with missing values is an additional important feature. Finally, the algorithm can work with an extremely large number of features with little to no cost in execution time.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=58438727 id=\"58438727\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgments</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank our referee, Y. Ascasibar, for useful comments and suggestions that helped improve this manuscript. We thank G. Ferland, N. Foerster Schreiber, A. Gal-Yam, O. Graur, T. Heckman, D. Maoz, B. M\u00e9nard, H. Netzer, P. Nugent, E. Ofek, J. X. Prochaska and D. Watson who helped us identify some of the unusual objects we found, and gave us valuable advice regarding this manuscript. DP is partially supported by Grant No 2014413 from the United States\u2013Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The bulk of our computations was performed on the resources of the National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center, which is supported by the Office of Science of the U.S. Department of Energy under Contract No. DE-AC02-05CH11231. The spectroscopic analysis was made using <span class=\"small-caps\">ipython</span> (P\u00e9rez &amp; Granger\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). We also used the following <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> packages: pyspeckit,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> scikit-learn<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> (Pedregosa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and astropy.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work made extensive use of the SDSS-III<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a> data. Funding for SDSS-III has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation and the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science. SDSS-III is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS-III Collaboration including the University of Arizona, the Brazilian Participation Group, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Carnegie Mellon University, University of Florida, the French Participation Group, the German Participation Group, Harvard University, the Instituto de Astrofisica de We note that some galaxies are classified into multiple categories; in this case, we present the galaxy in every class (and table) it belongs to.</p>                        <a id=\"58438743\" class=\"chapter-para\">(2) SDSS MJD of the observation.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN054\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN054\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(3) SDSS fibre ID of the galaxy.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN055\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN055\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(4) Redshift from SDSS pipeline, whenever available we use <em>z</em><sub>NOQSO</sub> that is more reliable.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN056\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN056\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(5) Best-fitting template from the SDSS galaxy composites by Dobos et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p></span></div><span class=\"articleListNewPopContent articleListNewAndPopular-ContentView-MostRecent hasContent\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"newPopularList-Article_RightRailB0Article_RightRail_ArticleNewPopularCombined\" class=\"fb\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-layout widget-layout--vert\">\r\n            <div class=\"widget-columns widget-col-1\">\r\n                    <div class=\"col\">\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3878\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3878/6041709?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 14": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Table correctly loaded": "", "Lens Kind": "1", "Message on table quality": "Found 'weird' systems in SDSS, of which all lenses mentioned in table are found by SLACS"}, "Table map to MasterLens database": {"Plate": "('PLATE', '(1)')", "MJD": "('MJD', '(2)')", "Fiberid": "('FIBER', '(3)')", "z_Lens": "('z', '(4)')@spectroscopic@"}}}, "Table 15": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 16": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 17": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}}}}, "Tables status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "The weirdest SDSS galaxies: results from an outlier detection algorithm", "authors": ["Baron, Dalya", "Poznanski, Dovi"], "author_address": ["AA(School of Physics and Astronomy, Tel-Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel), AB(School of Physics and Astronomy, Tel-Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "465", "publication_year": "2017/03/1", "start_page": "4530", "end_page": "4555", "keywords": ["methods: data analysis", "methods: statistical", "galaxies: general", "galaxies: peculiar", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017MNRAS.465.4530B", "abstract": "How can we discover objects we did not know existed within the large data sets that now abound in astronomy? We present an outlier detection algorithm that we developed, based on an unsupervised Random Forest. We test the algorithm on more than two million galaxy spectra from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and examine the 400 galaxies with the highest outlier score. We find objects which have extreme emission line ratios and abnormally strong absorption lines, objects with unusual continua, including extremely reddened galaxies. We find galaxy-galaxy gravitational lenses, double-peaked emission line galaxies and close galaxy pairs. We find galaxies with high ionization lines, galaxies that host supernovae and galaxies with unusual gas kinematics. Only a fraction of the outliers we find were reported by previous studies that used specific and tailored algorithms to find a single class of unusual objects. Our algorithm is general and detects all of these classes, and many more, regardless of what makes them peculiar. It can be executed on imaging, time series and other spectroscopic data, operates well with thousands of features, is not sensitive to missing values and is easily parallelizable.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stw3021", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1611.07526", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
